headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Brookfield to Acquire Paper Maker for $2.15 Billion
abstract: Brookfield Asset Management will acquire Longview Fibre, a paper and container maker, for $2.15 billion including debt. The Canadian real-estate firm will pay $24.75 a share, or an 18 percent premium to Longview’s closing price Friday. Through the deal, Brookfield will gain 588,000 acres of timberland in the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Sparks Fly at Congressional Hearing on Executive Pay
abstract: Lawmakers clashed Thursday over the idea of giving shareholders a voice in approving executive pay, while a top regulator scolded companies for failing to deliver the clear-cut pay disclosures now expected by the Securities and Exchange Commission. After a House hearing, Rep. Barney Frank (D-Mass.), chairman of the Financial Services Committee, said his panel would vote this month on a bill that would require all companies to allow shareholders to vote annually on pay deals approved by directors, as well as on “golden parachutes” for departing executives.

headline: Mills Board Tells Management to Open Talks With Simon
abstract: Directors of The Mills Corporation, a mall developer, told company leaders Tuesday to start discussions with the Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management over their offer to buy the company. Responding to the pair’s offer, which would top a $1.35 billion deal with a Canadian investor, Brookfield Asset Management, the Mills board determined that the competing $1.6 billion bid “is reasonably likely to lead to a superior competing transaction,” company officials said in a statement.

headline: What’s In a Name? $400 Million
abstract: After the announcements of the twin $400 million naming-rights deals inked by British bank Barclays, for the Nets new arena, and Citigroup, for the Mets new stadium, the Jets and the Giants must be salivating as they look over the next year to sell the naming rights to their $1.2 billion stadium in the Meadowlands. They professional football teams have hired the Wasserman Media Group to handle the transaction, and yesterday, Jeff Knapple, the president of WMG Marketing told The New York Times: “We’ve watched with a keen eye toward what the Mets and the Nets have done. It’s an indication of the power of the New York marketplace and its position in the nation and the world.”

headline: Blackstone Buys Xstrata Stake in Exploration Projects
abstract: Blackstone Ventures is buying Xstrata Nickel‘s interest in three Norway exploration projects for $15.5 million. The deal will give Blackstone all the outstanding shares of a joint venture partner and Xstrata subsidiary, Sulfidmalm, as well as full control of the Norwegian projects.

headline: A Look Inside Blackstone’s Money Machine
abstract: Blackstone Group, confirming a firestorm of speculation, said Thursday it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion. The preliminary prospectus offered a first glimpse inside Blackstone’s closely guarded money machine, which churned out $2.3 billion in profit in 2006. The offering is being structured to allow Blackstone to retain many advantages of a private business — a setup that Breakingviews compares with Berkshire Hathaway under Warren Buffett.

headline: Firms Said to Quit Claire’s Stores Auction
abstract: The auction for preteen trinket retailer Claire’s Stores appears to be stumbling after several private-equity firms dropped out ahead of the deadline for final bids Wednesday, according to The New York Post. The retail chain, which has been on the block since November, recently reported less than stellar fourth-quarter earnings, prompting several buyout firms to drop out of the auction, The Post said.

headline: Scania’s Profits Shore Up Bargaining Position with MAN
abstract: Shortly after a German competitor dropped its hostile bid, the Swedish truck maker Scania reported healthy profits for last year, giving it a position of strength to negotiate a better deal, the Financial Times reported Thursday. The German company, MAN, dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid earlier this week and instead proposed a friendlier alliance. But one of Scania’s largest shareholders, the Investor holding vehicle of Sweden’s Wallenberg family, insisted that the company could “stand alone.” Scania posted an operating income of 8.75 million krona, up 28 percent for the year.

headline: HCP Tables Rival Bid for Candian REIT
abstract: Health Care Property Investors Inc., the largest U.S. owner of real estate for healthcare providers, jumped into the bidding for Toronto-based Sunrise Senior Living Real Estate Investment Trust with an offer of C$2.3 billion ($2.0 billion). HCP said it is offering about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars for Sunrise REIT’s equity, which represents a 20 percent increase on a rival offer made in January by Ventas. HCP is offering C$18 a unit, valuing the equity at about C$1.4 billion. Ventas has offered C$15 per unit.

headline: Rival Caremark Suitors in War of Words
abstract: The high-stakes battle to acquire Caremark Rx, pharmacy benefits manager, escalated on Thursday when Express Scripts urged Caremark shareholders to reject an offer from the drugstore chain CVS. In a letter to Caremark shareholders, Express Scripts said that the CVS deal would have a “lasting negative impact” and called the CVS offer insufficient.

headline: Senate Democrats Warn F.C.C. of Tough New Oversight
abstract: Signaling tougher oversight, Democrats who recently gained control of the Senate urged the head of the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday to take a more aggressive approach to the industries he oversees. In his first appearance before the Senate Commerce Committee under Democratic leadership, Kevin J. Martin, the agency’s chairman, and the other commissioners faced sharp criticism from some senior senators on the handling of the recent acquisition of BellSouth by AT&T.

headline: Just ‘Citi’ as the Brand, and a Folded Umbrella
abstract: Citigroup, the global banking giant, is shrinking – but only its name. Executives are prepared to rebrand the company “Citi” and to fold up its familiar red umbrella and instead use a logo with a stylized arc above the name. The new name and look will be presented to the Citigroup board this week following a 14-month review of the bank’s brand, according to The New York Times.

headline: Siemens Chief Won’t Resign Over Corruption Inquiry, Report Says
abstract: Siemens‘ chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld, ruled out resigning over a corruption affair at the German conglomerate. He told the Bild newspaper, in an interview to be published on Monday, that he did “not even for a second” consider giving up his position at Siemens.

headline: Sears C.F.O. Resigns
abstract: Sears Holdings‘ chief financial officer resigned Friday after less than four months on the job, the latest in a string of high-level executive changes as billionaire Edward Lampert searches for ways to make money on one of his biggest, and most challenging, investments. The executive, Craig Monaghan, plans to leave at the end of January and return to Florida where his family lives, according to an announcement from the Hoffman Estates-based company. William Crowley, chief administrative officer and chief financial officer before Mr. Monaghan’s arrival, will assume the C.F.O. role while Sears looks for a replacement.

headline: Did Someone Say ‘Climate Change?’
abstract: Davos sends a warning of global warming.

headline: Bharti to Put Up $2.5 Billion in Venture With Wal-Mart
abstract: India’s Bharti Enterprises of India plans to invest up to $2.5 billion to set up a nationwide chain of supermarkets and retail shops in partnership with  Wal-Mart, a top executive at the Indian company said. The investment will be spread over the next eight years and create jobs for about 60,000 people, Bharti’s joint managing director, Rajan B. Mittal, told reporters Monday. “The company has planned an investment of $2 billion to $2.5 billion by 2015,” Mr. Mittal said.

headline: Fund Seeks Data on Delta-Northwest Talks
abstract: Delta Air Lines, which previously downplayed reports that it held merger talks with Northwest Airlines, acknowledged holding discussions about a “possible business combination” with Northwest while it was fighting a $10 billion hostile bid from US Airways. The disclosure stemmed from a dispute involving a group of dissatisfied Northwest shareholders, led by hedge fund Owl Creek Asset Management.

headline: Breeden Talks Tough, Then Walks the Walk
abstract: Around lunchtime in New Orleans, former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Richard Breeden told the audience at the Corporate Law Institute that he had a message for directors who think they can sit out the rise in shareholder activism: “Change will come. It’s only a matter of who brings it.”

headline: Bruce McLaren Film Gathering
abstract: With the announcement at the A1 Grand Prix in Taupo, New Zealand of the plans to make a film about Bruce McLaren, the founder of the Formula One team of same name, there was a meeting of several important drivers and other people associated with or related to Bruce McLaren.

headline: Tribune Plans to Shun Outside Bids, Report Says
abstract: More than four months after Tribune put itself on the auction block, the newspaper and television business is leaning away from accepting any outside offers, favoring a “self-help” plan instead, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Court to Caremark: Not So Fast
abstract: In the fierce contest to acquire Caremark Rx, a judge has called time out. Granting a request from a Louisiana pension fund that owns shares of the company, a judge in Delaware’s Court of Chancery said Tuesday he would block a shareholder vote on Caremark’s proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS, which had been scheduled for Feb. 20. “The court is not confident that all Caremark shareholders would be able to make an informed decision if they are required to vote on February 20,” Judge William B. Chandler III said in a letter, Reuters reported.

headline: Venture Capitalist Dies in Apparent Suicide
abstract: Todd Brooks, a venture capitalist who spent several years at the Mayfield Fund before leaving in 2003, died from an apparent suicide attempt, peHUB reported. He was 46 years old.

headline: Ronald Burkle Harvests His Wild Oats
abstract: After stocking up on shares of Wild Oats Markets, Ronald W. Burkle is set to check out at a tidy profit. Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, agreed Wednesday to pay $565 million for Wild Oats, a smaller competitor whose largest shareholder is Mr. Burkle’s investment firm, Yucaipa. At $18.50 a share, Whole Foods’ offer values Yucaipa’s nearly 18 percent stake at about $94.4 million. Yucaipa paid about $54 million, net of commissions, for its 5.1 milion shares, regulatory filings show.

headline: Treasury Official Defends New Hedge Fund Guidelines
abstract: Days after a presidential commission recommended a hands-off approach to regulating hedge funds, the Treasury Department is defending its new guidelines against critics who say the new rules don’t go far enough, according to The Financial Times. Answering naysayers — who include several state attorneys general — Robert K. Steel, a deputy to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., said that the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets would stand firm on its report’s recommendations.

headline: Court Rejects Suit Against Enron Banks
abstract: A federal appeals panel ruled Monday that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars after the company collapsed in 2001.

headline: E.ON Faces an 11th Hour Upset in Deal for Endesa
abstract: In yet another twist in the ongoing saga of E.ON‘s attempt to buy its Spanish rival Endesa, Enel, Italy’s biggest power company, said on Wednesday that it might increase its stake in Endesa to almost 25 percent. In a move that threatens to thwart E.ON’s yearlong, 41 billion euro takeover bid for Endesa, the Italian utility said onTuesday it had acquired 9.99 percent of Endesa for about 4.13 billion euros ($5.47 billion). Enel said Wednesday it is considering raising the stake to as much as 24.99 percent.

headline: Prediction: Spending Slowing
abstract: Economists are saying that sales will slow in 2007. But that is not a worrisome projection, they say.

headline: Study Questions Hedge Funds’ Stock-Picking Prowess
abstract: Evidence is weak that hedge funds are better stock pickers than mutual funds, a recent academic study suggests. The study was based on quarterly reports of funds’ long positions filed with regulators, rather than on published hedge fund indexes, which some say paint a skewed picture of hedge funds’ returns.

headline: Trouble at HSBC Stemmed from Household Purchase
abstract: The deterioration in the United States mortgage market has now forced the departures of two top executives at HSBC Holdings, one of the world’s biggest banking companies. HSBC said on Thursday that Bobby Mehta was stepping down as head of its North American business and as chief executive of HSBC Finance. Sandy Derickson, chief executive of HSBC Bank USA and vice chairman of HSBC Finance, is also leaving.

headline: Banks Cut Off New Century’s Credit
abstract: New Century Financial, the troubled mortgage company, said Thursday that it had stopped accepting new loan applications as it tried to negotiate terms with banks that had cut off its access to billions of dollars in funds. But in an indication that at least one of its lenders continues to have confidence in the company, New Century said it had received $265 million to finance loans and cover other obligations and $710 million to replace a credit line. The company did not identify the lender, but The New York Times reported that it was Morgan Stanley who provided the loan.

headline: Carlyle to Cut Stake in China’s Xugong, Report Says
abstract: The Carlyle Group has agreed to take a reduced stake in Xugong Group Construction Machinery of China in a bid to help speed approval of the deal, which has been awaiting government approval for more than a year, according to The Wall Street Journal. Carlyle has signed an agreement to take a 45 percent stake in Xugong, The Journal said.

headline: Immelt Slaps Down “Stupid” Deal Chatter
abstract: This, apparently, is what General Electric‘s chairman and chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, had to say about a report that he is considering selling NBC Universal: “That was more or less made-up stupid drivel.”

headline: Motorola Chief’s Non-Bonus Came to $1.27 Million
abstract: It was widely reported earlier this month that Motorola‘s chief executive, Edward Zander, received no annual bonus last year, after Motorola’s cell phone business derailed during the fourth quarter, hammering the company’s profits.

headline: 2 Law Firms Call Off Their Plans for a Merger
abstract: One of the biggest proposed law firm mergers of the last year has been called off, the victim of too many insurmountable issues. Dewey Ballantine and Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, who jointly announced the news Thursday, had been in talks to create one of the nation’s largest legal advisers, with 1,500 lawyers based in New York and San Francisco. But questions about a variety of problems, ranging from management seniority to Dewey’s unfunded pension system, undermined the deal.

headline: The Lonely Newspaper Reader
abstract: Recalling the recent surprise announcement by McClatchy that it had decided to sell The Minneapolis Star Tribune for $530 million to a group of private equity bidders, The New York Times’s David Carr takes a look at what has happened to reading the newspaper at the breakfast table.

headline: Porsche Makes a Bid for the Rest of Volkswagen
abstract: Porsche made a bid for Volkswagen that values the carmaker at 35.8 billion euros ($47.7 billion), a low offer intended to leave Porsche with a controlling stake rather than full ownership.

headline: BMO Adds Senior Bankers in U.S.
abstract: Moving to bolster its deal-advisory offerings in the United States, Canada’s BMO Capital Markets said it hired a head of U.S. mergers and acquisitions in its Chicago office and a head of energy investment banking in Houston. Both bankers were previously at Deutsche Bank, BMO said.

headline: Home Depot Considers Sale of Contractor-Supply Unit
abstract: Home Depot said Monday that it had hired Lehman Brothers to consider a sale or spinoff of its contractor-supply business, a move that would undo an ambitious and expensive diversification strategy advocated by its recently ousted chief executive, Robert Nardelli.

headline: How Rising C.E.O. Pay Spreads
abstract: Is Kenneth Langone “Patient Zero” — the primary carrier of a malady that makes corporate boards feverishly inflate executive pay? At the least, he is what The New Yorker’s James Surowiecki dubs a “supercarrier,” given his track record, which includes that of the recently ousted Home Depot head, Robert L. Nardelli. And abetting Mr. Langone is the clubby world of corporate boards, an increasingly interconnected social network where directors and executives tend to scratch each other’s back.

headline: The Latest Investment-Banking Bonus: A Life
abstract: Investment banks have long been known as the preserve of hundred-hour weeks, where leaving the office only to change clothes is considered a badge of honor. But according to Fortune, Wall Street is discovering that some of its best people don’t believe that being chained to the office is a mark of greatness — and are leaving for saner pastures. Now, Lehman Brothers and its rivals are turning to “return to work” recruitment programs to lure those employees back. The draw: lighter schedules and less travel.

headline: BP Plans to Bid for Yukos Assets in Auction
abstract: BP said on Friday that it planned to bid against the state-owned oil giant Rosneft in a bankruptcy auction for assets of the Yukos oil company, a surprise announcement that signaled BP’s deepening involvement in Russia’s turbulent energy sector.

headline: Citigroup Bids $10.8 Billion for Japanese Brokerage
abstract: In what would be its largest takeover in Asia, the banking giant Citigroup bid $10.75 billion for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage that has been struggling with an accounting scandal. The cash offer is part of a broader effort at Citigroup to reengineer its business in Japan, which is the world’s second-largest economy but accounts for a relatively small part of Citi’s business. Citi has suffered some setbacks in Japan in recent years, including the shutdown of its private bank there, which regulators ordered to close in 2004.

headline: Australian Insurer Buys 2nd U.S. Firm
abstract: The QBE Insurance Group, Australia’s largest property and casualty insurer, has agreed to buy the United States arm of Winterthur for $1.16 billion, its biggest purchase ever and its second American acquisition in three weeks. The deal will add $1.45 billion in annual sales to QBE, which is based in Sydney, the company said Thursday.

headline: Carlyle’s Great Experiment
abstract: In the past five years or so, famed private equity firm Carlyle Group has transformed itself from a company that focused primarily on buying and selling defense companies that did business with governments, to one that now deals in a broad swath of alternative assets. The firm also cut ties with some of its high-profile political advisers, including George H.W. Bush and John Major. BusinessWeek takes a look at how — and why — the firm’s founders undertook this radical overhaul.

headline: Cerberus’ Snow Calls on China to Open the Gates
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management Chairman and former U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow said China needs to open the country’s market for overseas investors to create the 25 million new jobs a year the nation needs. His call comes as New York-based Cerberus is opening a Hong Kong office to expand into China, the world’s fastest-growing major economy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bear Stearns Seeks to Expand — Literally
abstract: Bonus-flush investment bankers may be preparing to spend on pricey new real estate, and now it appears at least one of their companies will, too. Bear Stearns is close to signing a deal to drastically expand its midtown Manhattan location, The New York Observer reported Wednesday. After acquiring 240,000 square feet in two leases signed last year, the investment bank is looking to buy an additional 104,000 square feet at its 237 Park Ave. offices, the Observer said, citing three sources close to the deal. If completed, it would be the largest New York City lease of 2007 thus far.

headline: Questions Grow About CNBC Anchor’s Ties to Sources
abstract: Whether it is providing a personalized video tribute – shot from inside the CNBC newsroom – to Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the buyout giant Blackstone Group to celebrate his 60th birthday, or mingling with a source at a benefit for the New York City Ballet, the proximity of the CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo to the people she covers has created a model of journalism that jibes perfectly with the network’s mandate to add pizzazz and drama to its coverage.

headline: McAfee to Take Charges Related to Stock Options
abstract: McAfee, the security software developer, said late Monday that it expects to record charges of $25 million to $45 million over “several periods commencing with the fourth quarter of 2006″ related to the improper granting of stock options. In October, McAfee announced that it had discovered the improper accounting of up to $150 million in option grants, and Chairman and Chief Executive George Samenuk subsequently resigned.

headline: 2 Former Cendant Executives Spared Prison Sentences
abstract: Two former executives of Cendant were spared prison time on Monday for their roles in an accounting scandal that cost the company and its investors more than $3 billion. One of them, Anne Pember, 47, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in 2000, was sentenced to two years’ probation and 200 hours of community service. The other, Casper Sabatino, 54, a former accountant who admitted wire-fraud charges and cooperated with federal prosecutors, was sentenced to two years’ probation.

headline: Hedge Funds Pushes for Ultratech Sale
abstract: In the latest example of hedge fund activism, the largest shareholder in the struggling chip equipment maker Ultratech has called for management to bolster sales or consider selling the company. In a letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, a New York-based hedge fund, Thales Fund Management, called Ultratech undervalued and suggested management put the company up for sale if it cannot increase its share price this year.

headline: The Future of Hydrogen Cars
abstract: The pros and cons of alternative-fuel vehicles.

headline: Icahn Offers to Buy Auto-Parts Maker Lear
abstract: After placing a big bet on the beaten-down auto-parts business in October, Carl C. Icahn is doubling down. Mr. Icahn, who recently spent $200 million to increase his stake in Lear  to nearly 16 percent, has offered to acquire the entire company, Lear said in a news release early Monday. American Real Estate Partners, which Mr. Icahn controls, will offer $36 a share in cash for Lear, valuing the auto-parts maker at about $2.4 billion based on the number of shares outstanding on Nov. 3. The offer was about 4 percent more than Lear’s closing price of $34.67 on Friday.

headline: Serving Up a Side Dish to a Scandal
abstract: Wall Street is still trying to digest the news that 13 people, including current and former employees at top investment banks, were arrested in connection with what prosecutors are calling one of the biggest insider-trading schemes in decades. But the Grand Central Oyster Bar, the 94-year-old eatery where the stock-tipping schemes were allegedly hatched, seems to see a delicious bit of humor in the whole thing.

headline: Glu Mobile Goes Public in $84 Million Offering
abstract: Glu Mobile, a publisher of games for mobile phones, raised $84 million in an initial public offering that priced late Wednesday. The offering, which values the entire company at $327 million, comes amid what the GigaOm blog calls a slow resurgence of technology I.P.O.’s.

headline: Ritchie Capital Sells Financing Unit to BlueCrest
abstract: Ritchie Capital Management has sold its start-up finance business to BlueCrest Capital, a hedge fund firm partly owned by the British industry giant Man Group, MarketWatch reported. In a letter to investors cited by MarketWatch, Bluecrest said it had bought the finance vehicle, Ritchie Technology & Life Sciences, for an undisclosed price.

headline: Attorney General Shake-Up May Delay Options Inquiries
abstract: The recent shake-up in the United States Attorney’s office in San Francisco could lead to delays in the office’s wide-ranging backdating investigation, according to The San Jose Mercury News. The turnover, which includes the departure of a United States Attorney, Kevin Ryan, comes as the government’s scrutiny of options backdating at Apple appears to be heating up. Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission officials interviewed Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, last week as part of that investigation, the newspaper said.

headline: Quattrone Drops Hints About His Next Move
abstract: Few people know exactly what Frank Quattrone, formerly the sine qua non of technology bankers, is going to do next. Lots of people seem to think it will be big. Mr. Quattrone isn’t telling.

headline: EMI Sings Familiar Refrain: No Deal
abstract: Few deals have been proposed and rejected as many times as the one between music labels EMI Group and Warner Music Group. The latest installment in the saga came Friday when EMI of Britain said it rejected a proposal from Warner Music, of New York, under which Warner would offer to acquire it for 260 pence per share, or about $4.1 billion. The offer came with too many regulatory risks and was too low anyway, EMI said in a statement on its Web site.

headline: Martha Stewart’s Company: Recipe for a Buyout?
abstract: The market continues to debate whether Martha Stewart Omnimedia, the publishing empire that has launched countless dinner parties and glue-gun adventures, could inspire a leveraged buyout deal as well. Such speculation has helped to lift the company’s stock in the past, but judging from the shares’ recent decline, hope is fading. Further cooling the takeover chatter, Susan Lyne, the company’s chief executive, recently told TheStreet.com that a buyout is “unlikely.”

headline: Fast Times for Wall Street’s Debt Whizzes
abstract: Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDO’s and CMBS’s. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner, who reports that “bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans.”

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Saving the Nation Through Procreation
abstract: The aging of Western Europe is a continuing concern, leading to worries that there will not be enough workers to support generous public pension policies.

headline: Santander Takes Stake in Italy’s Capitalia
abstract: Grupo Santander, Spain’s largest bank, has moved deeper into the Italian market with the purchase of a 2 percent stake in Capitalia, the Italian bank at the center of merger speculation, The Financial Times reported. Santander also reported a 13 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits.

headline: LCD vs. Plasma: And the Winner Is…
abstract: LCD may be winning the battle of the marketplace, but the industry has long known that its technology has come up short in a number of areas, when compared to plasma’s overall picture quality.

headline: Four Car-Rental Brands May Merge
abstract: A deal to combine four of the nation’s largest car rental brands — National, Alamo, Thrifty and Dollar — is being discussed as the industry continues to consolidate. Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group is in early talks to merge with Vanguard Car Rental, of Tulsa, Okla., which owns National and Alamo, in a deal valued at more than $3 billion, according to The New York Times.

headline: For Many M.B.A.’s, a Big Graduation Present Ahead
abstract: “It’s a really good time to be an M.B.A.,” Andy Chan, assistant dean and director of the M.B.A. Career Management Center at Stanford University, tells Bloomberg News. How good? Last year, graduates of Harvard Business School averaged a record $186,174 in starting pay, while new M.B.A.’s from Stanford’s business school earned an average of $183,000. Starting pay for graduates from the top business schools may rise further, thanks to intense competition for them among big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Chief Talks Private Equity
abstract: Are private equity deals getting too expensive? A reader of the Financial Times’s Web site posed that timely question to Philip Purcell, the former chief executive of Morgan Stanley. His answer was a definite maybe. Mr. Purcell, who is now the president of Continental Investors, replied that prices are high enough that some buyout firms might see lower returns on current deals than they saw over the past 15 years. “History would say that some buyers are overpaying,” he said during an online Q&A.

headline: Current Hedge Fund Regulations Work, Report Says
abstract: A group of top United States regulators on Thursday recommended market discipline and risk awareness, rather than new regulations, as the best safeguards for the burgeoning hedge-fund industry. The conclusions, intended as guidelines, were part of a report published by the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, which includes the Federal Reserve Board, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: Steel Makers Prepare to Duke It Out Over Corus
abstract: The furnaces are stoked for a red-hot finish to the sale of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus Group, The Deal.com says India’s Tata Steel and its Brazilian rival Cia. Siderúrgica Nacional, are preparing to face off in a 10 hour, nine-round auction that begins Tuesday. The battle could spark offers dramatically higher than the 5.78 billion pounds ($11.33 billion) already on the table, according to The Deal.

headline: Security Software Startup TriCipher Raises $15 Million
abstract: TriCipher, which makes security software and appliances, said it raised $15 million in a third round of venture funding led by RBC Technology Ventures. The investment brings TriCipher’s total equity funding to more than $30 million and is expected to be its final private round.

headline: Onex Unloads Aerospace Firm
abstract: Six years after buying aerospace components maker CMC Electronics, Canadian private equity firm Onex has sold it to aerospace company Esterline Technologies for C$391.5 million ($335 million). Montreal-based CMC makes global positioning systems and other aviation parts, including vision systems, flight bags and flight management tools.

headline: Shell Ups Bid for Canadian Unit
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell, Europe’s biggest oil company, raised a bid to buy out its Canadian unit by 13 percent to 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) to gain increased production from oil sands. Shell, which owns 78 percent of Shell Canada, raised its bid to 45 Canadian dollars a share, from an offer of 40 Canadian dollars a share made in October.

headline: V.C.’s Welcome in San Jose, Study Finds
abstract: Venture funding in San Jose, Calif., during 2006 totaled about $616.4 million, up 27.4 percent from the previous year, according to a report released Monday. The report, from VentureDeal and the Business Performance Management Forum, said San Jose’s venture financing growth was more than double the national average.

headline: SXR Uranium to Acquire UrAsia for $3.1 Billion
abstract: SXR Uranium One, South Africa’s largest uranium miner, will buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion, forming the world’s second-largest uranium producer as surging demand propels prices. SXR offered 7.05 Canadian dollars ($6.01) a share in stock for UrAsia, a 13 percent premium over the company’s closing price on Friday.

headline: Smaller Exchange Avoids Big Problems
abstract: As the markets dropped sharply last week, sending volume soaring and backing up trades handled by the New York Stock Exchange, at least one stock market player was resting easy. Bats Trading, an upstart electronic trading system based in Kansas City, Mo., said it handled the volatility with none of the glitches that others did.

headline: Chevron Will Split Chief and Chairman Jobs
abstract: Chevron announced Monday that it would separate the positions of chief executive and chairman and make it easier for shareholders to remove directors. The company, based in San Ramon, Calif., said in a public filing that the chairman will now be elected annually by the board. Previously, the oil producer’s chief executive automatically occupied the role of chairman.

headline: Conrad Black: a Media King Dethroned
abstract: New York, according to Vanity Fair’s Maureen Orth, was Conrad Black’s downfall.

headline: Microsoft in Deal to Buy Tellme, Report Says
abstract: Microsoft is close to acquiring Tellme Networks, a privately held maker of products that bridge the worlds of speech recognition and the Internet, in a deal that could come as early as this week, according to CNet News.com.

headline: Livedoor Given Japan’s Largest Corporate Fine
abstract: The Internet start-up Livedoor was ordered to pay a $2.4 million fine Friday – the largest in Japanese corporate history – for violating securities laws. The fine is the latest blow in a scandal that has led to convictions of seven former executives and accountants. The Tokyo District Court ordered Livedoor to pay the fine – 280 million yen – and its subsidiary Livedoor Marketing to pay $338,000, a court official said on the customary condition of anonymity.

headline: Regulators Are Examining Commerce Bank
abstract: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself “America’s most convenient bank,” rattled investors Tuesday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the bank’s real estate deals with executives. Shares of Commerce fell 8.3 percent, or $2.89, to $31.83, after the bank said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve were conducting an inquiry. Commerce has become one of the fastest-growing banks in the nation, thanks in part to its extended branch hours, and has made an aggressive and successful push into New York’s crowded banking market. Commerce, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said, “The scope of the investigation will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises.”

headline: Why Backdated Options Might Be Contagious
abstract: Directors of corporations often form a tight-knit community, serving at more than one company and creating what are known as interlocking boards of directors. As a result of this chumminess, corporate practices that otherwise might remain confined to just a few companies can spread quickly. That appears to have been the case with the backdating of stock options, according to a new statistical study of publicly traded American companies.

headline: As Housing Slumps, Deal Talk Builds
abstract: Consolidation may be coming among publicly traded homebuilders as the housing market continues to sink, according to an article in BusinessWeek. As if to reinforce the point, the Commerce Department on Friday reported that sales of new homes last year fell by the largest amount in 16 years, though sales rose by a better-than-expected 4.8 percent in December.

headline: Catalina Checks Out with ValueAct for $1.6 Billion
abstract: Catalina Marketing, which had been on the auction block since December, agreed Thursday to a revised $1.6 billion all-cash offer from ValueAct Capital. The $32.10-a-share bid by ValueAct, a hedge fund, represents a 32 percent premium over Catalina’s stock price of $24.23 on Dec. 7, the day before an unnamed private equity firm first emerged as a potential suitor.

headline: Does a Palm Takeover Make Sense?
abstract: As takeover rumors swirl around Palm, the maker of the Treo smartphone, technology analysis firm The 451 Group assesses the fit — or lack thereof — for a half-dozen potential acquirers, including Dell and Hewlett-Packard. The report calls a deal with Research in Motion, which makes the Blackberry handheld device, a “very intriguing possibility.” Such a combination could allow Research in Motion to build a line of Windows devices that are still true BlackBerrys with relatively little effort, The 451 Group writes.

headline: Law Firms Dewey and Orrick Cancel Merger
abstract: The wedding between Dewey Ballantine and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe is off, the two law firms said Thursday afternoon. In a joint statement, the firms attributed the failure of the proposed merger to unspecified complexities in bringing the firms together.

headline: Millennial Media Rings Up $6.3 Million in Funding
abstract: Millennial Media, a mobile-advertising services company started by a former Verizon executive, has received $6.3 million in Series A funding, CNet News.com reported. The funding comes from Bessemer Venture Partner, an investor in companies such as Blue Nile, Skype and VeriSign; Columbia Capital, an investor in Mobi, Nextel and XM Satellite Radio; and Acta Wireless.

headline: Scandal at Siemens Tarnishes Promising Results
abstract: Siemens, the German engineering giant, has reported buoyant financial results, in part reflecting the ambitious overhaul of operations by the company’s chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld. But Siemens is immersed in a fast-expanding corruption scandal that threatens to torpedo its reputation. On Tuesday, Mr. Kleinfeld said the results of Siemens’ internal investigation into accusations of bribery and other misdeeds would not be known before he presented the company’s next strategic plan in April.

headline: Banks Answer Need for Charity Advice
abstract: Spurred on by Warren E. Buffett’s June announcement that he would hand most of his $40 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, philanthropy is increasingly attracting cash infusions from hedge fund managers, real estate moguls and technology entrepreneurs, Bloomberg News reports. And this year, Wall Street bankers and traders sharing more than $36 billion in bonuses may help drive the donations up even more.

headline: Versace Chief Sees Potential I.P.O. Ahead
abstract: Talk of an I.P.O. for Gianni Versace is in fashion as the company posted net profits of $24.1 million for last year on Thursday. Speaking to Women’s Wear Daily, chief executive Giancarlo DiRisio said that he is looking to get Versace on track for a possible stock market listing. But, he stressed it’s up to the owners to decide whether they want to take the company public. A decision will be made later this year.

headline: The Grand Prix Saboteurs
abstract: For years Joe Saward, a fellow Formula One journalist, has regaled me with stories about World War II, the French resistance and the history of the pre-war Grand Prix drivers who played a role in all of those things. Whether it be while talking in Paris near his home around the corner from the Nazi security police headquarters where they interrogated spies and resistance fighters, or on the highways near old French battlefields, or at the German Grand Prix tracks, Joe’s stories about the past always gave a welcome perspective to our usual discussion of today’s F1 circus.

headline: Icahn, in Battle Mode, Offers to Buy Homebuilder
abstract: Carl C. Icahn is getting tough with WCI Communities. The billionaire financier said Tuesday he would offer to buy the residential homebuilder for $22 share and if the company were to resist, he made it clear that he would try to throw out the board and get the deal done regardless. WCI is just one of several companies that Mr. Icahn has been prodding in recent months in what has been an especially active period for the activist investor.

headline: Private Equity Boom Racks Up Bankers’ Fees
abstract: Bankers enjoying their record bonuses from 2006 have, at least in part, private equity to thank, as the industry is poised to pay $11 billion in fees in an unprecedented year for leveraged buyouts. Taking the crown is Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which will pay out more than $837 million in fees to investment banks in 2006, more than any other private equity firm.

headline: Court Approves Settlement of Merrill Analyst Suits
abstract: Merrill Lynch won approval of a $40.3 million settlement of three lawsuits over claims it provided misleading analyst research about Internet companies. Judge John Keenan of United States District Court in New York on Wednesday approved settlements reached after investors appealed the 2003 dismissal of two of the cases. Judge Keenan also awarded $9 million to lawyers who represented almost 400,000 investors who sued.

headline: Palm Stock Surges Amid Deal Chatter
abstract: Shares of Palm jumped 11 percent Friday amid speculation that the company, which makes the Treo smart phone, could attract a takeover offer. Palm has been working with Morgan Stanley to consider its strategic options, people close to the company told DealBook. Separately, analysts at J.P. Morgan on Monday cut their rating on Palm’s stock to “underweight” from “neutral,” writing that the company’s product line appears stale.

headline: Tribune: All Dressed Up and No One to Bid?
abstract: Tribune, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, the Los Angeles Times and Newsday, appears to have thrown a takeover party where no one showed up. With the deadline for final bids today, the private-equity firms that have been meeting with Tribune’s management and looking over its financial records for the past several months do not plan to submit final offers, according to The New York Post.

headline: Hedge Fund Moguls Back Giuliani’s Presidential Fund
abstract: Former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is getting support from some high-flying financiers as he considers whether to run for president in 2008. Data published on Wednesday by PoliticalMoneyLine.com show that contributors to Mr. Giuliani’s presidential exploratory committee, formed in November, include T. Boone Pickens, the Texas mogul who runs the hedge fund BP Capital Management; and Paul Tudor Jones II, the chairman of the hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. The fund also got money from Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, filings show.

headline: Potential Jurors in Black Trial Leery of Salaries in the Millions
abstract: If the first day of jury selection for the former press tycoon Conrad M. Black is any indication, then many in the potential jury pool have not forgotten the corporate scandals of a few years ago. Judge Amy J. St. Eve began the process on Wednesday of winnowing down a pool of more than 100 potential jurors in the criminal fraud trial of Mr. Black and three former associates in United States District Court by asking them about their attitudes toward money, titles and tax loopholes.

headline: Merrill Lynch to Buy First Republic
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would acquire the First Republic Bank, a bank that specializes in serving wealthy individuals, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock. Merrill said its offer for San Francisco-based First Republic represented a price of $55 a share, or 44 percent more than First Republic’s closing stock price on Friday. The deal would be Merrill’s largest acquisition in almost 10 years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: City’s ‘First Lady’ to Leave State Position for Private Firm
abstract: Diana L. Taylor, who as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s companion has been called New York City’s de facto first lady, said Wednesday that she is leaving her job as the state’s superintendent of banking to join boutique investment bank Wolfensohn & Company. The firm, which acts as an adviser to corporations and governments, as well as investing in private equity, said Ms. Taylor will join as a managing director next month.

headline: Greenhill Vice Chairman Returns to His Roots
abstract: Greenhill & Company‘s vice chairman, Harvey Miller, who built Weil, Gotshal & Manges into a bankruptcy powerhouse before he left in 2002, is ending his stint in investment banking to return to his roots. On Wednesday, Mr. Miller said that he would be rejoining Weil as a partner after spending the last five years at Greenhill, a boutique investment bank. Mr. Miller told The American Lawyer that he was “returning to an old love.”

headline: Davos in the Papers: Hedge Funds, Iran, Snow
abstract: There was much ado in the press about German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s speech at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday, with several reports focusing on her stance on hedge funds. Ms. Merkel said proposals to shed more light on hedge funds’ operations would be a priority for her leadership of the Group of Eight industrial nations this year. “We want to minimize the systemic risks in international capital markets and to raise their transparency — above all, I see the need to catch up with hedge funds,” she said.

headline: Unicredit Buys Stake in Moscow Bank
abstract: The Eastern European division of Unicredit of Italy agreed Tuesday to buy a 20 percent stake in a Russian lender, the International Moscow Bank.

headline: Mirant to Sell Six Natural Gas Plants for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Mirant will sell six natural gas-fired power plants to LS Power Equity Partners, an asset management company, for $1.4 billion, the energy said Tuesday. After accounting for project-level debt, Mirant will reap about $1.3 billion, money that it said it would reinvest in other projects or return to shareholders. Mirant was advised by J.P. Morgan Securities and King & Spalding, while LS Power Equity was advised by Barclays Capital and Latham & Watkins.

headline: Sam Zell Seeks Value
abstract: Sam Zell brings hope that newspapers do have value.

headline: Private Equity Firms Face Deadline for J Sainsbury
abstract: The consortium of private equity groups stalking the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury has six weeks to come up with a bid or walk away. The ultimatum, known in Britain as a “put-up-or-shut-up” deadline, was imposed by Britain’s Takeover Panel after the supermarket group appealed for a ruling.

headline: More Analysis of a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
abstract: Microsoft could jumpstart its online business through a purchase of Web giant Yahoo , but such a deal could also “open the door to potentially unmanageable risks,” analysts at UBS said in a report Thursday. The analysts are just the latest to consider whether Microsoft should buy Yahoo. Speculation about such a deal has only increased with Google‘s recent moves deeper into the software business.

headline: Of Bankers, Models and Bottles
abstract: In New York’s West 27th Street club scene, they’re called “bottles.” In New York magazine’s recent profile of Club Row’s rise and fall, they’re referred to as businessmen. But the anonymous writer of the Banker’s Ball blog says he or she knows what they really are: investment bankers. And the blog suggests that Wall Street bankers, many of whom consider nights among models ordering overpriced bottles of premium alcohol to be part of the job description, did their part to build the neighborhood up and then ruin the vibe.

headline: Vornado-Led Group Offers $52 a Share for Equity Office
abstract: A consortium of three real estate companies offered $52 a share for Equity Office Properties Trust after the market’s close Wednesday, stirring up what could be the most expensive buyout contest on record. The three companies — Vornado Realty, Starwood Capital and Walton Street Capital — hope to wrest control of Equity Office, the nation’s largest office-building manager and owner, from the Blackstone Group, which offered a record $36 billion in November, based on a $48 a share bid.

headline: At Goldman, a Push for Middle-Market Deals
abstract: As the merger and acquisition boom rages on, Goldman Sachs, top banker to blue-chip companies, is eyeing middle-market deals as a way to further increase its banking fees, which hit record levels last year. In this case, says Reuters, middle market means companies ranging from $500 million to $2 billion in market value.

headline: Icahn: Buyout Firms Are the Real Raiders
abstract: Carl C. Icahn is not afraid to shake things up at big, publicly traded companies. In the 1980’s, the billionaire financier was known as a “corporate raider”; these days “activist investor” is the preferred term. But in an interview in BusinessWeek, Mr. Icahn suggests that private equity firms are the new corporate raiders — and it does not seem intended as a compliment. Mr. Icahn takes issue with private equity firms’ habit of buying cash-rich companies from public shareholders, piling on debt and selling them later at a profit. “Cash is a great asset,” he told BusinessWeek. “But if private equity investors get their hands on it, they’ll reap the benefit instead of the shareholder.”

headline: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo closed the books on a tough year Tuesday, reporting that its sales rebounded in the fourth quarter from an especially sluggish third quarter and promising investors that it would soon turn on technology that it hoped would close the widening gap with Google.

headline: Amid Hew and Cry, British Buyout Firms Stay on Message
abstract: British private equity leaders, determined to change the perception of themselves as vultures and locusts, stayed on point Monday. Speaking at the annual dinner of the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association, Rod Selkirk, the association’s chairman, said private equity takeovers were responsible for strong growth in British jobs and exports over the past five years. He said the industry had also benefited workers’ pension funds, because their investments in private equity funds had made double-digit gains.

headline: As Regulators Look Deeper into Sony BMG, Warner and EMI Watch from the Sidelines
abstract: Antitrust regulators in Europe said Thursday that they would take a deeper look into the merger of the music units of Sony and BMG, as part of a second review of a union that created the second-largest record company and provoked stiff opposition from independent music publishers.

headline: U.S. May Charge Ex-Executives of Apple and Broadcom, Report Says
abstract: Federal prosecutors are strongly considering criminal charges against former executives of Broadcom, Apple, and KLA-Tencor, related to the backdating of stock options, The Wall Street Journal reported. Prosecutors are also nearing charges against a former official of computer-security company McAfee, the report said. In addition, a former executive of Engineered Support Systems, a defense contractor now owned by DRS Technologies, has been told of a likely charge, according to the Journal.

headline: TXU Buyers Visit With Skeptics
abstract: The Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts made the rounds Monday with some remaining skeptics of their proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU. The firms met with Dallas Mayor Laura Miller and some Texas business leaders who had opposed the company’s original plans to build 11 coal-fired power plants.

headline: G.E. May Buy Abbott’s Diagnostic Unit
abstract: General Electric is near a deal to buy Abbott Laboratories‘ medical diagnostics unit for as much as $5 billion, according to The New York Times. Acquiring the Abbott business, which makes and sells glucose monitoring systems, blood test kits and other chemically based diagnostic tools, would enable G.E.’s health care unit to expand its growing stable of diagnostic products and services.

headline: EU Clears Berkshire Deal for TTI
abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway won approval from European regulators Thursday to buy U.S. company TTI, which distributes electronic components that other companies use to make a range of products. The European Commission cleared the deal automatically after identifying no antitrust problem and receiving no complaints from rivals within a deadline of 25 working days.

headline: Aegerion Pharmaceuticals Plans I.P.O.
abstract: Aegerion Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company whose backers include a private equity firm, Advent International, filed with regulators to raise as much as $86 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Private Capital Management Shrinks Newspaper Stakes
abstract: Private Capital Management, which pressured the Knight Ridder newspaper publisher into selling itself last year, has reduced its holdings in several newspaper chains, the Associated Press reports.

headline: J.P. Morgan Banker to Head to Treasury, Report Says
abstract: Another seasoned banker is set to leave Wall Street for Washington. The Bush administration will soon announce that Tim Ryan, a J.P. Morgan Chase vice chairman, will be the Treasury department’s next under-secretary for international affairs, The Financial Times reported Tuesday. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Ryan, who currently serves as the bank’s vice chairman of financial institutions and governments, will replace Tim Adams, who announced his desire to retire by the summer.

headline: Court Battle: Private Equity vs. Hedge Funds
abstract: In one way, at least, there is a winner in the competition between private equity and hedge funds: Private equity, by a score of 30-17. This battle was fought not on Wall Street, or even in the leafy environs of Greenwich, Conn., but on a basketball court, in a 20-minute charity game on Thursday night. Reuters writer Michael Flaherty has some post-game color:

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Deal Makers Are Setting a Torrid Pace for 2007
abstract: After breaking the record for mergers and acquisitions last year, deal makers have started 2007 at an even faster pace. With the first quarter drawing to a close, the value of corporate deals announced through Wednesday reached $1.08 trillion, according to Thomson Financial. That is 24 percent more than the value of deals in the first quarter of 2006.

headline: Vengence Is Mine, Saith the Executive
abstract: While many chief executives and other high-level managers cite challenges, passion for their industry and even money as their motivating forces, BusinessWeek takes a look at a little mentioned engine that pushes executives to perform: revenge. Examining some high-profile spats, as well as some lesser-known battles, the magazine reminds us of how sweet getting even can be.

headline: Hedge Fund Goes Public and Finds the Water Lukewarm
abstract: The latest hedge fund to hit the public markets found the reception not quite as warm as it had hoped. Brevan Howard Asset Management raised 770 million euros ($1 billion) in an initial public offering of hedge fund BH Macro Limited, about half of the maximum amount originally sought. London-based Brevan Howard had said it planned to raise as much as 1.5 billion euros. The middling performance may be due, in part, to investor wariness after the stock-market swings during the past two weeks and declines in the shares of rivals.

headline: A Wharton Dean Is Named to Lead the Conference Board
abstract: The Conference Board, a business research and consulting group that publishes some of the nation’s leading economic surveys, has selected Jonathan Spector, a vice dean at the Wharton School, as its chief executive. Mr. Spector, 50, will succeed Richard E. Cavanagh, former executive dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who has led the group since 1995. Mr. Cavanaugh announced last March that he was retiring. The selection of Mr. Spector, which is to be announced Monday by the Conference Board’s trustees, came after a yearlong search in which about 250 candidates were evaluated.

headline: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
abstract: Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures. The flood of investment has raised concerns among grain traders and agricultural producers that speculative money is gaining an undue influence over their markets, which help set the prices of raw commodities for a host of consumer food products, according to The New York Times.

headline: Group Considers $38 Billion Bid for Equity Office
abstract: The biggest leveraged buyout in history may get even bigger. A consortium of investors is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, The New York Times reported. The bid may not happen, but if it does, it would challenge the record-setting deal that Equity Office and the Blackstone Group agreed to in November.

headline: Daimler Shareholder Calls for Possible Spin-Off
abstract: A DaimlerChrysler shareholder, DWS, has reportedly called on the carmaker’s management to consider a spin-off of the firm’s ailing Chrysler unit in the United States as it gets ready to introduce its latest restructuring plan for Chrysler.

headline: Dell Reports It Has Found ‘Misconduct’
abstract: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said Thursday that “evidence of misconduct” had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its board’s audit committee had “identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment.” The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.

headline: Citigroup Overhaul to Test Chief’s Mettle
abstract: With his career and his company’s prospects on the line, Citigroup chairman Charles O. Prince III is preparing the most sweeping restructuring of the financial giant since it was forged from a merger a decade ago.

headline: Is Wall Street Really Losing Its Edge?
abstract: The people who are warning that New York is losing its dominance as a global financial center because of overregulation make up “a chorus of Cassandras,” James Surowiecki writes in the latest issue of The New Yorker. The article’s skeptical stance echoes Jenny Anderson’s Insider column in last week’s New York Times, in which she suggested there was some “undue panic” over the flight of companies to overseas markets.

headline: Icahn on Chiefs, Morons and Leased Jets
abstract: Earlier this week, several blogs and the New York Post picked up a funny and harrowing anecdote about the billionaire financier Carl Icahn that appeared in a profile in Avenue magazine: Aboard his leased aircraft, the activist investor (or “corporate raider” as he was known in the 1980’s) had just finished instructing Apollo‘s Leon Black on the virtues of leasing jets as compared to buying them when he saw smoke coming from the engine.

headline: Unusual Options Grants May Complicate Caremark Battle
abstract: While it battles CVS over Caremark Rx, Express Scripts may have some trouble in its own backyard. The prescription benefits manager has given stock option grants to its management at unusually lucrative times, The New York Post reported Thursday. The report arrives as Express Scripts criticizes Caremark executives for planning to enrich themselves through a $24.6 billion merger with CVS. Though its $26 billion bid was rejected, Express Scripts has already begun a tender offer for Caremark shares.

headline: Kerr-McGee Is Found Liable in Lawsuit Over Oil Royalties
abstract: A federal jury in Denver agreed Tuesday with a former top auditor for the Interior Department that Kerr-McGee had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties on oil it produced in publicly owned coastal waters. The decision, reached by the jury after deliberations of about four hours, is a vindication for the auditor, Bobby L. Maxwell. He became a whistle-blower and sued Kerr-McGee as a private citizen after top officials at the Interior Department ordered him to drop his audit findings.

headline: Volvo Revs Up Construction Business
abstract: Volvo said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy the road development division of Ingersoll-Rand for $1.3 billion in cash to expand its construction equipment business, particularly in the United States. Volvo, which also makes trucks, buses and engines, expects the acquisition to save it about 600 million Swedish kronor ($85.2 million) — mainly within sales and distribution — over five years, the company said. The transaction is due to be completed in the second quarter, subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Ex-Investigator for H.P. Is Expected to Plead Guilty
abstract: A former Hewlett-Packard private investigator is expected to plead guilty Friday to federal charges that he posed as a reporter to get phone records for the company’s internal investigation of boardroom leaks. The former investigator, Bryan Wagner of Littleton, Colo., will plead guilty to identification theft and conspiracy in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., said his lawyer, Stephen Naratil.

headline: Lawyers Call for More Rights in Corporate Fraud Cases
abstract: Some lawmakers are questioning the Justice Department’s recently revised guidelines on combating corporate fraud, asking whether they do enough to protect the confidentiality of legal communications and the right to legal counsel. At a hearing Thursday, two former federal prosecutors and other prominent lawyers are expected to tell the House Judiciary subcommittee and its chairman, Representative Robert C. Scott, Democrat of Virginia, that the new guidelines, known as the McNulty memorandum, are inadequate and do not protect basic legal rights.

headline: Goldman Backs Gemini Mobile
abstract: Wireless messaging and entertainment software developer Gemini Mobile Technologies has received $20 million in new funding, intended to support continued global expansion and product development. The internationally focused company, which splits its operations among the U.S., Japan and China, added Goldman Sachs of New York to its roster of investors in the new round. Follow-on funding came from three Japanese backers: Mitsubishi-UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Bank and Tokyo Marine.

headline: Chicago Merc Counsel Joins Skadden
abstract: Jerry Salzman, the longtime outside counsel for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom on Monday, as the law firm he cofounded is closing down after 40 years. Mr. Salzman is leaving Freeman, Freeman & Salzman months after the exchange agreed to acquire CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in an $8 billion deal that could create the world’s largest futures exchange. Skadden represented the Merc in that deal.

headline: Station Casinos Agrees to $5.4 Billion Buyout
abstract: Station Casinos said on Monday it had agreed to a $5.4 billion management-led buyout after the investor group buying the company raised its offer by about 10 percent.

headline: Wachovia’s Evergreen Buys British Investment Firm
abstract: Wachovia‘s asset management unit, Evergreen Investments, agreed to buy a majority stake in European Credit Management, a privately held, fixed-income investment management firm based in London. European Credit has about $26 billion in assets under management, which would lift Evergreen’s international total to more than $280 billion.

headline: ScanSafe Raises $15 Million Second Round
abstract: ScanSafe, an Internet security company, said Tuesday that it had raised $15 million in a second round of financing led by Scale Venture Partners. Benchmark Capital, an early investor in ScanSafe, also participated in the round, ScanSafe said.

headline: In Friendly’s Fight, a Brotherly Feud
abstract: Behind the scenes of the battle for control of Friendly Ice Cream is a tale of two brothers who founded the company during the Great Depression only to become estranged after disagreements over its future.

headline: Reports of a 3i British Flip Provokes Outrage
abstract: Reports that the London private equity shop 3i Group  is in exclusive talks with Australia’s Macquarie Bank about the sale of National Car Parks, a business it acquired from crosstown buyout rival Cinven just 18 months ago, has met with heated words on the evils of private equity. News of the possible flip stoked union anger as workers at National Car Parks went on strike in north London to protest the refusal of 3i to recognize the union.

headline: Garmin Goes to the Dogs
abstract: Among the host of GPS navigational devices that Garmin just announced at CES is one specialized for hunting dogs.

headline: Up, Up and Away
abstract: A major stock market index, the Russell 3,000, is in record territory.

headline: Commerzbank Posts Rise in Profits
abstract: Commerzbank, Germany’s second-largest bank by assets, said fourth-quarter profit rose 4.1 percent on higher trading and fee income. Net income climbed to 352 million euros ($459 million) from 338 million euros a year earlier. That missed the 393 million-euro median estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News.

headline: Express Scripts Begins $24.8 Billion Offer for Caremark Shares
abstract: Express Scripts began a $24.8 billion offer for all outstanding shares of Caremark Rx on Tuesday. The move is the latest step in a high-stakes takeover battle after Caremark said last week that it preferred a lower $23.3 billion deal with the drugstore chain CVS. Express Scripts is offering Caremark shareholders $29.25 in cash and 0.426 shares of Express Scripts stock for each Caremark share.

headline: Smaller Buyout Firms, Profiting Under the Radar
abstract: A “new generation of private equity entrepreneurs” is making its mark on the industry, according to a report in BusinessWeek. Some of these entrepreneurs’ firms, like New Mountain Capital, are run by relative unknowns.
