Others are run by private-equity veterans like Silver Lake Partners, headed by Glenn Hutchins, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group.

headline: New Chateaux for London Bankers?
abstract: Property in France, the United States and Italy is topping the shopping lists of bankers in London’s City this bonus season, with many putting down large deposits to reserve their second homes without even bothering to view the house, according to a report in The Guardian. About 51 percent of City bankers plan to invest in overseas property in 2007, according to a poll by Populus for the property agency PURE International, with France topping the list with 28 percent, followed by the United States with 21 percent.

headline: A Look at the Canadians Who Seek Chrysler
abstract: Though the names most often mentioned as potential buyers of Chrysler have been private equity firms like the Blackstone Group and Cerberus Capital Management, several reports highlight a lesser-known firm with roots in the car business. That would be the Canadian auto-parts supplier Magna International.

headline: Quanta Services to Buy InfraSource
abstract: Quanta Services, a builder of energy and telecommunications networks based in Houston, said Monday that it would buy InfraSource Services for $1.26 billion to expand its services and increase its national presence. The all-stock deal calls for the exchange of 1.223 shares of Quanta’s common stock for each outstanding common share of InfraSource. That is about $30.13 a share, a 17.4 percent premium over the closing price of InfraSource stock last Friday, according to the companies.

headline: Bain Bags South African Retailer
abstract: Edgars Consolidated Stores, South Africa’s biggest retailer by market value, agreed to be bought by Bain Capital for about 25 billion rand ($3.5 billion) in what would be the country’s largest private equity transaction. The offer is worth 46 rand a share, 15 percent above Wednesday’s closing price. Edgars, which has more than 900 stores in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia and Swaziland, said that it “recognizes that although its prospects remain positive, its future performance and corresponding growth profile are not without risk.”

headline: Partnership Buys Pipeline
abstract: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the province’s oil sands. The Corridor system transports diluted bitumen, a heavy oil, from the Athabasca oil sands project near Fort McMurray to a processing plant near Edmonton, the partnership said.

headline: Everbright Bank Said to Seek Investor
abstract: China Everbright Bank, which plans to hold an initial public offering this year, has hired China International Capital and Morgan Stanley to find a foreign investor before the offering, according to Bloomberg News. Everbright Bank, which in 1996 became the first Chinese bank to sell stock to an overseas financial institution, is trying to bolster its capital to comply with government guidelines, Bloomberg said.

headline: France’s Scor Makes Unsolicited Bid for Converium
abstract: Scor, France’s largest reinsurer, offered to buy Converium Holding for 3.1 billion Swiss francs ($2.5 billion) in the latest deal in the global reinsurance sector. Converium rejected the approach, saying that it is not in the interests of shareholders. Scor’s approach follows last year’s acquisition by Swiss Re of General Electric‘s Insurance Solution unit for $7.4 billion. Axa, Europe’s second-largest insurer, in June agreed to sell its Axa Re reinsurance unit to a group of investors. Reinsurers help primary insurers like Allianz shoulder risks for clients.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Asks S.E.C. To Delay New Trading Rules
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange is a little behind schedule, it seems. Its parent, the NYSE Group, requested Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission postpone the implementation date of Regulation NMS, a series of sweeping changes designed to update United States markets for new, rapid trading technologies, from Feb. 5 to March 5.

headline: Credit Suisse’s New No-Frills Chief
abstract: />One of the things that sets Brady W. Dougan apart from his peers is his aversion to the limelight. But Mr. Dougan, who was anointed Credit Suisse Group‘s chief executive Thursday, will be the youngest chief executive of a global banking giant, a position that is by no means a private one. Mr. Dougan, whom The New York Times describes a shy, workaholic from the Midwest who ran marathons in near world-class times and acknowledges an addiction to Diet Dr Pepper, stands in contrast with many of Wall Street’s top executives, whose aggressive charm has paved their way to the top.

headline: Merrill Analyst Turns Cautious on Cowen
abstract: Shares of the Cowen Group have risen nearly 30 percent from last year’s initial public offering, but Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski is concerned that there may be little upside left. On Monday, Mr. Moszkowski cut his rating on Cowen to “neutral” from “buy,” writing that, at Friday’s close of $20.70, the investment bank’s stock had topped his $18 price target. He also said that Cowen’s merger advisory business looks weak, especially in the fourth quarter of 2006.

headline: Washington’s Hedge Fund Shuffle
abstract: For Slate’s Daniel Gross, there is no mystery behind the influx of former politicians into the world of hedge funds. “Hedge funds can make you filthy rich,” he states.

headline: I.P.O. Market Offers Deals for Those With Derring-Do
abstract: When the markets get choppy, risky investing categories like initial public offerings tend to suffer. But, says BusinessWeek, the recent market turmoil that started with the sell-off in China has not overwhelmed the I.P.O. scene, and it may create opportunities. Stock in companies like BigBand Networks, which helps cable companies deliver high-definition video, have risen as much as 30 percent above their opening prices.

headline: Perella Lures 2 Morgan Stanley Bankers, Report Says
abstract: In potentially another coup for Joe Perella, his boutique investment bank has snatched two high-level bankers from his old stomping grounds at Morgan Stanley, Reuters reported Friday. The newswire said that Perella Weinberg Partners had poached Scott Bruckner, who was co-head of the European technology group, and Arnaud Dassy, an executive director on the telecom team. Mr. Bruckner was to have transferred to New York from London to take the helm of the East Coast technology team.

headline: Ruling Ripples Through Prime Brokerage Business
abstract: Bear Stearns was ordered yesterday to pay $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for failing to properly monitor the fund’s activities, and the ruling could have much broader effects. The decision may alter the nature of the relationship between big investment banks and hedge funds, The New York Times wrote Friday.

headline: With Mills Bid Simon Property Revisits a Deal It Abandoned
abstract: Simon Property Group, the nation’s largest mall operator, had always seemed like a logical buyer for its troubled rival, the Mills Corporation. But the announcement yesterday that Simon had teamed with Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund that owns 10.9 percent of Mills’s shares, to challenge a rival suitor and make an all-cash bid for Mills of $24 a share surprised the real estate industry because of its timing.

headline: London Stock Exchange Reports Higher Profit
abstract: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, got some more ammunition yesterday when it reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a “strong performance” in fiscal 2008.

headline: Online Marketing Boom Attracts Private Equity
abstract: The Web is still mostly a hodgepodge when it comes to advertising and marketing. Interactive agencies abound, as do marketing outfits, affiliate programs and technology firms that create the platforms for serving and tracking ads. But the business is booming, and, according to an article in Adweek magazine, ripe for consolidation by private equity firms.

headline: Russian Bank Closes in on $12 Billion Offering
abstract: Sberbank, Russia’s largest savings bank, was tallying the final orders on Monday from investors seeking entry to its $12 billion share sale, a deal that could become the biggest offering in Russian corporate history. The Financial Times reported that Sberbank’s supervisory board would convene on Wednesday to decide pricing for the domestic offering of up to 3.5 million new shares. Sberbank management has so far sent conflicting signals on how it wants to price the issue, throwing the stock price into turmoil.

headline: Carlyle Said to Raise $15 Billion Buyout Fund
abstract: Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity giant, is putting together a $15 billion fund for buyouts in the United States, which would be nearly twice the size of its previous fund, Reuters reported, citing undisclosed sources.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Spirals, and Casualties Mount
abstract: Just as the technology boom of the late 1990s turned twenty-something programmers into dot-com billionaires, and leveraged buyouts a decade earlier turned Wall Street bankers into Masters of the Universe, the explosive growth in subprime lending turned mortgage bankers and brokers into multimillionaires seemingly overnight.

headline: RBC Capital Names Co-Presidents
abstract: RBC Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada, said Wednesday that it had named two co-presidents as part of its “long-term succession planning.” The co-presidents, Doug McGregor and Mark Standish, will report to Chuck Winograd, chief executive of RBC Capital Markets. Mr. McGregor, based in Toronto, had been head of global investment banking and equity markets for RBC Capital, while Mr. Standish, based in New York, had been head of global markets.

headline: Endemol Leaves Disney Cold, Report Says
abstract: A source told Reuters in no uncertain terms that Walt Disney is not interested in buying Telefonica‘s 75 percent stake in the TV producer Endemol. The cryptically worded message: “We are not interested in it,” the source said. Disney was touted on Monday as possibly being interested with Endemol co-founder John de Mol in forming an alliance to repurchase the Dutch production house.

headline: Court Rules Parmalat May Sue Citi in New Jersey
abstract: A New Jersey state court has rejected Citigroup‘s bid to dismiss a $10 billion lawsuit accusing it of helping former management at Italian food company Parmalat commit fraud. The decision, by Bergen County Superior Court Judge Jonathan Harris, dismisses Citigroup’s claim that New Jersey is the wrong venue.

headline: Ex-Gateway Officers Found Liable in Trial
abstract: Two former executives at the computer maker Gateway were found liable on civil claims that they manipulated financial results to meet Wall Street expectations in 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday. The verdicts against Gateway’s former chief financial officer, John J. Todd, and the former controller, Robert D. Manza, were announced by a federal jury in San Diego after a three-week trial, the S.E.C. said.

headline: 4th Nikko Shareholder Rejects Citi’s Bid
abstract: And then there were four. Citigroup‘s $10.8 billion takeover offer for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage firm, has been rejected by yet another shareholder, bringing the total number of those opposed to the much-ballyhooed deal to four.

headline: Management Group to Take Laureate Education Private
abstract: Laureate Education, a for-profit operator of universities, said Sunday it had agreed to be acquired for about $3.1 billion by a group led by its chairman, Douglas L. Becker. The buyout group also included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the hedge fund SAC Capital.

headline: Time Inc. Magazines Auction Lures More Bidders
abstract: As the deadline to submit second-round bids for 18 Time Inc. titles expired Monday, up to six companies have emerged as competitors, The New York Post reported. Among the likely bidders are Sweden’s Bonnier Publications; the Quadrangle Group backing a former Wenner Media executive; Boston Ventures, supporting a former Time Inc. executive vice president; Intermedia Advisors; and Active Media in conjunction with Windpoint Partners. Also in the hunt for at least some of the titles is Elevation Partners, the private-equity firm founded by Roger McNamee and the U2 frontman Bono.

headline: Blackstone Files for $4 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: It’s in.

headline: Anadarko Unloads K2 Stake
abstract: Anadarko Petroleum agreed to sell part of its stake in the K2 oil and natural gas field in the Gulf of Mexico to two undisclosed buyers for $1.2 billion. The sale, which is expected to close in the second quarter, would reduce Anadarko’s stake in the project to 41.8 percent from 65 percent, the company said.

headline: Vertrue Agrees to $800 Million Buyout
abstract: Internet marketer Vertrue, which runs the online matchmaking service LavaLife, agreed to be acquired by a trio of investment firms and its senior managers for $48.50 a share in cash, or about $800 million including debt. J.P. Morgan‘s private equity arm One Equity Partners, venture capital firm Oak Investment Partners, and Rho Ventures, a venture investor, along with managers led by Vertrue chief executive and co-founder Gary Johnson, will invest an undisclosed amount of equity in the deal, which is slated to close by Sept. 30.

headline: Beacon Capital Unloads a Bean Town Dud
abstract: Not everyone is making a bundle selling commercial real estate these days.

headline: Berlusconi’s Mediaset Eyes Endemol Bid
abstract: Mediaset, the broadcaster controlled by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, is prepping a bid for Dutch reality TV producer Endemol, the creator of the genre classic “Big Brother.” Mediaset’s chief executive, Giuliano Adreani, told journalists that the company is planning a bid with Endemol’s founder, John De Mol, who sold the company to Spain’s Telefónica and now wants to get it back.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Renault-Nissan Says No Thanks to Chrysler
abstract: DaimlerChrysler‘s potentially pending auction of the Chrysler Group may field bids from a slew of buyers. The Renault–Nissan alliance, however, will not be among them, despite its interest in taking on a North American partner. A Nissan spokeswoman said Wednesday that the two car makers are focusing on righting their own finances, a task that would be difficult if the companies were saddled with ailing Chrysler. Last year, Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of both companies, entered talks with General Motors about a potential alliance, but none was formed.

headline: Google’s High-Octane Mixer
abstract: As politicians and moguls stream into Davos, some of them arrive with a discreet black envelope in their luggage. It contains an invitation to what has consistently been one of the conference’s hottest events: the party hosted by Web search giant Google.

headline: Lawyer Who Inspired the ‘Chinn Up’ Joins Centerview
abstract: Adam Chinn, a partner at the law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, who focused on financial-services mergers and executive compensation issues, is joining Centerview Partners, a recently opened investment banking boutique, as a founding partner, Centerview said. A partner at Wachtell Lipton since 1994, Mr. Chinn has helped many top executives beef up their employment agreements, giving rise to the term “the Chinn-up.” Centerview was founded last year by Stephen Crawford, formerly co-president of Morgan Stanley, Blair Effron, formerly vice chairman at UBS, and Robert Pruzan, formerly president of Wasserstein Perella.

headline: Nestle Frosts its Ice Cream Unit With Eskimo Pie
abstract: Nestle, the maker of Haagen-Dazs ice cream, agreed to purchase the Eskimo Pie and Chipwich ice-cream brands from CoolBrands International to increase its share of the global market. Nestle paid $18.9 million for the brands through a unit in the United States, Dreyer’s Grand Ice Cream Holdings.

headline: Who Gets Credit for Heinz Results?
abstract: Nine months of solid economic growth at H.J. Heinz, with net income increasing nearly 13 percent and total sales climbing almost 10 percent, brings up question: Is it Heinz, or is it Nelson Peltz? Analysts and industry watchers told The Pittsburgh Tribune-Review the positive results at Heinz are a combination of the two.

headline: Australia’s WorleyParsons Buys Canadian Oil Sands Firm
abstract: Colt Engineering, a private Canadian company focused on the oil sands, is selling itself for 1 billion Canadian dollars ($843 million) to Australia’s WorleyParsons, saying that being part of a larger foreign company is the best choice to pursue further growth.

headline: Hedge Fund Officer Is Accused of Fraud
abstract: The former head of an Idaho hedge fund, Wood River Capital Management, has been indicted on charges that he engaged in securities fraud that cost investors $88 million, prosecutors said Thursday. The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan said John H. Whittier, Wood River’s majority shareholder and principal executive, was charged with securities fraud and failure to disclose a beneficial interest in a publicly traded security. Mr. Whittier is expected to be arraigned next week.

headline: Icahn Raises Stake in Motorola
abstract: Shortly after Motorola disappointed shareholders and analysts by cutting its revenue forecasts and failing to make a bid for rival Palm, its biggest gadfly has increased his stake in the company. Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, increased his stake in the beleaguered cellphone maker to 2.7 percent from 2.48 percent, according to a regulatory filing made on Friday.

headline: Congress Tunes Into Satellite Radio Merger
abstract: In a sign of just how closely Washington plans to examine the proposed merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio, the House Judiciary Committee announced Thursday that it had formed a special group — the Antitrust Task Force — to consider the deal, which would create a single provider of satellite radio in the United States (albeit one that must still contend with old-fashioned radio as well as portable digital-music devices). Still, some analysts say they believe the markets are being too pessimistic about the deal’s chances of winning regulatory approval.

headline: Jumbo Bonuses: Dial Your Envy Down a Notch
abstract: It’s time to put the record Wall Street bonuses you’ve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million. But these people were the exception, writes The New York Times’ Phyllis Korkki, pointing to data that show the average 2006 bonus in the New York securities industry was about $137,000, an increase of 15 percent from the year before.

headline: Man Group Shares Slide As Key Fund Falters
abstract: Shares of the Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge-fund manager, bucked the trend Wednesday in a higher London market, retreating after the company disclosed poor performance from its leading fund. Man Group said the net asset value of its key AHL fund fell 8 percent last week. Man’s shares closed down 0.9 percent.

headline: Toronto-Dominion Posts Profit Increase
abstract: Toronto-Dominion Bank kicked off bank earnings season Thursday, beating expectations on stronger results at its retail division and U.S. discount brokerage. The bank’s profit before one-time gains jumped 20.8 percent to C$1 billion ($861 million) or C$1.38 a share from a year-earlier C$835 million or C$1.15 a share.

headline: Housing Slide Continues
abstract: The housing slide could go much farther.

headline: Cirrus Logic Chief Resigns Over Options
abstract: David D. French, chief executive of the chip maker Cirrus Logic, has resigned over his involvement in the company’s past stock option grant practices, the company said on Wednesday. Michael L. Hackworth, the former chief executive and current chairman, will be acting chief of the company he helped found, Cirrus said in announcing the results of an internal inquiry.

headline: Is Big Brother Ruckus Bad for Business?
abstract: It seems that the brouhaha surrounding the treatment of a Bollywood actress on the British version of “Big Brother” is not doing British business any favors. Richard Lambert, director-general of an employers’ organization, the CBI, has waded into the row over alleged racism on Channel 4’s “Celebrity Big Brother” by describing the program as “complete crap” and “unhelpful” to British firms trying to establish themselves in India. The Guardian reported.

headline: Private Equity Saves Jobs, Permira Chief Says
abstract: Under fire from government officials and labor unions alike, Permira Advisers‘ chief executive insists that private equity does not destroy jobs. Permira, one of Britain’s largest buyout firms, has been criticized for its stewardship of Birds Eye and the Automobile Association; each company has shed more than a quarter of its total workers since being acquired by the firm.

headline: British Homebuilder Buys Developer in Record Deal
abstract: Barratt Developments, the largest homebuilder in Britain, agreed to buy Wilson Bowden for 2.2 billion pounds ($4.32 billion) in what Bloomberg News said is the biggest-ever takeover of a British housing developer. Barratt, based in Tyne, said it would will pay 2,257 pence in cash and stock for each Wilson share. That’s 23 percent higher than Wilson’s close on Nov. 24, the last day of trading before the company put itself up for sale.

headline: What Will H-P Buy Next?
abstract: Hewlett-Packard has been acquiring its way into the big leagues of enterprise software. The 451 Group considers which companies might be next on H-P’s shopping list as it tries to fill gaps in its information-management offerings. Among the possible targets are Vignette, which the report describes as being “in transition,” and Interwoven, which is conducting a voluntary review of its stock option grants.

headline: Chevron Said to Be Interested in Buying Assets of Yukos of Russia
abstract: Chevron intends to bid for assets of Yukos, the bankrupt oil producer, Russian officials said Friday. If Chevron succeeds, such an acquisition could help close the final chapter on the downfall of Russia’s largest oil company.

headline: Australia’s Coles Reconsiders the Buyout Option
abstract: Last fall, Coles Myer spurned offers to take the Australian supermarket chain private. Now, its parent company has changed its mind. Coles Group put itself up for sale Friday, citing several interested buyers — presumably who would offer more than the A$18.2 billion ($14.3 billion) bid it previously rejected. Shares in the company shot up 10 percent in Friday trading.

headline: Owner of Lavalife Said to Seek Buyer
abstract: Vertrue, which runs the matchmaking Web site Lavalife, has hired an investment bank, Jefferies Broadview, to help sell the company, The New York Post reported, citing sources close to the deal it did not identify.

headline: Citi Faces Obstacles in Japanese Bid
abstract: Some early obstacles are emerging to Citigroup‘s big Asia bid, which it announced Wednesday. The bank’s $10.8 billion offer for Japanese brokerage Nikko Cordial was being touted as a much-needed coup for Citigroup’s chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, who has been under pressure from shareholders to improve firm’s performance.

headline: Qantas Buyout Clears Significant Hurdle
abstract: The consortium behind the 11.2 billion Australian dollars ($8.7 billion) buyout proposal for Qantas Airwaysmoved closer to closing the deal Tuesday when the Australian government said it would not oppose the transaction. The government was under immense pressure from unions, politicians and members of the public to veto the takeover under its foreign investment laws, as it had done in 2001 when Royal Dutch Shell bid 10 billion Australian dollars for Woodside Petroleum.

headline: What’s Next for Motorola?
abstract: Motorola, the subject of rampant deal rumors on Wall Street this week, on Wednesday sliced about $1 billion off of its revenue projections for the quarter and announced a management shake-up. The beleaguered cellphone giant also said it was expanding a stock-buyback program, addressing a demand of the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who has become a major Motorola shareholder.

headline: Kodak to Sell Health Group to Onex
abstract: Eastman Kodak, the photography company, said Wednesday it plans to sell its medical imaging business to a subsidiary of a Canadian conglomerate, Onex, for up to $2.55 billion. Kodak said the move would help it focus on its consumer and professional imaging business.

headline: Was YouTube Worth It?
abstract: A tidbit in a regulatory filing late last week revealed that Google paid a whopping 100 times revenues for the video-sharing Web site YouTube. Perhaps more remarkable than the sticker shock, however, was the rhetoric employed by Google’s chief executive, Eric Schmidt, to justify the deal. “If you can build a sustainable eyeball business, you can always find clever ways to monetize it,” Mr. Schmidt told a group of investors Tuesday.

headline: Housing Hopes
abstract: A sign of true distress in the housing market?

headline: S.E.C. Examines Improper Stock Tipping at Major Banks
abstract: Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Deutsche Bank are among major Wall Street banks that were sent letters last month by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of a broad examination into whether bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients, The New York Times reported.

headline: Carlyle Raises $3.1 Billion for European Fund
abstract: Another day, another near-record private equity fund. This time, it is Washington’s Carlyle Group, which said Tuesday that it has raised 2.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) for its latest European buyout pool. If it maintains that pace — the private equity firm said in a regulatory filing earlier this month that it aims to raise $5.9 billion for Carlyle European Partners III — it could beat Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ 4.5 billion euro fund from last year. As Bloomberg News reported, European buyouts rose to a record $200 billion last year, versus $120 billion in 2005.

headline: Should Companies Sell While the Selling Is Good?
abstract: There are increasing complaints among shareholders that companies are selling out to private equity at bargain prices — leaving the buyout shops to enjoy the upside when the business gets sold or taken public again. But Robert Kindler, Morgan Stanley‘s vice chairman of investment banking, says these critics are generally off-base. In his opening speech Thursday to deal lawyers at Tulane Law School’s Corporate Law Institute, Mr. Kindler suggested that, in this torrid buyout market, most companies are getting top dollar when they agree to go private.

headline: US Airways Stands Firm As Deadline Looms for Delta Bid
abstract: As the clock ran down on US Airways‘ $10 billion bid for bankrupt Delta Air Lines, US Airways’ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, said in a conference call Tuesday that the offer, a mix of cash and stock, was firm, and that he had no intention of extending the Thursday deadline for the the official committee of Delta’s creditors to respond. Also on Tuesday, US Airways reported a $12 million profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, and Delta said it had secured $2.5 billion in financing to fund its emergence as a standalone airline.

headline: Commentary: In Takeovers, Truth Can Be the First Casualty
abstract: When hostile takeover bids rear their heads, some chief executives declare fiercely that they’re not interested. From Gerald Grinstein of Delta Air Lines to Edwin Crawford of Caremark Rx, these chief executives insist that their suitors take a hike. But the problem, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his Sunday DealBook column, is that they may not be telling the truth — and that they’re simply looking to up the ante. Read on to find out more.

headline: At H-P, More Spying Allegations Fly
abstract: Hewlett-Packard is once again at the center of a cloak-and-dagger brouhaha. A former Hewlett executive accused by the company of stealing trade secrets is now saying that he was instructed by the company’s management to spy on a rival, Dell, CNet News.com reported. Karl Kamb, Hewlett’s former vice president of business development and strategy, was named as a defendant in a federal lawsuit filed by the computer maker in 2005 alleging that he used trade secrets to launch a rival flat-screen TV company of his own while still on the payroll.

headline: Dolan Family Raises Offer for Cablevision
abstract: Cablevision Systems‘s controlling family, the Dolans, said Friday that they had raised their offer to buy out the public shareholders of their cable television empire to $30 per share in cash, up from the $27-per-share cash offer they presented in October. In a press release, the family said their latest proposal valued Cablevision’s equity at $8.9 billion and implied a total entreprise value of $20.1 billion. The Dolans said the bid was their “best and final offer” and would expire on Jan. 17.

headline: Limelight Networks Plans $200 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Limelight Networks, a digital-content delivery provider backed by Goldman Sachs‘s private equity arm, filed to raise as much as $201 million in an initial public offering of stock. In July, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners led a $130 million funding round for Limelight, whose network helps media companies to distribute video, music, games and downloads over the Internet.

headline: Racing Team Could Take Aston Martin This Week, Report Says
abstract: Ford Motor could announce the sale of its Aston Martin luxury performance cars unit for more than 450 million pounds ($865 million) as early as this week, Reuters reported citing an unidentified source who acknowledged that the timing of a deal may slip. According to Reuters, the Prodrive Formula One team, together with the Egyptian investment bank Naeem, is in the pole position to win Aston Martin, but others like the British buyout shop Doughty Hanson are close behind.

headline: Pillsbury Winthrop Seeks to Recover Back Pay from Ex-Partners
abstract: Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, a global law firm based in New York, has asked at least eight former partners to return a portion or all of last year’s earnings within 30 days, The Recorder reports. Most say they have no intention of paying back anything, even if it means going to court.

headline: Q & A: Modern Love
abstract: My name is Daniel Jones; I edit the Modern Love column in Sunday Styles. Since the column launched in October 2004, we have published nearly 120 personal essays covering a wide range of relationship experience: marriage, death, divorce, parenthood, dating. From a high school student in Seattle to a grandfather in Albany, these writers explore the complexities of love in all its forms, often through a contemporary lens.

headline: Cisco’s WebEx Deal: Sizzle, Steak or Both?
abstract: Cisco‘s acquisition strategy has been a bit of a puzzle lately. The company, best known for making routers that direct network traffic, got Silicon Valley talking earlier this month when it bought the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site. On Thursday, Cisco announced another offbeat (and much bigger) deal: the $3.2 billion purchase of WebEx, a Web-based video conferencing service.

headline: Buyout Rumors Stir Shares in British Retailer
abstract: Shares in Next, a British clothing retailer, reached an all-time high Tuesday after rumors of private equity interest in the company emerged. One market trader told The Times of London that shares in Next, which was up 78 pence at 23.06 pounds, had jumped on rumors of a leveraged buyout by the retailer’s management or an approach by private equity firms.

headline: Citigroup Shells Out $1.13 Billion for Egg
abstract: Citigroup, moving to bolster its consumer business in the United Kingdom, said Monday it would buy Egg, the online bank, from the British insurer Prudential for 575 million pounds ($1.13 billion) in cash. Prudential, Britain’s second largest insurer, has been reviewing its underperforming British operations since last summer.

headline: New Republic’s Top Editor Sells His Stake to CanWest
abstract: Martin Peretz, who has been a part owner of The New Republic for more than three decades, has given up his share of the magazine, selling his interest to CanWest Global Communications, which now assumes full control. Mr. Peretz is to remain as editor in chief. CanWest, which bought a 30 percent interest in the magazine last year, announced Tuesday that a subsidiary, CanWest Media Works International, had acquired a 100 percent interest in The New Republic. Terms were not announced.

headline: Hot Spectrum Draws Cash, and Ideals
abstract: The auction for a prized swath of spectrum that could reshape the debate over who controls access to the networks that deliver digital content to consumers is about to go into high gear. Among those maneuvering ahead of the auction for the spectrum, which could be used for voice services for cellular carriers, new frequencies for emergency responders, or a commercial high-speed broadband multimedia network, are the nation’s four largest cellular providers, rural and regional wireless carriers, cable and satellite television companies and a range of technology companies – including Google and Yahoo.

headline: Get the Glow-Eye Out
abstract: Kodak reveals that it’s developing a system to remove glow eyes from pet pictures.

headline: S.E.C. Says Firm Traded on Information Stolen From Computers
abstract: An accounting firm in Hong Kong made $2.7 million from illegal insider trades by hacking into computers to view press releases before they were published, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Monday. The S.E.C. sued the company, Blue Bottle, a Hong Kong-chartered firm that says it is based in London, and its chief executive, Matthew Charles Stokes. Blue Bottle made $2.7 million by hacking into computer systems shortly before the release of market-moving information, the S.E.C. said in a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: V.C. Firms Rumble over Web Sites
abstract: What do venture capitalists do with the time they are saving from their lack of exits? In the case of Sequoia Capital and ComVentures, they scrutinize eachother’s corporate Web sites and end up in court over them.

headline: What Warren Buffett Is Buying
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of famed value investor Warren E. Buffett, has revealed its end-of-2006 stock positions, including its $843 million stake in Minneapolis-based U.S. Bancorp. From January through September of last year, Berkshire built up its U.S. Bancorp holdings by 23.3 million shares, representing a 1.3 percent stake in the bank, the nation’s sixth-largest by assets. Because so many investors watch Mr. Buffett’s portfolio, regulators sometimes allow his firm to delay disclosures of its trades in an effort to forestall market mimicry.

headline: U.S. Steel to Acquire Lone Star for $2.1 Billion
abstract: United States Steel Corporation said it plans to buy Lone Star Technologies, a maker of welded pipe used in oil fields, in a $2.1 billion cash deal that will make it North America’s largest producer of tubular steel.

headline: German Bank Auction Piques Interest
abstract: The most eagerly anticipated auction in the German banking sector in recent years kicked off Monday with several public and private banks declaring their interest in buying Landesbank Berlin. The sale is expected to be a hotly contested affair and the outcome will be closely watched by bank executives around the world because it presents the first real opportunity for private banks to enter the previously protected savings banks sector.

headline: Parmalat Gets Green Light to Pursue Banks
abstract: Italy’s constitutional court has upheld the legitimacy of attempts by Parmalat to seek funds from banks that lent it money before the dairy company’s 2003 bankruptcy. The Dec. 28 court ruling affects several banks including Intesa Sanpaolo, Banco Popolare di Verona & Novara, Credit Suisse, Unipol Banca and Banca Popolare dell’Etruria & del Lazio.

headline: The NYSE’s Electronic Man
abstract: In a long profile of the NYSE Group‘s chief executive, John Thain, New York magazine says Mr. Thain’s modus operandi has “always been to give the coming technocracy a human face.” It can be a tricky strategy to pull off, however. The essential functions of Wall Street, like trading on the New York Stock Exchange, are increasingly being handled by machines, threatening to uproot many of the Street’s long-standing traditions, the article notes.

headline: Bristol-Myers Hires Bankers for Bidding War, Report Says
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, is beefing up its banking team ahead of possible takeover approaches from rivals, notably Sanofi-Aventis, by retaining the services of three Wall Street banks, The Financial Times reported. Bristol-Myers in the past week appointed Lehman Brothers to work alongside Citigroup and Morgan Stanley to examine its options ahead of an expected takeover approach from Sanofi, the paper said.

headline: Kraft Serves Up Cream of Wheat to B&G
abstract: Kraft Foods said Tuesday it would sell its hot cereal business, including the popular Cream of Wheat products, to a subsidiary of B&G Foods for $200 million. “Our decision to sell Cream of Wheat is part of a broader effort at Kraft to focus our portfolio,” Rick Searer, president of Kraft’s North America commercial segment, said in a statement.

headline: Why Did Bush Step Into C.E.O. Pay Debate?
abstract: Business leaders applauded nearly everything President Bush said Wednesday during his visit to Wall Street. An exception was his call for more accountability on executive pay, which was met with silence from the crowd of business leaders at Federal Hall National Memorial. The compensation of chief executives “should be based on their success at improving their companies and bringing value to their shareholders,” Mr. Bush said, adding that “America’s corporate boardrooms must step up to their responsibilities.”

headline: Daimler Minus Chrysler = Buyout Target?
abstract: As rumors swirl about who might buy Chrysler, Reuters asks a different question: Would a Chrysler-less Daimler-Benz be a candidate for a leveraged buyout? Shares in the combined company, DaimlerChrysler, are trading above where they were when the company first announced that all options were on the table for its troubled American unit. Since then, there has been speculation that hedge funds or private equity firms might try to buy the assets that remained after a Chrysler sale, including the prized Mercedes brand.

headline: Private Times: Imagining a Newspaper Buyout
abstract: For months, certain outside investors have criticized the New York Times Company over its two-tiered stock structure. If the Sulzberger family, which controls the Times, ever decides that they have had enough of such badgering, they might conceivably try to take the company private. Slate’s Daniel Gross considers such a hypothetical and concludes that the publisher is “an excellent target for a management-led buyout.”

headline: Blackstone May Play the Spoiler in Alliance Boots Bid
abstract: The past week has not been kind to Stefano Pessina, the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots of Britani. While he and a partner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, are expected to raise the 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid that his company rejected last month, rival suitors came into the picture. Then he was reportedly banned from the health and beauty store’s central office.

headline: Blodget Warns on Hedge-Fund Investing
abstract: Average investors should be wary of taking the plunge into hedge funds, the former Internet analyst Henry Blodget cautions in a Slate article adapted from his book, “The Wall Street Self-Defense Manual.”

headline: Proxy Firm’s Flip May Bury Express Scripts Bid
abstract: The diagnosis for Express Scripts‘ $26.3 billion bid for Caremark Rx is getting even grimmer. On Tuesday, a proxy advisory firm came out in favor of the proposed merger of Caremark, a drug-benefits manager, with drugstore chain CVS, reversing its previous position that shareholders should reject the deal.

headline: Time Warner Cable May Come to Market Without an I.P.O.
abstract: Shares of Time Warner Cable, the second largest cable company in the nation, could hit the market within the next few weeks, analysts said. But Time Warner may bring its cable unit to market without having to go through the costly and time-consuming process of an initial public offering.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Clear Channel Shareholder Plans to Reject Buyout Offer
abstract: In a blow for the Mays family, one of Clear Channel Communications‘ largest shareholders said Thursday that it planned on voting against a proposed $18.7 billion management buyout. Highfields Capital Management, which owns roughly 5 percent of the radio giant, said the $37.60-a-share offer was too low.

headline: As YouTube Faces Pricey Lawsuit, Some Wonder: Where’s the Business Model?
abstract: Viacom‘s $1 billion copyright-infringement lawsuit has turned fears that Google‘s purchase of YouTube would end up being a legal quagmire into a reality. Now, attention is turning to whether other predicted pitfall’s of the $1.65 billion deal — namely that the site will end up being a financial black hole — will also come true.

headline: British Housebuilders to Merge
abstract: George Wimpey and Taylor Woodrow are merging to create Britain’s largest housebuilder, a move that will lead to up to 700 job losses. The deal, announced this morning, will create a new company called Taylor Wimpey. It will have annual revenues of 6.7 billion pounds ($13.1 billion), and an estimated market capitalization of 5 billion pounds ($9.8 billion).

headline: Former Take-Two Boss Pleads Guilty to Options Backdating
abstract: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records in a stock-option-backdating scheme and agreed to help state authorities investigate the company, the Manhattan district attorney said Wednesday.

headline: The Merger Outlook and This Year’s Targets
abstract: After helping to drive a record year for mergers and buyouts, will deal makers take a breather in 2007? Don’t count on it, several market watchers are saying this week. Among these M&A bulls is talk-show host and former hedge-fund manager James Cramer, who writes in the latest issue of New York magazine that “2007 will be even bigger than 2006″ in terms of deals. He also ticks off a series of well-known companies that he thinks are logical targets.

headline: Two Nascar Angles
abstract: I think this is the first time I’ve linked to a story from the IHT opinion pages on this blog – but this one in tomorrow’s paper is a very relevant one. The question is, does this show what F1 is up against in the U.S., or is F1 looked at differently because it is NOT a homegrown, national series like Nascar? On the other hand, you might want to check out the story we have in another section of the same paper for a different Nascar angle….

headline: Ex-Morgan Consultant Pleads Guilty to Data Theft
abstract: A former information technology consultant for Morgan Stanley pleaded guilty in federal court late Wednesday to stealing data on the investment bank’s hedge fund clients, The New York Post reported. Ira Chilowitz, 44, faces a maximum of 26 years in prison and an $850,000 fine on charges of conspiracy, theft of trade secrets and other crimes. In court, Mr. Chilowitz admitted that he and an unnamed co-conspirator had set up their own business advising hedge funds on how to negotiate the fees investment banks charge.

headline: Cryptologic Buys Scandinavian Poker Brand
abstract: A Canadian gambling software firm CryptoLogic has agreed to pay up to 20 million Canadian dollars ($17 million) for the poker brand and related assets of Parbet.com, a popular Scandinavian online poker room.

headline: G.E. Finds Strength in Its Diversity
abstract: Biotechnology, security, energy services and “green” products are just some of the areas that Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electric‘s chief since 2001, has singled out as the company’s growth platforms. He has jettisoned reinsurance and advanced materials, two slow-growth businesses, and the plastics business is on its way out.

headline: Senators Criticize S.E.C. on Pequot Inquiry
abstract: Two prominent Republican senators renewed their criticism Wednesday of the way the Securities and Exchange Commission carried out its investigation into a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management. In separate speeches on the Senate floor, the senators, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, said the S.E.C. – which filed no charges against Pequot – had failed to aggressively follow up on investigative leads developed by the lawyer who led the inquiry, Gary J. Aguirre.

headline: Venezuela Disavows 1980s-Era Bonds
abstract: The plot would seem to come right out of a novel in which the reader does not know whom to believe.

headline: Surging Real Estate Values Put Giant French Retailer in Play
abstract: The New York Times takes a look at how Carrefour, the world’s second-largest retailer, was put into play. Last month, the American real estate investment firm Colony Capital and the richest man in France, Bernard Arnault, announced that they had acquired nearly 10 percent of Carrefour’s shares and hoped to translate that value into a fat capital gain.

headline: 2 Enron Traders Avoid Prison in Sentences
abstract: Two of three former Enron traders accused of driving up energy prices during California’s power crisis in 2000 and 2001 were each sentenced on Wednesday in federal court to two years of court-supervised release.

headline: Chandlers Make Competing Bid for Tribune
abstract: Tribune Company’s largest shareholder, the Chandler family, has submitted a bid to buy the company and spin off some of its broadcast and entertainment operations in an offer that values Tribune at $7.6 billion.

headline: Is Icahn Over Time Warner?
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, after a very public campaign against Time Warner last year, during which he attacked its chief executive and tried to force a break up of the company, now apparently has other fish to fry. Mr. Icahn and his Icahn Management affiliate have dumped about 44 million shares of the media company over the course of the fourth quarter, according to a Wednesday filing with the Security and Exchange Commission quarterly filing.

headline: TXU Deal May Stoke Alternative Energy
abstract: All those investors in clean energy might want to buy a ticket for Texas. The New York Times reports that the agreement by TXU bidders Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group to scrap plans for eight new coal-fired plants is likely to increase the potential shortfall in the state’s energy supply, creating opportunities for entrepreneurs of green tech and renewable energy.

headline: Ex-Enron Executive Reports to Prison
abstract: Michael J. Kopper, a former finance executive at Enron who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt, started serving a three-year prison sentence Tuesday in Big Spring, Tex. Mr. Kopper, 42, entered the prison about 11 a.m. yesterday, a United States Bureau of Prisons official said. The former executive, a top lieutenant of Enron’s chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, managed daily operations for Fastow-controlled partnerships in the fraud that ultimately destroyed the company.

headline: Pearson Shares Rise Amid Buyout Chatter
abstract: Pearson shares rose the most in 14 months amid speculation that the company, which owns Penguin Books and the Financial Times newspaper, may receive an offer from a buyout firm or be split up, Bloomberg News reported. The stock was up as much as 4.2 percent Friday. A Pearson spokeswoman did not confirm or deny the rumors.

headline: Cushman to Sell Banker’s Trust Building for $325 Million
abstract: Cushman & Wakefield has sold the former Banker’s Trust building at 14 Wall St., with its iconic pyramid top, as office space for $325 million, The New York Post reported. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that the real estate firm approached John Zamir of Capstone Equities about buying the building, which was not then for sale. Its current owners bought the building, with 1 million square feet of space, for $215 million in 2005 with the intent of making it residential. Those plans have long since stalled.

headline: Another Suitor May Bid for Alliance Boots
abstract: Guy Hands, a longtime British dealmaker, may wade into the battle for Alliance Boots, the Telegraph reported Monday citing unnamed sources. But he may have a tough time going up against a rival offer from the pharmacy chain’s deputy chairman and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: UBS Employee May Face Charges Over Tips to Hedge Funds,  Report Says
abstract: Federal authorities have uncovered a scheme in which at least one UBS employee was allegedly selling information about upcoming changes in analyst ratings on stocks to hedge fund traders, BusinessWeek reported. The report said that federal prosecutors in New York and securities regulators in Washington could file criminal and civil charges against a number of individuals as early as Tuesday.

headline: The Anthropology of Cellphones
abstract: Nokia’s cultural anthropologist studies the way people use their cellphones all over the world.

headline: Defending the Big Buyout
abstract: In a Q&A in The New York Times, William J. Holstein, editor in chief of Directorship magazine, discusses current trends in private equity buyouts with Justin B. Wender, president of Castle Harlan, a private equity firm in New York that specializes in retailing and restaurants. Among the points covered, Mr. Wender addresses the complaint that big take-private deals make money for the private equity owners and fleece the average shareholder. He rejects the notion, calling it “apples-to-oranges analysis.”

headline: Amid Pressure from Icahn, Temple-Inland Plans Breakup
abstract: Chalk up another win for Carl C. Icahn. Under pressure from the activist investor, the diversified holding company Temple-Inland announced Monday that it would spin off its real estate and financial services units and timberlands. Temple-Inland will instead focus on its packaging and building products, with proceeds from the sales to be distributed through a shareholder dividend and a debt restructuring, the company’s chief executive said in a conference call Monday morning.

headline: Kimberly-Clark May Draw Buyout Interest, Analyst Says
abstract: It would be a tall order, but consumer products giant Kimberly-Clark could be a good candidate for a leveraged buyout, according to credit-research firm GimmeCredit, MarketWatch reports. With a market capitalization of about $31.6 billion, Kimberly-Clark would rank among the largest buyout targets ever. Though it acknowledged that size could be a deterrent, GimmeCredit said Kimberly-Clark’s relatively low price-to-earnings ratio could attract buyout firms.

headline: Virgin America Refuels With $30 Million
abstract: Virgin America, the upstart airline backed by British billionaire Richard Branson, said it raised an addition $30 million in financing from Black Canyon Capital of Los Angeles and New York’s Cyrus Capital Partners.

headline: Google Buys Stake in Chinese Multimedia Site
abstract: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China’s Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Google, which dominates the Internet search market in the United States, to compete better with Baidu.com, which controlled nearly 57 percent of China’s search-engine market at the end of June, according to Analysis International, an information technology research company based in Beijing.

headline: Set the TiVo
abstract: A note about Pogue’s segment this Sunday on CBS.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
abstract: Microsoft‘s drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Microsoft is buying Medstory, a small start-up in Foster City, Calif., for an undisclosed amount. Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.

headline: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports
abstract: Amid the increasingly heated debate over executive pay, The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson takes a look at how illuminating the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires in companies’ pay filings really are. Calling the filings an exercise in exhaustion, Ms. Morgenson suggests that the additional data now required by the S.E.C. — with a view to helping shareholders better understand the details of executive compensation — has produced opaque results.

headline: Has Fraud Followed I.P.O.’s to London?
abstract: The London Stock Exchange snagged more initial public offerings than the New York Stock Exchange in 2006, putting a dent in an otherwise impressive year for the NYSE Group, which runs the New York exchange. But there may be a downside for the L.S.E. as well: British regulators are fighting a 40 percent spike in business fraud, according to the New York Post. Citing a report by BDO Stoy Hayward, problems such as stock swindles and profit-rigging have cropped up in increasing numbers, costing at least $2.7 billion.

headline: Loans to Hedge Funds Face Scrutiny
abstract: The financial regulators in the United States and several European Union countries have begun a joint investigation into whether banks’ prime brokerages are taking too many risks as they increase lending to hedge funds. Officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Britain’s Financial Services Authority, the New York Federal Reserve and several European agencies met last month to discuss whether a relaxation in credit standards could spark trouble down the road.

headline: Sun and the Kohlberg Edge
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ recent deal to invest $700 million in Sun Microsystems shows how Kohlberg, a giant private equity firm, got special access to a public company the average Joe cannot hope for, Breakingviews writes.

headline: In Europe, Private Equity Strives to Buff Its Image
abstract: European private equity firms are anteing up to burnish their image. Under attack by politicians who called them “asset strippers” and “locusts” and by trade union leaders accusing them of cutting too many jobs, private equity firms are offering to hold meetings with their fiercest critics and have contributed 5 million pounds ($9.8 million) to set up a foundation to share part of their wealth.

headline: Is It Time to Bail Out of REITs or Buy Them?
abstract: Investors in real-estate assets seem to be sending mixed signals these days. Even as Blackstone Group is paying the highest price ever for a property owner, Deutsche Bank Private Wealth Management and MFS Investment Management are selling off shares of U.S. real-estate investment trusts, Bloomberg News reports. At the same time, TheStreet.com reports that Morgan Stanley is raising $8 billion for a fund that would acquire real estate assets around the world.

headline: Sapporo Said to Consider Management Buyout
abstract: Sapporo, Japan’s third-largest brewer, may resort to a management buyout to stymie Steel Partners, a hedge fund based in the United States that is trying to take over the company, the Kyodo news agency reported Wednesday. Previous reports said that Sapporo was in talks with its rivals, Asahi Breweries or Kirin Brewery, about a possible joint venture to thwart Steel Partners, which has said it mightlaunch a tender offer to raise its stake in Sapporo to 66.6 percent from 18.6 percent.

headline: Buyout Shop Takes Mattress Firm
abstract: Mattress Firm is getting new owners. J.W. Childs Associates, a Boston-based private equity firm, and members of Mattress Firm’s senior management team are acquiring the company from majority shareholder Sun Capital Partners.

headline: Nestlé Sells Composting Unit
abstract: Nestlé, the Swiss food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to Garick for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestlé unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost.

headline: Michael Eisner Presents His ‘Prom Queen’
abstract: It is shaping up to be a busy month for Michael Eisner, the former head of Disney. Less than a week after announcing it would help take baseball-card maker Topps private, Mr. Eisner’s investment firm, Tornante, said it was launching Vuguru, an independent studio to produce and distribute original programming on the Web. Mr. Eisner has shown an interest in Web-based video with his previous investment in Veoh Networks, a video-sharing site that competes with the much more widely visited YouTube.

headline: Viacom’s Deal Strategist Expands Role
abstract: The former investment banker who has overseen Viacom‘s acquisition strategy for the past year just got a longer title for his business card. Wade Davis, the media group’s senior vice president of mergers and acquisitions since December 2005, has become senior vice president of strategy, mergers and acquisitions, Viacom said Friday.

headline: Did Jim Cramer Cross the Line?
abstract: As money-manager-cum-TV-personality James Cramer was apologizing Thursday for parts of his recent treatise on how to manipulate stock prices, his nemesis, stock-analyst-cum-writer Henry Blodget, was tapping out a column for Slate suggesting that Mr. Cramer may have destroyed his own career.

headline: Law Firms Are Urged Not to Force Retirements
abstract: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners. In a strongly worded report that is to be released Friday, the committee concluded that “mandatory retirement – requiring a partner to leave the firm upon reaching an arbitrary age – is not an acceptable practice.”

headline: Citigroup Profit Falls in 4th Quarter
abstract: Citigroup said on Friday that fourth-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, when it took a one-time gain, although the company benefited from growth in investment banking. Net income for the New York-based company fell to $5.13 billion from $6.93 billion a year earlier, when Citigroup recorded a $2.1 billion gain from selling its asset management business.

headline: Holland & Knight Hires Securities Lawyers From a Rival
abstract: A law firm, Holland & Knight said Monday that it had hired three lawyers from a smaller rival, Akerman Senterfitt, to join its securities and public companies practice.

headline: Tim Draper Backs Vibrator Maker
abstract: JimmyJane, a startup that makes high-end sex toys, has raised $1.1 million in financing from a group of investors that includes an entity controlled by Tim Draper, the veteran venture capitalist, according to Private Equity Week.

headline: Indonesian Oil Giant May Hold I.P.O. in 2008
abstract: Pertamina, Indonesia’s state oil company, said it might be ready for an initial public offering by the end of 2008 after weeding out corruption and improving accounting procedures. It would have a market value of $30 billion, making it the biggest stock on the Jakarta Stock Exchange, the company’s president, Ari Soemarno, said last week.

headline: Kravis and Roberts on the Buyout Boom
abstract: Two of the three names behind private equity behemoth Kohlberg Kravis Roberts weighed in on the state of the buyout industry in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. Henry Kravis and George Roberts told the newspaper that much has changed since the firm’s first leveraged buyout in 1979 (price: $355 million). These days, banks are eager to lend billions of dollars to help take companies private, although Mr. Roberts suggests that debt is used more judiciously than it was in the go-go 1980’s. He said:

headline: For the Super-Rich, Too Much Is Never Enough
abstract: For voyeurs of billionaires, a brief period from mid-February to mid-March serves up two of the juiciest snapshots they will get all year. In February, the Slate 60 list of the year’s biggest philanthropic gifts comes out, followed in March by the Forbes magazine list of the world’s richest people.

headline: Vulcan Pours $4.6 Billion into Deal for Florida Rock
abstract: Vulcan Materials, the nation’s biggest producer of highway construction materials, will acquire Florida Rock Industries for $4.6 billion to add concrete-making capability in the Southeast. Florida Rock shareholders will receive cash and stock valued at $68.03 a share, 45 percent higher than the closing price on Friday, Birmingham, Ala.-based Vulcan said Monday. The payment will be 70 percent in cash, it said.

headline: Citigroup to Buy ABN Amro Mortgage Unit
abstract: Citigroup agreed to buy ABN Amro Holding‘s ABN Amro Mortgage Group for an undisclosed amount to strengthen its presence in mortgage origination and servicing in the United States. Citigroup will acquire about $9 billion in net assets and the mortgage group’s $224 billion mortgage-servicing portfolio, the bank said on Monday. The mortgage group is unit of ABN Amro’s LaSalle Bank.

headline: Losses in Home Loans Prompt HSBC to Shake Up Management of Unit
abstract: A day after HSBC issued its first-ever profit warning, the bank’s chief executive started a management shake-up at the American consumer finance unit where losses from home loans to high-risk borrowers increased more than expected last year.

headline: Norwest Outsources $20 Million to Adventity
abstract: Norwest Venture Partners has invested $20 million in India-focused Adventity, which provides high-end research and analytics to the investment banking, mortgage and financial services industries. The investment closes the second round of financing for Adventity and marks the first funding received from an institutional source. Based in New York, most of Adventity’s operations are in India. With more than 2,000 employees, Adventity serves several global investment banks, management consulting firms and some of the largest hedge funds. The funding is one of several investments by Norwest in second-generation services, or business processes that are not traditionally outsourced.

headline: Encore Buys Anadarko Wyoming Properties
abstract: The oil and gas producer Encore Acquisition said on Wednesday that it would pay $400 million in cash to buy oil and natural gas properties in Wyoming from Anadarko Petroleum. The properties include the Elk Basin Unit and the Gooseberry Unit in Park County, Wyo., and Encore expects them to generate about $50 million in cash flow a year in 2007 and 2008. The transaction is expected to close in March, Encore said.

headline: Italian Bank Backs Alitalia Bid
abstract: Intesa Sanpaolo, Italy’s second-biggest bank, will back Air One owner Carlo Toto’s bid for a stake in Alitalia with “initial” financing of 105 million euros ($137 million), the lender’s chief said. “We are committed to studying together a plan for Alitalia,” Corrado Passera told Bloomberg News. “The 105 million is only an initial investment.”

headline: It’s Buyout Time, and the Interest Rates Are Easy
abstract: Henry Kravis and Stephen Schwarzman never had it so good, at least in terms of getting the lowest interest rates on loans from their bankers. Just three months after borrowing $12.8 billion to pay for the hospital operator HCA in November, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its partners negotiated a new loan with lower rates, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Daimler Said to Consider G.M. Stake
abstract: DaimlerChrysler is considering taking a minority stake in General Motors as payment for Chrysler if a deal between the two automakers takes place, the Financial Times reported.

headline: Network Appliance Shareholders File Suit Over Options Backdating
abstract: Another company is being accused of options backdating, but this time it’s the shareholders pointing the finger.

headline: Bristol May Be a Bargain, Analyst Says
abstract: Let the bottom-fishing begin. Tuesday’s stock market plunge may have rattled investors, but it also cut the prices of some companies that are widely considered to be in play. One of these, the pharmaceuticals giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, received an upgrade Thursday from analysts at UBS, who wrote that the recent pullback in the company’s shares “reinforces takeout prospects.” Speculation about a takeover of Bristol-Myers has been swirling ever since the drug maker named an interim chief executive last fall.

headline: Trading Halted in Auto Parts Maker Wooed by Icahn
abstract: The United States auto parts maker Lear, which has received a $2.31 billion buyout offer from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, was silent on the reasons behind a long trading halt in its shares Thursday.

headline: Where Have All the V.P.’s Gone?
abstract: Vice presidents are apparently getting a lot of attention on Wall Street — and we aren’t talking about Dick Cheney. Heidi Moore of Financial News reports that many investment banks are looking to hire people at the vice-president level but are finding them to be in short supply. Hedge funds (which seem to get the blame for almost anything these days) are pegged as one cause of the shortage: Ms. Moore reports that they are dangling compensation of up to $1 million to bankers just two or three years out of school.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Lies, Fallacies and Truths
