abstract: Lawrence Summers, the former U.S. Treasury Secretary and Harvard University president, delivered some harsh criticism of the way globalization has been pitched to the public. Making the intellectual case for free trade and then simply “paying off” some of the losers in globalization, Mr. Summers said, will not work for world leaders trying to sell the current round of global trade talks to a skeptical polity.

headline: Ex-Qwest Official Says Chief Was Misleading on Growth
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications who is on trial for insider trading, knowingly repeated unreliable growth forecasts in 2000 and 2001, a former company official testified Wednesday.

headline: Barclays Predicts Slower Growth at Investment Bank
abstract: Barclays, which said on Tuesday that its second-half profit rose 41 percent to a record, predicted slower growth this year in the securities unit that contributed the most to the bank’s earnings for the last two years.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Power Vacuums, C.E.O. Pay, Shrimp
abstract: Who’s in charge here? That seems to be a question that more people are asking, on a global scale, heading into this year’s conference in Davos.

headline: Tango Says Hello to Motorola’s Cash
abstract: Motorola said on Tuesday that Motorola Ventures, its venture-capital arm, made an investment in Tango Networks, a closely held maker of communications equipment. The company did not disclose the size of its investment.

headline: Credit Suisse Put $13 Million in Its Chairman’s Pocket
abstract: Credit Suisse Group said it paid its chairman, Walter Kielholz, 16 million Swiss francs ($13.2 million) last year, one-third more than a year earlier, after profit at the bank, the second-largest in Switzerland, rose to a record. Mr. Kielholz, who earned 12 million francs in 2005, received 9 million francs in cash and 7 million francs in share-based compensation, the bank said in its 2006 annual report, published Monday. Marcel Ospel, chairman of larger Swiss rival UBS AG, received 26.6 million francs.

headline: Dell Fills New Position
abstract: Dell has hired Michael R. Cannon, who has been serving as chief executive of Solectron, to fill the newly created position of president for global operations. Dell said Mr. Cannon, whose departure from Solectron was announced Wednesday, will assume his new role on Feb. 26.

headline: YouTube, Viacom and Some Unfriendly Dealmaking
abstract: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded on Friday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.

headline: Best and Worst of Show
abstract: The C.E.S. is winding down, so now it is time for the reflecting and summing up.

headline: Irish Ferry Operator Is Target of Management Buyout
abstract: Senior management at ferry operator Irish Continental Group have made a board-backed 471 million euro ($619 million) buyout offer, the company said Thursday. But with shares trading higher than the offer price, investors might be holding out for better terms, The Deal noted. The buyout proposes paying Irish Continental stockholders 18.50 euros per share, which would represent an 18.6 percent premium to the closing share price on Wednesday, the last day before an approach was announced. Irish Continental shareholders will have the option of cash or a redeemable preference share alternative.

headline: Germany’s Merck May Sell Generic Drugs Unit
abstract: Merck of Germany said Friday that it is considering the sale of its generic drugs business, which could fetch more than $5 billion, according to some estimates. Reuters reported that the German drugs and chemicals group seems eager to cut debt from its recent $13.3 billion acquisition of Serono, which it is financing largely through loans.

headline: Judge Won’t Block Nardelli’s Pay
abstract: A Georgia state judge on Monday refused to block the severance pay of Home Depot‘s former chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, but gave plaintiffs time to gather more information in the case. “On the injunction, I’m going to deny it with the proviso that I may consider it at a later date,” Judge Craig Schwall of Fulton County Superior Court said at a hearing. He said it would give lawyers for shareholders who sought to block the exit pay 60 days to depose company directors and compile more information.

headline: Cerberus Said to Offer Job to Home Depot Ex-Chief
abstract: Home Depot‘s recently ousted chief executive, Robert Nardelli, has received a job offer from Cerberus Capital Management, CNBC reported, citing undisclosed sources. But the home-improvement retailer may try to prevent him from joining Cerberus, a private equity firm whose investments include tje General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the parent of Air Canada, by invoking his noncompete contract, CNBC said.

headline: Moelis Is Leaving UBS: The Memo
abstract: It’s official: Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS‘ investment bank, is leaving. DealBook obtained a copy of an internal memo by Huw Jenkins, the chairman and chief executive of UBS’ investment bank, and Peter A. Wuffli, the president of the firm’s Group Executive Board, announcing the veteran investment banker’s departure.

headline: Bucking Biotech Trend, Sitris Goes for I.P.O.
abstract: Sirtris Pharmaceuticals, whose research into the red-wine extract reservatrol brought the company to rock-star status, said Thursday it hopes to raise up to $60 million in an initial public offering. By going public at so early a stage (the company was founded in 2004), Sirtris is bucking a recent trend in biotech companies, the Boston Globe said. Biotech companies now prefer remaining private or going public through alternate routes like reverse mergers, as I.P.O.’s have proven less lucrative.

headline: Herbalife to Consider Take-Private Offer
abstract: Shares of Herbalife International of America rose 21 percent on Monday after J.H. Whitney & Company offered to take the nutritional supplement company private for $38 a share, or $2.7 billion. J.H. Whitney took Herbalife private in 2002 and took it public again two years later at a big profit, TheDeal.com reports.

headline: Boston Private Acquires Bank Holding Company in Washington
abstract: A bank holding company, Boston Private Financial Holdings, said on Monday it had agreed to acquire Charter Financial for about $70.8 million in cash and stock to expand in the Pacific Northwest.

headline: The Downside of Club Deals
abstract: Private equity funds may find that being part of a buyout consortium, which has become increasingly popular in recent years, can be problematic, especially when the time comes to negotiate an exit, Financial News reports.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Pinnacle Foods for $2.16 Billion
abstract: The Blackstone Group will acquire the Pinnacle Foods Group, whose brands include Duncan Hines baking mix, Mrs. Buttersworth’s maple syrup and Swanson frozen dinners, for $2.16 billion in cash, the two companies announced Monday. Pinnacle’s current owners include the private equity arm of J.P. Morgan Chase and the buyout firm J.W. Childs Associates.

headline: Tenaris to Buy Maker of Oil-Drilling Gear
abstract: Making its second large deal in the United States in a year, Luxembourg-based Tenaris said Monday it agreed to buy Hydril, which supplies connections and pressure control products for oil and gas drilling, for about $2.2 billion. Tenaris, a pipe manufacturer that has recently been the subject of takeover speculation, said it would pay $97 per share for Hydril, of Houston. In June 2006, Tenaris said it would buy Maverick Tube of Missouri for $2.8 billion.

headline: Everything Is Networking
abstract: Do you want to be able to send pictures, music and movies around the house, from one PC, TV or stereo to another?

headline: Red Bull Snorts to the Front
abstract: Red Bull must have read my blog entry yesterday, right? (Or could it be because Dietrich Mateschitz, the head of the Red Bull energy drink company, was at the track?) In any case, today’s testing times from Barcelona only confirm the lack of any one team in dominating form. There is a report at Autosport quoting Fernando Alonso himself as saying the same. Red Bull said in a statement that more than 21,000 people attended the testing at the circuit over the last three days – imagine how well the race will be attended in May.

headline: Canadian Regulators to Force Hedge Funds to Register
abstract: As lawmakers in the United States and Europe mull ways to bring greater transparency to the largely unregulated hedge fund industry, Canada is moving ahead with its own plans to force hedge fund managers to register with regulators and pass tests to prove their proficiency. Under the plan, hedge fund managers and sales staff also would have to clear a background check, the Canadian Securities Administrators said at a Toronto news conference Tuesday.

headline: BP’s Chief to Join Apax Partners
abstract: John Browne, chief executive of BP, will become chairman of the advisory board of the private equity firm Apax Partners when he leaves the oil company in July. Mr. Browne told BP executives on Friday of his plans, which would make him one of the biggest names in a new trend of globalism sweeping the private equity industry. His years presiding over an international company are likely to help Apax’s expansion plans.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis and Sun: Just Friends
abstract: Sometimes an investment is just an investment.

headline: Kazaa’s Creators Do Latest Venture by the Book
abstract: Executives at Google‘s YouTube might want to take a page out of the playbook of Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis. This time, the duo behind the file-sharing service Kazaa and the Internet telephone service Skype are dotting their i’s and crossing their t’s when it comes to their latest venture, the web video start-up Joost. Revenue-sharing agreements have been signed. Licenses have been granted.

headline: LA Landlord Raises $400 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Meruelo Maddux Properties, the largest landlord in downtown Los Angeles, raised $400 million Wednesday in an initial public stock offering intended to capitalize on investors’ widespread demand for commercial real estate. Meruelo Maddux sold 40 million shares at $10 each, well below the $12 to $14 a share the company was seeking. The stock was to begin trading Thursday on Nasdaq under the symbol MMPI.

headline: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett
abstract: While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, don’t expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshire’s chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His company’s stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. But in a regulatory filing Thursday, the company said that “neither the profitability of Berkshire Hathaway nor the market value of its stock are to be considered in the compensation of any executive officer.”

headline: Time Inc. to Sell Magazines to Swedish Publisher
abstract: Media conglomerate Time Warner will sell 18 magazines to the Swedish publishing company Bonnier Group, Bonnier said in a press release Thursday. The magazines to be sold include Field & Stream, Outdoor Life and Yachting.

headline: LinkedIn, Social Network for Suits, Gets Funding
abstract: Venture capitalists have infused $12.8 million into LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts. The funding comes as last year’s flood of investments in social-networking startups — it seems all of Silicon Valley hopes to back the next YouTube or MySpace — has many in the industry wondering when the shakeout will begin.

headline: Eisner and Wenner Team up for Celebrity TV
abstract: Michael Eisner and Jann Wenner, who once joined forces to save a celebrity magazine, are about to reunite in the world of Internet video. Wenner Media and Veoh Networks announced a partnership Monday between Usmagazine.com, the Web site for Wenner’s Us Weekly, and Veoh.com, a video-sharing Web site and a competitor of YouTube.com, to create a celebrity entertainment channel on Veoh. Mr. Wenner leads the privately owned Wenner Media, while Mr. Eisner, the former chief executive of Walt Disney, is a major investor in Veoh and brokered the deal.

headline: The Buyout Flip: It Works For Mansions, Too
abstract: Buy, fix and sell at a big profit: That’s the private equity mantra. So it is quite fitting that J. Christopher Flowers, the billionaire former Goldman Sachs partner who now private equity fund J.C. Flowers & Company, is aiming for a 35 percent return in just three months on his newly acquired mansion on New York’s Upper East Side.

headline: Homophoner
abstract: Ewe plug inn any text yew wont, and it presence yew withe an alternative version–done awl inn homophones, of coarse.

headline: Author, Facing Court Date, Must Limit His Book Tour
abstract: A court date is not the only thing marked on the spring calendar of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International. At the same time that he is scheduled to be in court facing charges of criminal fraud and money laundering in Chicago, Mr. Black will also be promoting his new biography of Richard M. Nixon, “The Invincible Quest: The Life of Richard Milhous Nixon,” to be published in May.

headline: HDTV Heavy
abstract: You know that HDTV has arrived when even CNN and The Weather Channel are converting to the high-resolution format.

headline: TXU Deal Provides Conference Buzz
abstract: Will anyone dare to mount a rival bid for TXU? That was the question being whispered yesterday in Frankfurt where many of the world’s private equity chiefs were gathered for Super Return, one of the industry’s best-attended gatherings.

headline: Layoffs Hit the N.Y.S.E. as Specialists Are Squeezed Out
abstract: Wall Street executives and office types may be enjoying record bonuses right now, but those who work the trading floor have increasingly little to celebrate. The New York Post reported Friday that Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs have laid off even more floor workers at the New York Stock Exchange, as the market increasingly moves to electronic trading via its so-called hybrid-trading system. Lehman laid off six and Goldman nine on Thursday, the paper said, adding that both laid off an unknown number of marketers who sell floor-trading screens and execution services.

headline: Bertelsmann Said to Consider Thomson Learning Bid
abstract: Moving quickly, Bertelsmann, the media group, is considering a bid for Thomson Learning, a textbook publisher, just one day after announcing that it had formed an unusual partnership with two several private equity funds to target media companies, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Chicago Merc’s Profit Falls Short of Expectations
abstract: Shares of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell after the company said fourth-quarter profit was below some analysts’ estimates because of higher-than-anticipated costs. Net income rose 35 percent to $102.6 million, or $2.91 a share, from $76.3 million, or $2.18 a share a year earlier. Higher operating expenses and equity losses in unconsolidated subsidiaries cut 11 cents a share from earnings, the exchange said.

headline: Sanofi Executives Said to Clash on Bristol-Myers Bid
abstract: A deal between Sanofi-Aventis, France’s largest drug company, and Bristol-Myers Squibb of the United States could still be in the offing. The Times of London reports that if a battle of egos between Sanofi’s chairman and its younger chief executive is resolved, the French company may dust off its $54 billion merger plans with Bristol-Myers.

headline: Banks Seek to Stop Enron Class-Action Suit
abstract: Two investment banks, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse, asked a federal appeals court on Monday to end a class-action lawsuit by Enron investors seeking $40 billion that they lost when the energy trader collapsed in 2001. The banks argued that a Houston judge was wrong to allow Enron investors to sue as a group and contended that they could not be sued because they did not participate directly in the accounting fraud that led to Enron’s bankruptcy. The investors argued the court could address only whether the plaintiffs could sue as a group. Trial is set for April in Houston.

headline: L.S.E. Rival Said to Lure More Investment Banks
abstract: Leading investment banks are considering joining Project Turquoise, the trading platform being created by seven financial firms to rival the London Stock Exchange. The banks developing the platform have received tentative requests — believed to be from ABN Amro and HSBC — to join forces, The Guardian reported.

headline: For a Senator, Hedge Funds Are Close to Home
abstract: Joseph Biden has more than a passing familiarity with hedge funds. As a Democratic senator and a longtime member of that body’s judiciary committee, the Delaware native participated in hearings last year on issues ranging from regulation to naked short-selling.

headline: First Offering of a Hedge Fund Is Bid Up 67% on Opening Day
abstract: Investors stormed the Fortress Investment Group Friday, driving its shares up 67.6 percent in the first American market offering of a hedge fund manager. The offering was eagerly anticipated because it gives a much bigger pool of investors the opportunity to share in the returns of hedge funds and private equity. Those alternative private investments are limited to the very wealthy and to large institutional investors like pension funds and university endowments.

headline: Office Real-Estate Market Feels Wall Street Effect
abstract: Flush with record-breaking bonuses, investment bankers and hedge funders are said to be driving up demand for all kinds of luxury goods, including expensive cars and multimillion-dollar apartments. (Whether or not that is true is another story.) Now, Bloomberg News suggests that Wall Street’s very good year could be raising prices in another area: office space rents. The cost of renting commercial space in Manhattan has jumped by as much as 35 percent, according to reports by two commercial brokers, which Bloomberg traces in part to the expanding financial-services sector.

headline: For Citi, a Shorter Name and a Sunnier Logo
abstract: Citigroup is folding up its umbrella and giving “group” the boot. The financial-services giant said Tuesday that it was rebranding itself under the name “Citi” and would sell the trademark for its signature red umbrella, which it acquired through its landmark merger with the insurance company Travelers Group. The announcement confirmed last month’s report by Eric Dash of The New York Times, who said the rebranding is part of an “ambitious campaign by [Citigroup’s] chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, to better integrate the bank’s sprawling parts after years of acquisitions.”

headline: LinkedIn Hires New Chief Executive
abstract: LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts, announced Monday that it had hired a new chief executive to succeed Reid Hoffman, one of Silicon Valley’s most active angel investors. While Mr. Hoffman will remain the start-up’s chairman, the move to hire Dan Nye, the former executive vice president of publicly traded Advent Software, could fuel speculation about a potential initial public offering, possibly as early as this year.

headline: Analyst Greenfield Thinks, and Acts, Like an Activist Investor
abstract: Nearly five years after Wall Street’s sweeping settlement with regulators over its conflicted research business, “the analytical path of least resistance still reigns,” writes BusinessWeek’s Roben Farzad. That sounds a little like the dilemma faced by the Washington press corps, often accused with avoiding tough questions to keep lines of communication open. But Richard S. Greenfield of Pali Research may be the Helen Thomas of Wall Street analysts. He “stands out in the sea of noncommittal analysis by making pointed demands, the sort you hear from an agitating hedge fund manager, Mr. Farzad writes.

headline: Sirius Chief Talks of Ways to Get XM Deal Approved
abstract: Facing skeptical lawmakers, Mel Karmazin, the architect of a proposed merger of the nation’s two satellite radio companies, announced at a hearing in Congress on Wednesday that the companies would agree to government-imposed price controls and other unspecified measures to gain regulatory approval for the deal.

headline: Perella’s New Hire on Leaving Ivy Behind
abstract: Asked about his move from being manager of the University of Texas’s endowment fund to an asset-management job at investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners, Robert Boldt told Dan Primack of PEHub that yes, money was a factor in his switch to the private sector — but not the main factor. He also said the University of Texas gig paid pretty well, relatively speaking. “But we all know that anybody who’s good can make a lot more money in the private sector,” he said, “except maybe if you’re at Harvard.”

headline: Goldman’s Alliance Stake May End in an I.P.O.
abstract: The combined television assets of CanWest Global Communications and Alliance Atlantis Communications could be spun off in a multibillion-dollar public offering four years from now under one of several scenarios set out in CanWest’s $2 billion deal with its financial partner, Goldman Sachs, to buy the business, The Globe and Mail reported. The specifics of how the private equity arm of the New York investment banker will cash out on this week’s blockbuster takeover of Alliance are not yet public, but the pact with CanWest includes a limited number of outcomes, including an I.P.O.

headline: A Bank Merger for the Record Books
abstract: Sanford I. Weill’s reign as the banking industry’s top deal-maker may be coming to an end. If Barclays and ABN Amro succeed in their merger talks — they announced further progress Tuesday, including agreements on location and management structure — the deal would likely carry a price of more than $80 billion, which would surpass the value of Travelers’ landmark merger with Citicorp in 1998. That transaction is widely seen as the defining moment of Mr. Weill’s career and, up until now, no bank deal has topped its $72.6 billion price tag.

headline: Brightcove Uploads $59.5 Million in Funding
abstract: An Internet video company, Brightcove, said Wednesday that it had received $59.5 million in funds from dozens of investors, including The New York Times Company. The company, one of dozens of video-sharing start-ups trying to take on Google’s YouTube also took in funding from AllianceBernstein, Brookside Capital, and Maverick Capital.

headline: Is York Advising on Chrysler Bid?
abstract: Jerome B. York, former chief financial officer at Chrysler and Kirk Kerkorian’s right-hand man, may be advising possible bidders on a Chrysler buyout, David Welch wrote in BusinessWeek’s Auto Beat blog.

headline: 2 + 20, and Other Hedge Fund Math
abstract: Many people would jump at the chance to invest in hedge funds, which have mainly been available to only the very wealthy. But a new study finds that the funds’ high fees make it unlikely that investors will improve their long-term performance by putting money into hedge funds, Mark Hulbert writes in The New York Times.

headline: European Investors Can Join Vivendi Suit, U.S. Court Rules
abstract: A federal judge in New York has ruled that French, British, and Dutch citizens who bought Vivendi shares before the French media and telecom group neared bankruptcy in 2002 are allowed to join a U.S. class action against the company.

headline: Merger Monday May Boost Banks’ League Rankings
abstract: More than $30 billion in just four deals announced Monday may represent a big payday for investment-banking advisers, potentially shaking up the industry’s league tables as the industry enters the home stretch, MarketWatch notes. The Web site estimated that the total fees could ring in between $30 million and $100 million. Check out the breakdown after the jump.

headline: Amaranth Returns Chunk of Capital to Investors, Report Says
abstract: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last year after losing more than $6 billion in energy markets, has returned more than half of its remaining capital, MarketWatch reports, citing a letter the firm sent to investors earlier this month. Almost 55 percent to 60 percent of the firm’s capital as of Sept. 30 was returned during the fourth quarter through investor redemptions and withdrawals, Amaranth’s founder, Nick Maounis, wrote in the letter obtained by MarketWatch. Apparently favorable market conditions allowed Amaranth to sell a swath of its remaining positions without incurring large losses.

headline: Hedge Funds Share in Epic’s Bloody Spoils
abstract: The most famous surviving words from the ancient Greek Battle of Thermopylae have been “molon labe,” the defiant taunt by 300 Spartans to their numerically superior Persian adversaries. Translated, it means roughly “Come and take them,” referring to their weapons. This past weekend, it could also have referred to seats at movie theaters, as viewers swarmed cinemas to help Warner Brothers’ “300” shatter box-office records.

headline: Ex-Chief of Aspen Technology Accused of Inflating Revenue
abstract: The former chief executive of the software company Aspen Technology surrendered Monday to face charges that he inflated the company’s software revenues as he competed to become its chief executive. The executive, David L. McQuillin, 48, of Sudbury, Mass., was accused in Federal District Court in Manhattan of plotting to exaggerate the company’s software revenue from January 2001 to September 2002. In court filings, prosecutors accused Mr. McQuillin of trying to inflate the revenue while he was competing against the company’s other chief operating officer to become chief executive. He became chief executive in October 2002.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: How Gentlemen Disagree
abstract: A few weeks ago, I singled out an especially poorly written, hostile e-mail from a 15-year-old named Josh to support my theory that in the Internet age, civility is an endangered species.

headline: New York Times Family Pulls Funds From Morgan Stanley
abstract: The family that controls the The New York Times Company is withdrawing most of its assets from the custody of Morgan Stanley. The decision by the Sulzberger family, which a spokeswoman for the Times Company confirmed, comes as the Times Company is fighting a proposal by a Morgan Stanley fund manager that would allow shareholders to vote on whether to end the company’s two-tier stock structure and make it more vulnerable to a takeover.

headline: Platinum Looks Set to Win Delphi Unit
abstract: Another private equity firm has joined the auto-parts fray. Platinum Equity became the lead bidder Wednesday for Delphi‘s steering and hallshaft business, which has sales of $3.4 billion. Delphi, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, did not disclose terms of the deal, saying only that they would remain confidential until an asset purchase agreement is filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan.

headline: Wall Street’s Not-So-Green Deal
abstract: As a big battle over global warming is unfolding in Texas, Fortune takes a look at how green Wall Street’s investment banks really are. At the heart of the controversy is a Dallas-based energy company that wants to build 11 coal-fired plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air. In an effort to stop the plants, environmentalists, along with a coalition of institutional investors, have turned their attention to Merrill Lynch, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, the three lead arrangers of TXU‘s financing.

headline: Caremark Delays Vote on CVS Deal
abstract: Caremark Rx, responding to a court ruling on Friday that it must provide more information on its proposed merger with CVS, delayed a shareholder vote by a week and assured shareholders Saturday they had the right to seek a court’s intervention if they are concerned about CVS’s offer for the pharmacy benefits manager. Caremark also sent notice that $35 million in payments to its investment bankers are contingent on their favorable recommendations about the merger with CVS, the nation’s largest retail pharmacy chain.

headline: Are Some Stock Analysts Rewriting History?
abstract: We thought it was dead, but the controversy over a widely used database of Wall Street research has popped up again. The debate began last fall when a group of researchers questioned the integrity of Thomson Financial‘s I/B/E/S service, a clearinghouse of analysts’ stock picks. The researchers appeared to backtrack after Thomson disputed their methodology, but last month they published the paper and are standing by its conclusions.

headline: Imperium Raises $113 Million From VCs for Biofuel
abstract: A biofuel developer, Imperium Renewables, raised $113 million in new equity to build four biodiesel processing facilities in a deal that highlights a maturing financing market for alternative fuel development, The Deal reported. The new money brings in a slew of private equity and institutional investors to round out what will be the largest single investment round for a biodiesel fuel developer.

headline: R.I.M. Restates Profits by $250 Million after Options Inquiry
abstract: Research In Motion, the maker of the ubiquitous BlackBerry phones, will restate earnings by about $250 million and said its chairman will resign that position after a review of backdated stock options. While the company, based in Waterloo, Ontario, said that it did not find intentional misconduct by its executives, it will carry out a management shuffle that will include James Balsillie giving up his chairman post. He will remain co-chief executive.

headline: India’s Banks Are Seen as Antiquated and Unproductive
abstract: India’s drive to become a global economic powerhouse faces a huge roadblock in its inefficient, largely state-controlled financial system, The New York Times reports. Two-thirds of India’s banking business is conducted through less than 5 percent of its branches, and its growing corporate sector has headed overseas for financial advice and loans.

headline: Takeover Talk Lifts ABN Shares to Record High
abstract: Reports that the British bank Barclays might bid for ABN Amro, the Dutch financial group, sent ABM Amro’s shares surging to a record Monday. The stock gained as much as 10 percent, despite skepticism from some analysts who questioned whether such a merger would actually happen. With the increase, ABN’s market capitalization swelled to about $76 billion.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Sarbanes-Oxley Problem
abstract: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act might be meant to guard against massive white-collar scandals, but the resignation of a high-profile tech veteran suggests the law may also be restricting efficiency atop Silicon Valley’s corporate ladder, CNet News.com suggests. Earlier this month, venture capitalist and Netscape founder Jim Clark announced his departure from the board of directors at photo-printing site Shutterfly, where he served as chairman. In his resignation letter, he cited “the constraints imposed by Sarbanes-Oxley” as one of the primary reasons for departure.

headline: Soros Likes Obama, Is Worried About Leverage
abstract: George Soros says America needs “denazification.”

headline: Apollo Signs $3.1 Billion Deal to Buy Claire’s
abstract: It’s official: Claire’s Stores, purveyor of costume jewelry and accessories to preteens, said Tuesday afternoon that it will be acquired by Apollo Management for about $3.1 billion in cash. Under the terms of the deal, Apollo will pay $33 a share for the company, a premium over Monday’s closing price of $30.76.

headline: Watch a Plasma TV…for Your Health
abstract: Did your mother tell you that watching too much TV would strain your eyes? Turns out she was right.

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Rival TXU Bid
abstract: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group are leading a consortium that is considering making a rival bid for TXU, The Financial Times and Reuters reported Monday, citing undisclosed sources. Such a move could spark a bidding war for the Texas energy giant, which recently agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group for $45 billion.

headline: Friendly Ice Cream to Consider Sale
abstract: Friendly Ice Cream, a 72-year-old chain known for its sandwiches and sundaes, said it had hired Goldman Sachs to explore a possible sale of the company. Friendly, which has been under pressure from an activist shareholder, could attract interest from middle-market private equity firms that invest in franchised restaurant chains, The Deal said.

headline: Bears, Colts and (Corporate) Jets
abstract: A composite radar image of corporate jets departing the Miami area on Monday morning — the day after the Super Bowl took place there — appears to show a parade of planes making beelines for New York, many of them doubtless hauling their human cargo back to jobs on Wall Street. A considerable number were headed to Chicago, and another handful seemed to be flying to, well, flyover country. The image, accessible Wednesday at the Air Transport Association’s smartskies.org, has since been removed from that site, but not before it was picked up by other sites to be made the object of snarky comments. (Update: The image is back, at least for now.)

headline: CVS Sweetens Caremark Deal with $2 a Share Dividend
abstract: Fighting back against a higher $24.8 billion offer from Express Scripts, CVS said Tuesday afternoon that it would pay Caremark Rx holders a special $2 a share dividend. The one-time move is an effort by the drugstore chain to shore up its $23.3 billion offer for the prescription benefits manager, as Express Scripts launched its tender offer for Caremark shares. Caremark’s board has said it favors the CVS offer despite its lower valuation, citing antitrust concerns in a merger with Express Scripts.

headline: Essar Lines Up Financial Pledges for Cellphone Company Bid
abstract: Essar of India has secured financing pledges for a potential bid for the 67 percent that it does not own of Hutchison Essar, the cellphone operator it jointly owns with Hong Kong’s Hutchison Telecommunication International, The Financial Times reported. The paper said that Essar’s move underscores its seriousness and proves its toughness against rival bidders Vodafone and Reliance Communications.

headline: US Airways Chief Sentenced for DUI
abstract: US Airways‘ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, was sentenced to one day in jail and a fine of $1,646 after pleading guilty to driving under the influence. Mr. Parker was pulled over for speeding Jan. 31, the same day that US Airways dropped its $10 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. Mr. Parker, who will serve his 24 hours behind bars on March 15, pleaded guilty Tuesday to the DUI against the advice of his attorney, the airline said.

headline: Siemens Executive Arrested
abstract: German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens on Tuesday in an investigation into suspected bribery, dealing the troubled company another blow in what has become a steady barrage of corruption accusations. The executive, Johannes Feldmayer, was detained as prosecutors searched company offices in Munich, where Siemens is based, and two other German cities, a spokeswoman for Siemens said.

headline: With a U.S. Partner, First Family of Canadian Media Tests Ownership Rules
abstract: By relying on money from Goldman Sachs to do a deal, the chief executive of the media giant Canwest is directly challenging Canadian laws banning the foreign control of broadcasters.

headline: Pricing of Chinese Retail I.P.O. Suggests Demand Is Alive and Well
abstract: China’s Intime Department Store has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total of 2.43 billion Hong Kong dollars ($311 million), suggesting the recent market correction and subsequent volatility has not had much impact on the Hong Kong I.P.O. market. Other parts of the capital markets are finding the going tough at the moment, but FinanceAsia notes that companies that have chosen to go ahead with their Hong Kong I.P.O.s have found that investor demand is still there.

headline: Will Blackstone Raise Its Equity Office Bid? Speculation Abounds
abstract: The Blackstone Group is apt to fight back in the bidding war over Equity Office Properties Trust by raising its $36 billion bid, Reuters reported Monday, citing “industry sources.”

headline: Some Shareholder Grumblings Over Lear Deal
abstract: Carl C. Icahn may experience some turbulence as he navigates his $2.8 billion deal to buy the Lear Corporation. Several shareholders, including one of Lear’s biggest, criticized the deal, which the company agreed to Friday.

headline: Highland Capital Raises Ruckus Over Delphi Plan
abstract: Delphi is facing objections to its bid for a six-month extension of its right to develop its bankruptcy-reorganization plan without interference from creditors or investors. Delphi, an auto parts supplier, said it needs the extra time to meet the terms of a “framework agreement” that proposes a $3.4 billion capital infusion from a pair of hedge funds and a private equity firm.

headline: Endesa Board Likely to Accept E.ON Offer, Report Says
abstract: The board of Endesa will meet Tuesday to consider its response to a 41 billion euro ($53 billion) bid by E.ON of Germany in what should mark the final stage of the battle for control of Endesa, Spain’s largest electricity group. The Financial Times reported that directors are likely to recommend the 38.75-euro-a-share offer, which is 41 percent higher than the original bid presented by E.ON almost a year ago

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Said to Be Near Cap in $16 Billion Fund
abstract: Contributing to a record-breaking fund-raising year in 2006, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has now closed on $16.1 billion for its newest buyout fund, according to LBO Wire. The New York-based buyout shop has yet to hold a final closing for the fund, KKR Associates 2006 Fund LP, which has a cap of $16.625 billion, the report said.

headline: Aruba Raises $88 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Wireless local-area-network technology developer Aruba Networks generated about $88 million in its first day of trading on Nasdaq Tuesday. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is one of a crop of venture capital-backed compaines to have done well in March I.P.O.s. Others include Glu Mobile and Sourcefire even though none of them has shown a profit. Still, Aruba is growing. Its revenue rose to $72.5 million last year from $12 million in 2005.

headline: British Venture Capital Investor Raises Record Biotech Fund
abstract: A British venture capital investor, Abingworth, has raised Europe’s largest ever life sciences venture fund, worth 300 million pounds ($589 million), according to The Guardian. The news is a boon for the industry’s start-ups, which, according to the paper, have been lamenting the lack of venture capital funds for biotech firms in Britain.

headline: Russian Prosecutors Search Office of Yukos’s Audit Firm
abstract: Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCoopers’s own tax filings. Russian officials have compared the Yukos affair to the Enron scandal in the United States, with ominous implications for the firm.

headline: ICV and Palladium Sell Eyewear Supplier Hilsinger
abstract: ICV Capital Partners and Palladium Equity Partners said Tuesday they sold a vision-products business, Hilsinger Holdings to PNC Equity Partners in a secondary buyout that The Deal.com said was valued at more than $100 million. The sale allowed ICV and Palladium to pocket 2.5 times their original money and yielded an internal rate of return of more than 30 percent.

headline: Affiliated Computer Gets Buyout Offer
abstract: Affiliated Computer Services‘s chairman, Darwin Deason, and Cerberus Capital Management said Tuesday they had offered to take the technology outsourcing company private for $59.25 a share in cash, or about $8.2 billion including assumed debt. The offer represents a 15.5 percent premium to Affiliated Computer’s closing share price Monday.

headline: Merrill Chief Pocketed $48 Million in 2006
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said Wednesday in a regulatory filing. Mr. O’Neal received $700,000 in salary for 2006, a cash bonus of $18.5 million and stock valued at $28.8 million. The previous year, Merrill gave Mr. O’Neal $37 million in salary and bonuses.

headline: In the Law-Firm Pay Race, Who’s Really Ahead?
abstract: On Thursday, Holland & Knight became the latest law firm to raise the pay of its first-year associates. In doing so, it joins a long line of firms that are increasing compensation offers as competition to attract and retain young lawyers gets hotter. Still, the National Law Journal suggests that, while increases for associates may sound impressive, as measured against what law firm’s partners are getting, associates’ pay is actually falling.

headline: China Stocks Top $1 Trillion
abstract: China’s stocks have surpassed $1 trillion in value after indexes more than doubled last year and the government encouraged the domestic listing of state-owned companies like Industrial & Commercial Bank of China. The combined value of shares listed on the stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen rose to $1.01 trillion, making mainland China the world’s 10th biggest equity market, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

headline: Qwest Gave Chief a Raise Despite Cloud, Witness Says
abstract: A former director of Qwest Communications testified Thursday that the board had agreed to give Joseph P. Nacchio, then its chief executive, a raise and 7.25 million shares in stock options about a month after the phone company acknowledged for the first time that it had used one-time transactions to help meet financial targets.

headline: Texas Pacific May Also Like the Looks of Europe’s Biggest L.B.O.
abstract: The private equity firm Texas Pacific Group may try to elbow in on a possible deal for the British supermarket giant J. Sainsbury and is working on building a consortium, the Financial Times reported. The rival buyout shops CVC, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone said on Friday they were in the early stages of assessing a bid for Sainsbury, Britain’s third-largest supermarket owner, in what would be Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout.

headline: Hedge Funds Take Hollywood, but For How Long?
abstract: In an article on the ubiquity of hedge funds in Hollywood these days, The Economist says that the survival rate of the new wannabe studios backed by investment pools may not be high. Noting that three-quarters of the newly financed outfits may be gone within five years, it also notes that the film industry’s real problem is not so much a shortage of films as a shortage of eyeballs.

headline: Signals of Distress in Europe Seen in Banks’ Hiring Trend
abstract: Are the big investment banks seeing distress signals in Europe? They could be, according to Financial News, which sees a larger trend in Morgan Stanley‘s recent hiring of a top European restructuring banker. The article describes “a renewed scramble by investment banks and hedge funds to hire high-yield and distressed-debt traders” before a downturn in the credit market, which, if it were to happen, is likely to trigger a wave of defaults and bankruptcies. Activity on that front has been low lately.

headline: Barclays Pays Record Price to Put Name on Nets’ Arena
abstract: It looks $400 million is the going rate these days to buy naming rights for the play grounds of professional sports teams, at least when investment banks are anteing up. Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the New Jersey Nets’ planned future home in Brooklyn, according to press reports. The deal follows Citigroup‘s November agreement to shell out $20 million a year over 20 years to have its name attached to the structure replacing Shea Stadium, the most expensive stadium rights deal in the United States.

headline: Zell Defends His Dealmaking Prowess
abstract: Samuel Zell has an answer for critics who argue that the $39 billion deal he made to sell his Equity Office Properties to the Blackstone Group could have been even more lucrative. DealBook suggested as much in its recent column in The New York Times, writing that while Mr. Zell “played the Blackstone Group and Vornado Realty Trust like two fiddles,” he also left money on the table when he accepted a higher breakup fee in return for Blackstone’s raised bid, because it limited Vornado’s ability to come back with an even bigger offer.

headline: Britain to Put Private Equity in the Hotseat
abstract: Even as a collection of private equity firms are circling the United Kingdom’s largest supermarket chain — and perhaps partly because they are circling it — Britain’s Parliament is preparing to conduct an inquiry into the private equity business. At issue: asset-stripping, “short-termism” and complaints that there is a general lack of accountability for private equity funds, which usually buy public companies in debt-financed deals in hopes of selling them or taking them public later at a profit.

headline: France’s Weinberg Capital Cooks Up Bakery Deal
abstract: Weinberg Capital Partners, a French buyout fund headed by the former head of luxury goods group PPR, Serge Weinberg, said Friday it had agreed to buy 60 percent of French baking equipment maker Sasa Industrie in a deal that values the group at 80.7 million euros ($106 million). The acquisition is the fourth by Weinberg Capital, which was founded in July 2005 by Mr. Weinberg, one of France’s highest-profile managers, and three partners, Guillaume d’Angerville, Henri Gagnaire and Philippe Klocanas.

headline: Big Media’s Web Video Play May Help Start-Ups
abstract: The news that the News Corporation and NBC Universal are teaming up to start an online video distribution network that may well rival Google‘s YouTube is a tale of big-name media giants trying to outmaneuver one another as they struggle to win control of content distribution on the Internet.

headline: Overstock Takes Banks to Court Over Short Selling
abstract: Overstock.com, whose chief executive has been roundly criticized for his crusade against naked short selling and what he claims is a vast conspiracy to bring down the stock of his company, filed a $3.5 billion lawsuit in California state court Friday accusing 10 of the largest securities firms in the nation of participating in a “massive, illegal stock market manipulation scheme” to distort the retailer’s stock.

headline: BitTorrent Comes to the Television
abstract: A new Netgear product, developed with BitTorrent, will find any media content that is sitting on your PC and send it over to your TV wirelessly.

headline: Is Icahn Forcing Motorola to Mortgage its Future?
abstract: Carl Icahn’s demands on Motorola — of which the activist investor owns 2.7 percent – have put the company at an “existential crossroads,” Roben Farzad of BusinessWeek wrote. In his commentary, Mr. Farzad suggests that Mr. Icahn’s calls for huge share buybacks could force the cellphone company to “mortgage future cash flows by taking on debt.”

headline: Microsoft to Buy Speech Technology Company
abstract: Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company. In a statement, Microsoft said that it plans to integrate Tellme’s products into its mobile offerings, with a long-term goal of integrating the technology into the rest of its lineup.

headline: Yankee Candle Shareholders Say Yes to a Buyout
abstract: Madison Dearborn Partners‘ $1.4 billion buyout of Yankee Candle moved one step closer to completion Tuesday after Yankee stockholders formally voted to accept the private equity firm’s all-cash $34.75-a-share proposal.

headline: Hedge Fund Scrutiny With an International Flair
abstract: Finance ministers from the world’s leading economies put the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry on the international policy agenda on Saturday, saying they would scrutinize the sector with an eye toward encouraging more self-regulation. Representatives from the Group of 7 nations, who met in the industrial center of the host country, Germany, issued a statement saying that the practices of hedge funds, which have drawn growing concern from financial policy makers over the last few years, have “become more complex and challenging” in light of the industry’s prominence and volatility.

headline: SideStep Raises $15 Million to Expand Horizons
abstract: A travel search company, SideStep, has raised $15 million in a Series C round of funding led by Norwest Venture Partners, CNet News.com reported. The investment, which CNet said SideStep plans to announce on Wednesday, is the largest single injection yet for the company, bringing its total venture capital to $32 million. Other investors reportedly include Trident Capital, Leader Ventures and Saints Capital. The report said that the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to use the cash to pay for acquisitions in the United States, Europe and Asia.

headline: Canadian Consortium Inks Deal for New Zealand Yellow Pages
abstract: The investment arm of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan of Canada has bought Telecom New Zealand‘s yellow pages directories business for about C$1.85 billion ($1.59 billion), the telecom provider said Monday. Private equity consortium of CCMP Capital and Teachers’ Private Capital, the investment arm of the O.T.P.P., has bought the yellow and white pages directories, both print and online.

headline: $40.6 Million in Pay for Lehman’s Chief
abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the brokerage firm Lehman Brothers Holdings, made $40.6 million in compensation last year after the company reported near-record profits, according to a regulatory filing on Monday. Mr. Fuld made a salary of $750,000 and a bonus of $6.24 million, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Chrysler to Announce Job Cuts, Plant Closings
abstract: The Chrysler Group is set to announce a restructuring plan Wednesday aimed at securing its place in the crowded American car market – and within DaimlerChrysler. The plan is expected to include the elimination of about 11,000 blue- and white-collar jobs along with the closing of one and possibly two assembly plants – in Delaware and Missouri, The New York Times said.

headline: Delta, US Air Executives to Testify on Airline Mergers
abstract: The Senate will hear testimony about the effects of potential airline mergers Wednesday morning, as the takeover feud between US Airways and Delta Air Lines comes to a possible head. Top executives of both airlines will field questions from lawmakers about US Airways’ unsolicited $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta — which Delta has opposed — as other players continue to try to influence the endgame.

headline: Sun Life Buys Genworth Unit
abstract: Canada’s Sun Life Financial said on Thursday it would buy Genworth Financial‘s group benefits business in the United States for $650 million. Sun Life, Canada’s third largest insurer by market value, said the acquisition would expand its business in the United States. A Morgan Stanley analyst, Ken Zerbe, said in a research note that the deal appeared to be positive for Sun Life, which had been “a sub-scale player” in the United States group insurance market and was searching for a chance to bulk up.

headline: Clear Channel Bidders Bash Analyst Critic
abstract: Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners, the buyout shops behind the Mays family’s bid to take Clear Channel Communications private, have been trash talking a Bears Stearns analyst who has pegged their $18.7 billion bid as too low, The New York Post reported.

headline: The Hard Rain That’s Falling on Capitalism
abstract: Bad corporate behavior, including avaricious management-led buyouts and options backdating, is undermining the trust that is the bedrock of capitalism, Ben Stein writes in The New York Times. Among the offenses that Mr. Stein sees being perpetrated are backdating and management buyouts, both of which he says fleece shareholders.

headline: Prosecutor in Apple Case Joins Law Firm
abstract: Christopher J. Steskal, a lead prosecutor of a federal task force investigating the backdating of stock options at Apple and other companies, is leaving his San Francisco post to join a law firm, the United State Attorney’s office in San Francisco confirmed late Friday.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Shift on Antitrust Issues May Aid Sirius-XM Deal
abstract: While XM Satellite Radio‘s merger deal with rival Sirius Satellite Radio has drawn numerous comparisons with EchoStar Communications’ failed effort to merge with DirecTV four years ago, the regulatory climate that led the Federal Communications Commission to block the deal has changed, The New York Times reports.

headline: Sit Down for a Chat With Hedge Fund Movers
abstract: A new book on hedge funds pulls back the curtain slightly on an industry that is gaining increasing attention from lawmakers, regulators and the media. The New York Times says that “Inside the House of Money” by Steven Drobny is less a book of sustained narration or explanation than a notebook of interviews developed from exclusive confabs sponsored by the author’s consulting firm, Drobny Global Advisors. Still, it says, the ruminations of supposedly hush-hush hedge fund operators are richly illuminating and cost much less expensive than the fees they charge.

headline: Drug Manager Raises Caremark Bid but Sees Delay
abstract: Express Scripts raised its $26.1 billion bid for Caremark Rx, a rival drug-benefit manager, on Wednesday but cautioned that the bid would be delayed by further regulatory scrutiny. In raising its bid, Express Scripts sought to prolong an already tough battle for Caremark, which is twice its size. Both Express Scripts and its competing bidder, CVS, the nation’s largest pharmacy chain, have exchanged barbed remarks to win shareholder support for their offers.

headline: Civil War, or War Against Civilians?
abstract: There has been great debate in recent months about whether the conflict in Iraq can accurately be called a civil war. Iraqi Vice President Adil Abdul Mahdi offered his view Thursday in a panel discussion at Davos chaired by Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.

headline: Morgan Stanley Moves into Canada With Infrastructure Buy
abstract: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay about C$460 million ($396 million) for a majority stake in a Montreal-based container-shipping operation, making its first venture into Canada. The financial services firm is buying Montreal Gateway Terminals from TUI, a German shipping and tourism conglomerate, in a move that pits Morgan Stanley against the likes of Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Australia’s Macquarie Bank Ltd. and Toronto-based Brookfield Asset Management for control of Canadian infrastructure assets.

headline: Report on Wall Street’s Decline Draws More Skepticism
abstract: A study released this month by New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Charles E. Schumer, which flagged an exodus of foreign offerings from New York exchanges as a sign that Wall Street’s dominance is on the wane, has sparked a debate over what the data really mean.

headline: Spinning Google and YouTube Into Gold
abstract: Riding two of the Internet’s big success stories, Google and YouTube, venture capitalist Michael Moritz of Sequoia Capital took the No. 1 spot on Forbes’s latest Midas List, an annual ranking of the top 100 dealmakers in technology and the life sciences.

headline: Will Bid for Affiliated Computer Go Higher?
abstract: Affiliated Computer Services should hold out for a higher price from Darwin Deason and Cerberus Capital Management, according to Breakingviews and the Financial Times’s Lex column. Mr. Deason, who is Affiliated Computer’s chairman, and Cerberus offered Tuesday to buy the company for $59.25 per share, but a Prudential analyst thinks Mr. Deason might be open to other bidding partners.

headline: Buyout Firm and Partner Bid for British Drugstores
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britain’s largest drugstore chain. The move comes amid a flurry of buyout interest in European retailers. K.K.R., based in New York, and Mr. Pessina, who is the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots and its largest shareholder, made a friendly approach worth 1,000 pence in cash for each Alliance share, or about 9.7 billion pounds ($19 billion).

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Reports 2006 Profit Increase
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group said its profit rose 14 percent last year and raised its dividend by 25 percent. The bank said 2006 operating profit reached 9.41 billion pounds ($18.4 billion), up from 8.25 billion in 2005 and narrowly ahead of an average forecast of 9.34 billion from a Reuters Estimates poll.

headline: Hedge Fund Report Draws Mixed Reactions
abstract: Guidelines for safeguarding the hedge fund industry released yesterday by the Bush administration drew applause from much of Wall Street for their laissez-faire approach. A combination of common sense and market forces should be enough to keep this trillion-dollar-plus asset class from disrupting markets or decimating workers’ pensions, the report suggested. But there was criticism from some lawmakers and industry observers — as well as the attorney general of Connecticut, home to many of the biggest hedge funds — who complained the report’s recommendations were too weak.

headline: Food for Thought: an Apple V.C. Fund
abstract: Apple is sitting on $12 billion in cash, and the pile is growing by more than $1 billion every quarter. How should the high-flying maker of iPods and Macs spend that money? According to BusinessWeek’s Arik Hesseldahl, the company should launch a $1 billion venture-capital fund. Big acquisitions, especially of tech companies, haven’t always fared well, Mr. Hesseldahl writes. Apple also has a tendency to pick up small companies whose projects can easily be integrated with its own.

headline: Power Announces $3.9 Billion Deal for Putnam
abstract: The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan said on Thursday that it would sell its troubled money manager, Putnam Investments, to a unit of Power Financial of Canada for $3.9 billion. The sale price was in line with recent press reports, but toward the lower end of initial estimates of how much Putnam would fetch when Marsh & McLennan said in September that it was considering a sale.

headline: Reclaiming Video Resumes For the ‘Forces of Good’
abstract: The operators of career Web site Vault.com are encouraging would-be investment bankers to produce video resumes, but they have no intention of inspiring “Impossible Is Nothing II.” Don’t wax philosophical, they advise, and please — no feats of strength.

headline: What Keeps Buyout Bigwigs Up at Night
abstract: Private equity chiefs are used to making daring, debt-heavy bets that would cause other investors to go pale. So what strikes fear into the hearts of a buyout veteran?

headline: Buyout Team Considers Bid for British Supermarket Giant
abstract: In what would be Europe’s largest leveraged buyout, Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and CVC Capital Partners say they are considering an offer for the British supermarket company J. Sainsbury. Sainsbury shares soared as much as 18 percent Friday, giving the London-based company a market value of 8.8 billion pounds ($17.3 billion).

headline: Lasik Surgery Company Will Buy a Rival
abstract: Advanced Medical Optics, a laser vision correction company, said yesterday that it would buy a rival, IntraLase, for about $808 million, gaining its competitor’s popular blade-free technology used during Lasik surgery. The cash deal, valued at $25 a share, represents a 12.5 percent premium over IntraLase’s closing price of $22.23 on Friday. Advanced Medical Optics said it expected to complete the acquisition early in the second quarter.

headline: More Talk of a Time Warner Revamp
abstract: Carl Icahn must be smiling.

headline: Merkel of Germany Says ‘Nein’ to Protectionism
abstract: Addressing an audience of world leaders and top executives, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany opened this year’s Davos conference with a wide-ranging speech that touched on climate change, trade talks and hedge funds, among other topics. Ms. Merkel offered up her views on globalization, which carry special resonance because Germany this year took over the rotating presidency of the Group of Eight, the leading industrialized nations, which will hold a summit meeting in June.

headline: Time Warner Elects Motorola Chief and Its Own President to the Board
abstract: Motorola Chairman and Chief Executive Ed Zander and Time Warner President and Chief Operating Officer Jeffrey Bewkes have both been elected to join Time Warner’s board, the company announced Thursday. Richard Parsons, Time Warner’s board chairman and C.E.O., credits Mr. Bewkes with helping him turn around Time Warner and leading the AOL transition, while Mr. Zander brings mobile communications expertise to the table.

headline: Red Kite Calls Investor Withdrawals ‘Insignificant’
abstract: RK Capital Management downplayed reports of investors withdrawing cash from its $1 billion Red Kite Metals hedge fund, after the firm suffered a 30 percent loss last month. “We are pleased to report that our investor base, including all of our major investors, has given us strong support and encouragement for the future,” Red Kite, run out of London and New York, said in a statement Friday.

headline: Former Monster Lawyer in Plea Deal, Report Says
abstract: Federal prosecutors are expected to announce a plea deal with a former executive of recruitment service Monster Worldwide in a stock options manipulation case, the Wall Street Journal reported. The company’s former general counsel, Myron Olesnyckyj, has agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in Manhattan and is expected to describe the role of founder Andrew McKelvey and others in stock-options practices at Monster, the paper said.

headline: Nasdaq Chief Says He ‘Chose Not to Win’ L.S.E.
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market Chief Executive Robert Greifeld had what seemed like a somewhat novel take on his resounding defeat on the bid for the London Stock Exchange. Speaking Tuesday during a conference call to announce Nasdaq’s fourth-quarter results, Mr. Greifeld said that he “chose not to win” the war for the overseas rival, after L.S.E. shareholders, calling Nasdaq’s bid of 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) too low, suggested higher prices they might accept. Nasdaq ended up with commitments of less than 0.5 percent from L.S.E. shareholders.

headline: Blodget Thinks Web 2.0 Should Go While The Going Is Good
abstract: Henry Blodget sees possible storm clouds ahead for Web 2.0 start-ups. Writing in Forbes, the former star tech analyst that should the stock market tank due to “housing, flattening corporate profits, recession, China recession, etc.”, the Internet stocks will go with it.

headline: Corruption Charges Follow Siemens to the U.S.
abstract: A corruption affair that has shaken the German industrial conglomerate Siemens has spread to the United States with investigations by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. “The U.S. Department of Justice is conducting an investigation of possible criminal violations of U.S. law by Siemens in connection with these matters,” Siemens said in its first-quarter financial report. The company is being investigated by German prosecutors for suspected bribery related to telecoms contracts.

headline: S.& P. Buys 3 Indexes
abstract: The Standard & Poor‘s unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies agreed to buy the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index and two other products from Goldman Sachs, S.& P. said. Goldman’s index, created in 1991, tracks 24 commodities to provide investors with a reliable benchmark, S.& P. said. S.& P. also agreed to buy Goldman’s Sector and Technology Indexes. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Morgan Stanley and Swedish Group Buy Healthcare Firm
abstract: Investor, the holding company of the Swedish billionaire Wallenberg family, teamed up with Morgan Stanley to buy Moelnlycke Health Care for 2.85 billion euros ($3.7 billion) including debt. Stockholm-based Investor and Morgan Stanley will buy the maker of surgical gloves from London-based Apax Partners. Investor said it is financing the purchase mainly with debt

headline: Hedge Funds Walk Line Between Silence and Sharing
abstract: How do you become less secretive about your business without actually talking about it? Such is the conundrum faced by hedge funds, which are described more often than not as secretive. Hedge funds are governed by a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that prohibits them from engaging in anything that could be construed as advertising or any kind of general solicitation. To hedge funds’ cautious general counsels, that means no talking on the record to the news media about the fund.

headline: NCR to Spin Off Teradata Unit
abstract: NCR, the world’s largest maker of automated-teller machines, said it would split into two public companies, spinning off its Teradata data warehousing business. The spinoff should be completed in six to nine months, separating their businesses into NCR’s banking and checkout systems and Teradata’s corporate data storage operations, NCR said in a statement Monday. J.P. Morgan Chase is serving as financial adviser in the move.

headline: Quanta Services Sets $1.26 Billion Deal
abstract: Quanta Services, a provider of engineering support to power companies, said Monday it had agreed to buy InfraSource Services, a Pennsylvania company that also provides services to utilities, for $1.26 billion in stock.

headline: Lehman Buys Stake in Large Hedge Fund
abstract: Moving deeper into the alternative-asset management business, Lehman Brothers said Tuesday it had bought a 20 percent stake in D.E. Shaw, one of the largest hedge funds in the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it follows similar transactions at Lehman and other Wall Street firms that want to be able to offer their clients greater access to these private pools of capital. Morgan Stanley has been especially active: It announced Monday that it had bought a piece of Abax Global Capital, its fifth hedge-fund investment in the past few months.

headline: Giuliani’s Investment Bank Is Sold
abstract: Giuliani Capital Advisors, the investment banking arm of former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s consulting business, will be acquired by Macquarie Group of Australia, Macquarie said early Monday. The sale, which was expected, comes as Mr. Giuliani embarks on a run for the presidency, raising questions about the fate of his various business endeavors.

headline: EGL Chairman Finds New Buyout Backers
abstract: EGL‘s chairman said Wednesday that he had found a new group of investors, including Centerbridge Partners and the Woodbridge Company, to participate in his offer to take the transportation company private. His previous buyout partner, General Atlantic, withdrew from the original deal, after it was announced in January.

headline: Publishing Deal Maker Sells Cambium Learning
abstract: The former chief executive of Houghton Mifflin, Nader F. Darehshori, who engineered the book publisher’s 2001 sale to Vivendi Universal for $2.2 billion, has sold his five-year old education publishing start-up, Cambium Learning, to a private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson of New York.

headline: No Bonuses for G.M. Executives
abstract: General Motors, which significantly improved its financial performance in 2006 but failed to earn a profit, said on Wednesday that for a second consecutive year, it would not pay cash bonuses to top executives. Such bonuses would undoubtedly have rankled members of the United Automobile Workers union ahead of this summer’s contract talks, although a G.M. spokeswoman, Renee Rashid-Merem, declined to say whether the pending negotiations were a factor.

headline: Equity Office Board Supports Blackstone Offer
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord at the center of a takeover battle, on Friday reaffirmed its support for a $38.3 billion, all-cash bid from private equity firm Blackstone Group, saying it was less risky for shareholders than a $41 billion cash-and-stock offer from Vornado Realty Trust. Equity Office also said a vote on Blackstone’s offer will probably take place Feb. 7, two days later than previously planned, to give shareholders time to review new information about the bid.

headline: Sony Dips Its Toes Into Internet TV
abstract: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off.

headline: Greenberg Invests in China Buyout Fund
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg’s Starr International will take a 50 percent stake in a 1 billion yuan ($129 million) private-equity fund to invest in Chinese companies. In the first confirmed investment in China since he was ousted from the American International Group, Mr. Greenberg’s company will invest alongside state-owned Citic Securities, China’s biggest publicly traded broker. During his tenure at AIG, Mr. Greenberg, who ran the insurance giant for 38 years before getting the boot, won the first insurance license in China for an overseas company since the country’s communist revolution in 1949.

headline: Timberland Said to Call Off Auction
abstract: Timberland ended an effort to sell itself after bids from major strategic and financial buyers fell short of expectations, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. In November it was reported that the footwear company had hired Goldman Sachs to seek out potential buyers.

headline: Worrying About Wall Street
