abstract: The top five Wall Street investment banks have lost a combined $40 billion in market value in the past few weeks as shareholders have fretted about subprime mortgages. That seems like an extreme overreaction, but it might not be if the troubles spill into the broader market, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Tokyo Exchange Considers Alliance in Chicago
abstract: The Tokyo Stock Exchange, which agreed this week to collaborate with the New York Stock Exchange, is discussing a potential alliance with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, an official at the Tokyo exchange said Thursday. “We are in negotiations for a possible alliance with the C.M.E., especially in the area of futures trading of Japan government bonds,” The spokesman, Toru Onoda, told The Associated Press.

headline: Mixed Results for Hedge Funds in February
abstract: Most hedge funds made money in February but some trend-following strategies and managers focused on the financial-services sector were hit by the sharp market sell-off late last month, Hedge Fund Research, a firm that tracks industry performance, said on Wednesday. Hedge funds returned 0.65 percent on average in February as gains from earlier in the month helped offset the effect of sharp stock market declines on Feb. 27, according to early calculations from the firm. About a quarter of the managers the research group tracks have reported February results.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Questions Satellite Radio Deal
abstract: Mel Karmazin, whom The New York Times’ Richard Siklos described as a man who “could sell microwavable ice to Eskimos,” has apparently not sold Kevin J. Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, on his plan to merge the nation’s two satellite radio companies.

headline: Former Brocade Official Seeks a Separate Trial
abstract: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former human resources director, accused of conspiring with the company’s former chief executive to manipulate stock option grants, asked a judge for a separate trial. Stephanie Jensen, charged in August with conspiracy, fraud and false securities filing, seeks to sever her case from that of Brocade’s former C.E.O., Greg Reyes, so he can provide exculpatory testimony at her trial, according to a filing in San Francisco federal court Friday.

headline: Enel and Acciona Will Challenge E.On’s Bid for Endesa
abstract: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, and Acciona said they will offer at least 41 euros ($54.37) a share for the stock they don’t already own of Spanish power company Endesa, trumping a rival bid by E.On. The offer depends on E.On receiving less than 50 percent of Endesa in its tender, Acciona said in a statement Monday. The bid by Enel and Acciona, which together control 46 percent of Endesa, values all of Spain’s largest power utility at a minimum of 43.4 billion euros.

headline: Gol to Resurrect Varig
abstract: Gol will buy Brazil’s former flagship carrier, Varig, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $275 million, Gol said Wednesday. Gol will also assume about $45 million of Varig’s debt. Varig, which had been Brazil’s top airline for decades, fell victim to crushing debt last year and was bought in bankruptcy proceedings by investors that included Brazilians and the United States investment fund Matlin Patterson.

headline: Why Wall Street Is Rushing to Schmooze
abstract: After the record earnings they took home last year, Wall Street firms appear to be actively courting more prospects for mergers and initial public offerings. But why are so many gatherings taking place at the same time?

headline: Tears Cast a Shadow at a Sunny Tech Gathering
abstract: Much is being made of venture capitalist John Doerr breaking down into tears as he talked about global warming on Thursday during the TED conference in Monterey, Calif. But what may be more disturbing is what he actually said: “I’m scared. I don’t think we’re going to make it.”

headline: With Ericsson Bid, Tanderg TV Develops Bidding War
abstract: Ericsson, the world’s largest maker of wireless network gear, made a 9.8 billion-kronor ($1.4 billion) cash bid for Norway’s Tandberg Television, topping a rival offer by the Arris Group. Ericsson, based in Stockholm, is bidding 106 Norwegian kroner for each share of Tandberg TV,which boasts more than a quarter of the global market for video processing. Arris offered 96 kroner in cash and stock on Jan. 15. Tandberg Television’s stock rose 11 percent.

headline: The Complicated End of an Ex-Law Firm
abstract: At one time, the breakup of a big, prestigious law firm was rare. But since the technology boom and bust, implosions of once highflying firms like Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison and Testa, Hurwitz & Thibeault have occurred with more frequency.

headline: Guessing games on a Formula One champion to be
abstract: In this short period between the last days of winter testing and the first race of the season next week at the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne on March 18, the race is on to predict who the next world champion will be. Actually, there are discussions of a few more angles than just that, and from every quarter.

headline: Caremark Makes Its Case for CVS Deal
abstract: The pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx on Tuesday sent a letter to its shareholders urging them to vote for its pending merger with the drugstore operator CVS. Caremark says in the letter that the proposed $21.2 billion buyout by CVS will deliver immediate value to shareholders and has a high probability of being completed in about a month.

headline: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology
abstract: After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology. In Silicon Valley, investment in clean technology – from alternative energy products, like solar panels and hybrid cars, to the use of nanotechnology to solve environmental problems – went from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter, according to an annual report released Sunday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, a research organization in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Fortress Affiliate Sees Deals in Subprime Mortgages
abstract: While the troubled subprime mortgage market has weighed down Wall Street — Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers both reported that their 1st-quarter revenues were hurt by the sector — others see a buying opportunity. Buyers like Goldman Sachs have said that they see a chance to acquire beaten down assets cheaply, anticipating a rebound, rather than a continued implosion.

headline: Northwest Restructuring Makes Headway
abstract: Northwest Airlines can begin seeking creditor approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy that values the company at an estimated $7 billion, a judge ruled Monday. Judge Allan L. Gropper of Federal Bankruptcy Court said that when Northwest revises its disclosure statement to include agreements reached on Monday, the statement could be released to creditors along with a restructuring plan.

headline: Bear Stearns Profit Rises 8 Percent
abstract: Bear Stearns, Wall Street’s leading underwriter of mortgage-backed securities, said Thursday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter rose 8 percent from a year ago, but problems in the risky subprime loan sector hurt mortgage-related revenue. The investment bank said net income in the quarter increased to $554 million from $514 million in the year-earlier period.

headline: A Book Review and an Apology and Conrad Black in Headlines Again
abstract: Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, has been relatively quiet lately as he awaits his trial this spring on fraud and racketeering charges in Chicago. But a literary spat and apology to the author of a book he reviewed critically put him back in the gossip pages last week, writes The New York Times.

headline: Russia’s Sitronics Raises $350 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Sitronics, a technology company owned by a Russian conglomerate, Sistema, priced its initial public offering on Wednesday at the low end of the expected range, raising about $350 million through a dual listing in Moscow and London.

headline: The Suitors for Chrysler Grow Sparse
abstract: DaimlerChrysler would prefer to sell the struggling Chrysler Group in one piece rather than let potential bidders pick and choose among its assets, The New York Times reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the situation. But it is hard to find anyone who will admit to being interested in buying Chrysler, at least before J.P. Morgan Chase sends out the offer book that it is preparing on the struggling American car company.

headline: Executive Coach With a Groovy Approach
abstract: In the growing field of executive coaching, Marshall Goldsmith is among the cream of the crop — and seems to be feeling very Zen about it. Mr. Goldsmith, who apparently has coached bigwigs at companies including Boeing, Motorola and Goldman Sachs, promotes a Buddhist-inspired path to enlightened leadership, according to a profile of the coach in The Chicago Tribune.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Qatar May Take a 10% Stake in EADS, Official Says
abstract: Qatar is in talks to buy a 10 percent stake in EADS, the parent company of Airbus, the country’s foreign minister told news services Monday. Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, who heads the $40 billion Qatar Investment Authority, told Bloomberg News that he was interested if the stake was “at the right value,” though he declined to say how much the authority would invest or from whom it would buy the stake.

headline: Who Will Bring the Internet to Your TV?
abstract: The companies trying to bring the boundless realm of the Internet to the 83-year-old TV are taking one of three markedly different approaches.

headline: World Bank Blacklists More Than 100 Firms
abstract: World Bank investigators blacklisted more than 100 firms and individuals for fraud and corruption in projects financed by the development agency over the past two years, a new report said Tuesday. The report by the Institutional Integrity Department, the bank’s investigative arm that looks into abuse of development funding, said it had investigated and closed 441 cases involving fraud and corruption in projects in 2005 and 2006.

headline: Goldman Said to Be Backing Lionsgate Slate
abstract: Lionsgate is putting the finishing touches on a $210 million financing pact led by Goldman Sachs, according to Variety, in a sign that private equity and hedge fund money continues to pour into Hollywood, despite mixed results on those investments in 2006. The deal apparently provides backing for 23 films, excluding, among other projects, the “Saw” movie franchise. Variety said that Lionsgate will receive a distribution fee of 15 percent — on the high side for deals that cover slates of films — showing just how the mini-studio has impressed Wall Street with its track record and its model of modestly priced films.

headline: News Corp. Puts Cash Into Roo’s Pocket
abstract: The News Corporation is investing $1.3 million in an Australian Web video company, Roo, which provides technology for distributing and syndicating video content. News Corporation will initially take a 5 percent stake in the company, which already powers video services for several News Corporation Web properties, and an additional 5 percent if News Corporation reaches various revenue targets through Roo’s products and services.

headline: A Form 13D, Complete with a Four-Letter Word
abstract: Some harsh words, including the F-bomb, livened up the usually bland world of regulatory filings last week. The colorful exchange, noted by Paul Kedrosky on his blog Infectious Greed, was directed at Robert Chapman, the chief of Chapman Capital, whose grandiloquently harsh criticism of the companies he invests in regularly raises executive ire. (DealBook readers may recall that Mr. Chapman recently complained about not receiving a return phone call from the chief executive of eSpeed, another company he has pressured for change.)

headline: Merrill Chief Could Get $251 Million in Exit
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, could receive $251.4 million if he were to resign from the company under certain circumstances, the company disclosed Friday. The estimated payout would be triggered if Mr. O’Neal was terminated without cause or resigned for good reason, Merrill’s annual proxy statement said.

headline: Amaranth Founder Said to Plan New Firm
abstract: The founder of Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that is winding down after losing more than $6 billion last year, is considering launching a firm with some former colleagues, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

headline: Wall Street Insiders Charged in Stock-Tipping Cases
abstract: An executive at UBS and a former lawyer at Morgan Stanley were charged with conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday for allegedly passing information about pending stock-rating changes and merger announcements to hedge funds and other accomplices, who then traded on the tips. In all, the insider-trading schemes involved 13 defendants who made more than $8 million in illegal profits, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York said in a news release describing the indictments.

headline: G.E. to Buy Energy Company From Investment Firms
abstract: General Electric has agreed to buy Vetco Gray, a maker of oil and gas-drilling and production equipment, for $1.9 billion to profit from surging demand for energy exploration. G.E., the world’s second-biggest company by market value, is acquiring Houston-based Vetco from three private equity firms, the 3i Group, Candover Investments  and J.P. Morgan Partners.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Wish List
abstract: Here are a few of things that Warren E. Buffet, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has on his to-do list:

headline: Profit Slips at Sony on Losses for PlayStation 3
abstract: Sony faulted a strategic decision to set the price of the PlayStation 3 below the cost of production as a way to bolster market share.

headline: This Family’s Hot Stuff
abstract: Five generations of the family that owns and operates the McIlhenny Company have kept the Tabasco sauce business going while weathering many storms.

headline: A Scary Tuesday Was No Black Monday
abstract: The 3.3 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average last Tuesday could almost be called a blip when measured against the biggest plunges on record.

headline: The Future of Hydrogen Cars
abstract: The Times’s David Pogue on the pros and cons of alternative-fuel vehicles.

headline: No Progress in Middle East Talks
abstract: The first peace talks in six years between the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians took place today without any apparent progress beyond an agreement to meet again.

headline: Gap’s Chief Executive Resigns
abstract: Paul S. Pressler stepped down after the clothing retailer’s third dismal holiday shopping season.

headline: Pakistan: 14 Dead in Renewed Northern Fighting
abstract: At least 14 people were killed in renewed clashes between Uzbek militants and local tribesmen in the South Waziristan tribal region, officials said. The new fighting, over a hilltop, followed a four-day lull after more than 110 people were killed in a week. The tribesmen are trying to drive the outsiders, allies of the Taliban, out of Wana, South Waziristan’s main town. While the government has refused to say that it is helping the locals try to oust the foreigners, said to be more than 1,000-strong, sources say it is.

headline: Which Videos Are Protected? Lawmakers Get a Lesson
abstract: After Nancy Pelosi was accused of “pirating” clips from C-Span on her new blog, members of Congress were introduced to the complexities of copyright law.

headline: EMI Merging Record Labels and Ousting Capitol’s President
abstract: The cuts are expected to represent the effective end of Capitol Records as a stand-alone label.

headline: A Higher Bid for REIT Is Expected by Vornado
abstract: A consortium of investors led by Vornado Realty Trust planned to raise its bid for Equity Office Properties Group to more than $40 billion.

headline: U.N. Considers New Iran Sanctions Resolution
abstract: The resolution would impose sanctions on Iran for its defiance of demands that it suspend nuclear enrichment.

headline: Discovery to Buy Out Cox, a Major Shareholder
abstract: The deal will transfer the Travel Channel, a museum audio tour business and $1.275 billion in cash to Cox in exchange for its 25 percent stake.

headline: Finding the Green in Building Renovation
abstract: A New York developer has an eye on making environmentally conscious improvements to properties in locations served by mass transit.

headline: German Court Frees Leader of Terror Group
abstract: Brigitte Mohnhaupt, a leader of the terrorist Red Army Faction, has been imprisoned for 24 years for kidnappings and murders in the 1970s.

headline: Iraq Defends Hanging, but Holds Hussein Guard
abstract: The arrest was in connection with the cellphone video showing Saddam Hussein being taunted before his death.

headline: Suspected Maoist Rebels Kill Many Indian Police
abstract: The ambush appeared to be the biggest attack on Indian law enforcement in the last several years of insurgency.

headline: Orin Atkins, 82, Executive Who Built Up Ashland Oil, Dies
abstract: Orin E. Atkins’s 16-year tenure as chief executive of Ashland Oil was also marred by improper business dealings.

headline: A Printer Meant to Produce Images That Last a Lifetime
abstract: Epson says its new printer, the Stylus Photo 1400, will produce prints that last 98 years.

headline: Salvadoran’s Death in Iraq Leaves His Mother Fuming
abstract: El Salvador is the only country in Latin America with troops in Iraq, despite extreme opposition from a war-weary population.

headline: 16 Civilians Die as U.S. Troops Fire on Afghan Road
abstract: American officials said the civilians were caught in cross-fire with militants, but witnesses and some Afghan officials said the troops shot indiscriminately.

headline: Time Inc. Lays Off Nearly 300
abstract: The cuts come as Time Inc. seeks to expand its presence on on the Web, where the company sees its future.

headline: U.S. Inquiry on Bonds at Big Bank
abstract: Bank of America said it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.

headline: Whole Foods Buys Smaller Rival
abstract: Whole Foods surprised investors by announcing a proposed merger with Wild Oats Markets, a similar though much smaller chain.

headline: Gordon Macklin, 78, Pioneer in Electronic Stock Trading, Dies
abstract: Gordon S. Macklin helped usher in the era of electronic trading of securities when he oversaw the development of the Nasdaq.

headline: What’s White, Fluffy and Isn’t Falling Yet?
abstract: New England’s fickle weather has been the subject of many jokes, and it seemed to be playing one last week on Yankee Magazine.

headline: Angry Dispute Erupts Among Iraqi Lawmakers
abstract: The prime minister’s presentation today of a new security plan  broke down in bitter sectarian recriminations.

headline: Hey, Boss, Permission for a Follow-Up Question?
abstract: Judging from a conference call by the News Corporation and NBC Universal, corporate control of the news media is still going strong.

headline: Showdown Looms in Congress Over Drug Advertising on TV
abstract: Drug advertising will face hard scrutiny in the new Congress as it considers the renewal of fees that manufacturers pay to speed reviews of new drugs.

headline: Push to Fix Ozone Layer and Slow Global Warming
abstract: A coalition of industrial and developing countries is pushing for stringent limits on a popular air-conditioner refrigerant.

headline: Rice Says Bush Authorized Iranians’ Arrest in Iraq
abstract: President Bush’s order appears to formalize the U.S. effort to contain Iran’s ambitions as a new front in the Iraq war.

headline: Google Makes Another Investment in the Internet in China
abstract: Google struck a deal to invest about $5 million in one of the country’s fastest-growing Internet start-ups, Xunlei.com.

headline: France: Government Opens U.F.O. Files
abstract: The National Center for Space Research opened its files on U.F.O.’s, putting them on a <a href=

headline: Two Members of Home Depot Board Will Not Stand for Re-Election
abstract: The board has been working to regain investors' trust after coming under fire for the sky-high compensation package paid to former chief executive Robert Nardelli.

headline: Canada: Bank Acquires New Jersey Money Manager
abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada agreed to buy a money manager J. B. Hanauer & Company of New Jersey, in its sixth acquisition in the United States in the last year. Details of the purchase, which is expected to be completed in May, were not disclosed, Royal Bank said. J. B. Hanauer, created in 1931, specializes in fixed-income and wealth management services. The company, based in Parsippany, has five offices in three states, with about 300 employees including 147 financial consultants, and almost $10 billion in assets under administration.

headline: New U.S. Commander in Iraq Won’t Rule Out Need for Added Troops
abstract: Gen. David H. Petraeus left open the possibility of calling in even more soldiers as he described the difficult task of calming the country.

headline: Correction: The Doctor Is In
abstract: An article last Sunday about the NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System referred incorrectly to the history of hospitals that was chronicled in “The Care of Strangers: The Rise of America’s Hospital System,” by Charles E. Rosenberg. The number of hospitals in the United States grew from only two in 1800, according to the book; there were not only two in the early 1900s. And a census of hospitals in 1909, not 1920, showed more than 4,300 hospitals housing more than 420,000 beds.

headline: Serbs Face Tough Choice as Kosovo Independence Looms
abstract: The estimated 120,000 Serbs left in the majority-Albanian province, many of them natives, are wondering whether to go or to stay.

headline: Again, Boeing Is Scrutinized on a Contract
abstract: A government decision that said the Air Force should reopen competition on a recent contract is a stunning reversal of fortune for Boeing.

headline: Japan’s Retooling Is Distinctly Japanese
abstract: What's up with Japan? China’s ascent has diverted attention from East Asia’s other formidable power.

headline: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Colombia: A Challenge to Banana Tariff
abstract: Colombia, the world’s third-biggest banana shipper, filed a new complaint with the World Trade Organization against European rules that it said discriminated against banana exports. The trade organization first ruled against Europe in September 1997, backing claims brought by Ecuador, the United States, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico almost two years earlier. The new request starts a fresh challenge to a tariff of 176 euros ($234) per metric ton.

headline: Intel Plans Faster Chips That Also Save Power
abstract: A new generation of chips would achieve a significant increase in performance without consuming more power.

headline: Hussein’s Former Vice President Is Hanged
abstract: He was the highest-ranking official from the former Iraq government to be executed after Saddam Hussein himself.

headline: Israel: Bomb Song Cleared
abstract: Israel’s entry for the annual Eurovision Song Contest, “Push the Button,” has been approved by the competition’s organizers, despite earlier suggestions that its lyrics were inappropriate. The song, by a band called the Teapacks, has been interpreted as a protest against Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

headline: Britain: BBC in Talks With YouTube
abstract: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

headline: Stricter Road Rules May Empty Ireland’s Pubs
abstract: Regular customers are staying at home, frightened by strict laws against drunken driving.

headline: It Takes More Than Veggies to Make a Kitchen Green
abstract: Restaurant owners are finding ways to handle the garbage and mess of a professional kitchen while reducing the effects on the environment.

headline: Indian Army and Police Tied to Kashmir Killings
abstract: A string of recent deaths has unearthed a deep well of resentment among the people of Indian-administered Kashmir.

headline: Negotiators Extend Deadline for South Korea Trade Pact
abstract: The deal, if successfully concluded, would quickly remove 85 percent to 90 percent of tariffs between the United States and South Korea.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 8 through Dec. 10 with 922 adults throughout the United States.

headline: South Korean Gets 5 Years for Dealings With Iraqis
abstract: Tongsun Park, a once flamboyant businessman, had been convicted of illegally representing Saddam Hussein in trying to influence the United Nations oil-for-food program.

headline: Inside Japan’s Puzzle Palace
abstract: If there is another puzzle craze after sudoku, chances are it will spring from a Japanese company called Nikoli.

headline: Guatemala: 4 Held in Killings of Salvadoran Politicians
abstract: Four suspected drug traffickers were arrested on charges that they helped orchestrate the killings of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver in Guatemala last month.

headline: More than 68,000 Displaced by Mozambique Floods
abstract: It was the worst flooding of the Zambezi River in Mozambique since a catastrophic 2001 flood.

headline: In Big Shift, U.S. Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Paper
abstract: Officials said the new policy could lead to duties on imports of Chinese steel, plastics, machinery and textiles.

headline: The C.E.O.’s Parachute Cost What?
abstract: Directors are waking up to the full cost, tax included, of executive exit packages.

headline: On Charging Batteries, Trusting Children and Washing Fruit
abstract: Who out there keeps track of how long a phone is left in its charger?

headline: Sweet Smell of Sidewalls
abstract: Ecsta DX tires are imbued with scented oils that make the rubber smell like lavender for a year.

headline: Court Rejects Tax Shelter Once Sold by KPMG
abstract: A federal judge ruled that a widely used aggressive tax shelter was based on fake bank loans and is therefore not legitimate.

headline: Bernanke Not Worried About Market Drop
abstract: The Fed chief said he saw little cause for alarm in either the previous day’s stock market plunge or new evidence of slowing economic growth.

headline: Indian College Quota Law Suspended
abstract: An incendiary law to expand caste-based college admissions quotas, which had set off months of protest last year, was temporarily suspended Thursday by the country’s highest court.

headline: Italy Swapped 5 Jailed Taliban for a Hostage
abstract: It appears to be the first time prisoners have been openly exchanged for a hostage in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: 2 Suitors for Tribune Co. Renew Their Interest
abstract: Tribune is said to have responded to a request for additional financial information from Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle.

headline: Finding a Way to Stay on the Go
abstract: A disability or injury doesn’t have to bring a traveler to a halt.

headline: Oil Innovations Pump New Life Into Old Wells
abstract: Technology has unlocked more oil from old fields, challenging forecasts that  reserves are drying out.

headline: Separatists Blamed for Attacks in Northern India
abstract: It was the worst violence in the region in years, and hundreds of workers were fleeing the area.

headline: Chechen Police Under Scrutiny in Journalist’s Killing, Group Says
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists said Russian prosecutors are investigating police involvement in the killing of a prominent Russian journalist.

headline: Search for Safe Haven Raises Bond Prices
abstract: Treasuries posted their biggest gains yesterday since December 2004 as a rout in global stocks and bonds bolstered demand for what is regarded as the safest debt.

headline: Senate Critique of Bush’s Iraq Plan Wins New Support
abstract: Two of the authors of a sterner resolution of disapproval said they would accept a compromise offered by Senator John Warner, a Republican.

headline: Britain: Letter Bomb Suspect Arrested
abstract: The police arrested a school janitor at a house in Cherry Hinton, near Cambridge, in connection with a series of letter bombings this year that wounded nine people. News reports identified the suspect as Miles Cooper, in his 20s. The seven bombs, in book-size padded envelopes containing explosives similar to powerful firecrackers, were delivered mainly in south and central England and south Wales. The targets seemed to be forensic research labs with ties to the police and offices associated with traffic rule enforcement.

headline: A.& P. Negotiating to Acquire Pathmark
abstract: Great Atlantic is offering Pathmark shareholders $12.50 a share in cash and stock if a deal is reached.

headline: Intel Says Chips Will Run Faster, Using Less Power
abstract: Intel has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for faster and more energy-efficient processors.

headline: A U.S. Alliance to Update the Light Bulb
abstract: A coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists is banding together to try to eliminate the incandescent light bulb in about 10 years.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
abstract: Microsoft says its purchase of Medstory is part of an effort to build a suite of tools and services related to health care.

headline: Consumers Have Allies on the Web
abstract: Consumer advocacy takes on renewed power as it moves into a new form, the blog.

headline: Indonesia to Resume Sending Flu Virus Samples to W.H.O.
abstract: As a result, the W.H.O. will be able to keep tracking the evolution of the virus there and designing vaccines against the latest mutant strains.

headline: Inquiry Faults Management at BP in Blast That Killed 15
abstract: A report painted a picture of recurring neglect and avoidance that culminated in a fatal explosion at a Texas refinery in 2005.

headline: An American University for Iraq but Not in Baghdad
abstract: The university, which would be built 150 miles north of Baghdad, raises hopes of stanching the country’s enormous brain drain.

headline: Chinese Leader to Visit Sudan for Talks on Darfur Conflict
abstract: President Hu Jintao’s visit to Sudan will be part of an eight-country tour of Africa, the latest of a string of high-level visits to the continent by Chinese officials.

headline: Iraqi Leaders Try to Show Progress on Problems
abstract: Iraqi leaders highlighted crackdowns on militias, progress on a national oil law, and new examples of reconciliation with former Baathists.

headline: Chávez Moves to Nationalize Two Industries
abstract: After swearing in his new cabinet, Venezuela’s leader announced the latest in a series of steps to transform the country to a socialist state.

headline: Trying to Make ‘Care’ Part of the Image of Hedge Funds
abstract: Hedge Funds Care is one in a growing number of charities that have arisen within the $1.3 trillion world of hedge funds.

headline: Canada: Environment Minister Loses Portfolio
abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper shuffled his cabinet in anticipation of a possible election this year. The main move was the removal of Rona Ambrose, left, as environment minister after months of condemnation. Clean air and climate change are likely to be major issues in the next national election, with the opposition Liberal Party now led by a former environment minister, Stéphane Dion. Ms. Ambrose was replaced by John Baird, who had been head of the Treasury Board. She is now intergovernmental affairs minister.

headline: Ethiopia Plans to Pull Troops From Somalia
abstract: The country, one of the poorest in the world, could not afford to keep its troops in Somalia, the leader said.

headline: State Farm to Pay $1 Million to Settle Gulf Claim
abstract: The settlement came a week after a jury ordered the insurer to pay $2.5 million in punitive damage to a homeowner with a similar case.

headline: Insurgents Shell Somali Airport as Peacekeeps Arrive
abstract: Insurgents shelled the airport where the peacekeepers had just landed, setting off explosive battles across the city that killed several civilians.

headline: Insurgents Attack Palace in Somalia
abstract: Insurgents blasted Somalia’s presidential palace with heavy explosives on Friday, but it appeared that no one was hurt.

headline: Revisiting Overstock.com and Utah
abstract: The crusade against “naked short selling” by Patrick M. Byrne, the head of Overstock.com, may be in the midst of a meltdown.

headline: After 15 Years, Someone’s in Charge in Somalia, if Barely
abstract: After Somalia’s Islamist forces abandoned their final outpost, the country’s transitional government moved aggressively to assert control.

headline: Bulletin! Washington Post Decides to Go for the Satirical
abstract: The Washington Post will sell local advertising for the humor weekly The Onion and print and distribute it in the Washington area.

headline: New Leader Is Appointed at McAfee
abstract: McAfee, the large maker of security software, appointed David DeWalt of the EMC Corporation as its chief executive.

headline: C. Harry Falk, Chief of New York Board of Trade, Dies at 66
abstract: C. Harry Falk became chairman of the exchange’s board in 2000 and helped guide it after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Symantec to Buy Software Tracker
abstract: Symantec, a maker of computer antivirus products, will buy Altiris for about $1.03 billion to gain programs that track corporate software use.

headline: Some More Numbers to Juggle in Figuring Out Retirement
abstract: A debate grows about the percentage of income to set aside for a retirement that includes drinks with umbrellas.

headline: Jobs Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
abstract: Apple’s chief said record companies should allow songs to be sold online without anticopying software, in part because the technology does not stop piracy.

headline: Whaling: A Japanese Obsession With American Roots
abstract: For Japan, whaling is intricately tied to the country’s relations with the West, especially the United States.

headline: Citizens’ Groups Take Root Across China
abstract: In 15 years, China has gone from having virtually no independent groups of any kind to more than 300,000 nongovernmental organizations, by official count. But that understates the true number.

headline: The Computer With a TV, and a Family's Virtual Bulletin Board
abstract: The notion of a computer at the heart of every home gets a little bump with the multitasking Hewlett-Packard's $1,800 TouchSmart PC.

headline: Environmental Group Behind the TXU Deal Hires a Banker
abstract: Environmental Defense has hired Perella Weinberg Partners to advise it, possibly signaling that it wants an even more powerful seat at the bargaining table with TXU.

headline: Charges of Vote Rigging as Egypt Approves Constitution Changes
abstract: The disputed measures empower the Egyptian president to dissolve Parliament, to suspend civil protections and to limit judges’ oversight of elections.

headline: After Setbacks, BP May Be Forced to Give Up Some Control of Joint Venture in Russia
abstract: A landmark deal to open Russia’s natural resources for development will most likely be scaled back, as the government tightens controls.

headline: Mexico Sends 4 Kingpins to Face Trial in the U.S.
abstract: The m0ve was a signal that the newly elected president, Felipe Calderón, is serious about cooperating with the U.S. to dismantle drug cartels.

headline: Online Sellers Discover the Power of Video Clips
abstract: Online retailers have begun capitalizing on the YouTube craze, offering a video platform for product demonstrations, rants and raves, and just plain bizarre behavior.

headline: The Biggest Buyout Ever Could Have Been Bigger
abstract: Is Samuel Zell the hero in the epic battle for Equity Office Properties?

headline: Village May Have Housed Builders of Stonehenge
abstract: New excavations near Stonehenge have uncovered what archaeologists say was probably the village of workers who erected the monoliths on Salisbury Plain in England.

headline: Japan: Key Indicator Improved in January
abstract: Japan’s machinery orders rose in January, the most in five months, signaling that capital spending will keep fueling the economy. Nongovernment machinery orders, excluding shipping and utilities, rose a seasonally adjusted 3.9 percent, to 1.09 trillion yen ($9.4 billion), from December, when they fell 0.7 percent, according to a Cabinet Office report.

headline: Putin Seeks Expanded Ties With Saudis on Arab Tour
abstract: The Russian president’s overnight visit was part of a three-day tour of the Middle East intended to bolster bilateral ties with major Arab countries.

headline: U.S. Moves Against Iranian Bank for Weapons Ties
abstract: The Treasury Department today said a major Iranian bank had been involved in illicit weapons programs.

headline: Wal-Mart Chooses New Ad Agencies
abstract: The announcement came five weeks after Wal-Mart overturned decisions made by senior marketing executives to hire the Draft FCB Group as the lead agency to create ads.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Thai Army Officers Held in Bombings
abstract: Sources said police and soldiers had searched locations in and around the capital and detained eight military officers and seven civilians.

headline: International Court Names Darfur War Suspects
abstract: The chief prosecutor today presented evidence against a former Sudanese minister and a janjaweed militia leader.

headline: Bush Seeks Iraq War Funds ‘With No Strings’
abstract: President Bush also defended his decision to send more than 8,000 more troops to Iraq and Afghanistan, saying they would be dedicated to training and support missions.

headline: Deciding Eligibility for Oscar
abstract: There has been a rise in skirmishes over who has the right to walk up and accept an Academy Award as a named producer.

headline: In Live Bacteria, Food Makers See a Bonanza
abstract: More food makers are scrambling to offer products with special live microbes that boast health benefits.

headline: Amazon and TiVo in Venture to Put Downloaded Videos on TV
abstract: The companies will allow TiVo owners who shop on Amazon’s digital download store to send films and TV shows to their broadband-connected TiVo machines.

headline: 10 Sites That Pay for Your Video
abstract: That vacation video from Hawaii may be a long shot to surpass “Titanic” as a moneymaker, but a number of Web sites now offer ways for individuals to earn a return from the video content they produce. Here are some of the sites that generate revenue from advertising, rentals or paid downloads, and then split it with the creator.

headline: Arabs and U.N. Chief Press Sudan’s Leader to End Darfur Crisis
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said a meeting between Sudan’s president and Arab leaders had resulted in “progress.”

headline: Iran to Take Part in Iraq Security Conference
abstract: The conference next month would include the first high-level diplomatic contacts between American and Iranian officials in more than two years.

headline: U.S. News & World Report Editor Resigns
abstract: Brian Duffy has left the magazine to write a book and his job responsibilities have been given to his No. 2, Brian Kelly.

headline: Israel Fires Into Gaza, Responding to Rocket Attack
abstract: This is the first time that Israel has responded to rocket attacks since a shaky cease-fire came into effect in November.

headline: Who’s Attacking an Online Marxist Archive? China Is Suspected of Trying to Block Access to Texts
abstract: An online Marxist library says computer attacks from China may force the library to stop providing material in Chinese.

headline: New York Investor Plans to Buy Air America
abstract: The liberal radio network said today that it had reached a tentative agreement with the chairman of a real estate investment trust.

headline: Russian Ex-Diplomat Guilty in Bribe Case
abstract: Vladimir Kuznetsov, a former Russian diplomat who once headed the United Nations budget oversight committee, was convicted by a federal jury in Manhattan of having conspired with a United Nations purchasing officer to obtain $300,000 in illicit payments from foreign companies seeking contracts. He was found guilty of setting up an offshore company and opening up a bank account in Antigua to launder money received from the officer, Alexander Yakovlev, who has admitted receiving nearly $1 million in bribes from United Nations contractors. He testified against Mr. Kuznetsov.

headline: Countering the Big-Bank Trend
abstract: Community banks keep financing flowing to local entrepreneurs at a time when mergers have reduced the number of banks.

headline: China to Open Fund to Invest Currency Reserves
abstract: With up to $1 trillion of reserves to work with, the agency could become one of the world’s biggest investment funds.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: PAULSON IN ASIA Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., below, will head to Asia this week, stopping in Japan on Monday, South Korea on Tuesday, Beijing on Wednesday and Shanghai on Thursday. The trip will include meetings with the Japanese finance minister and the governor of the Bank of Japan, and discussions about the weakness of the yen. Discussions in China will also include currency issues; Mr. Paulson has urged Chinese officials to move toward a more flexible exchange rate on the yuan. In Shanghai, Mr. Paulson is scheduled to deliver a speech on reform in Chinese financial markets.

headline: Some Investors Skeptical of a Chrysler-GM Deal
abstract: DaimlerChrysler’s willingness to cut loose its Chrysler Group is drawing cheers from investors but Wall Street analysts were skeptical of an outright sale of Chrysler to G.M.

headline: Violence in Somalia Over Disarmament
abstract: Hundreds of Somalis stormed into the streets of Mogadishu, further destabilizing the already unsteady city.

headline: Czech Republic: Vote Ends Stalemate
abstract: Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek’s newly appointed coalition cabinet narrowly won a critical vote of confidence, ending a political stalemate that had left the country without an active government since elections last June. Those elections left the 200-seat Parliament evenly divided between rival coalitions. The deadlock was broken when two legislators from Mr. Topolanek’s opposition broke ranks and backed his cabinet in the vote. But Mr. Topolanek warned that the political crisis might not be over if the continued partisan split made it impossible for the new government to act effectively.

headline: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo predicted only modest improvements for this year, suggesting that it would continue to struggle to keep up with Google.

headline: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports
abstract: Shareholders who thought that a quick glance at the summary compensation table would tell them all they needed to know have another thing coming.

headline: House Passes Iraq Resolution With 17 Votes From G.O.P.
abstract: The House voted 246 to 182 today to denounce President Bush’s plan to send more American troops to Iraq. Two Democrats voted against the non-binding resolution.

headline: Stockman Is Charged With Fraud
abstract: The former budget director for President Ronald Reagan was indicted on charges that he covered up the dire financial state at Collins & Aikman, the auto parts supplier he ran.

headline: With Cameras, Compromising Can Pay Off
abstract: Midsize digital cameras can offer features you generally don’t get with S.L.R.’s, like a movie-capture mode and a “live” back-panel screen, at a price often under $350.

headline: Chávez Shares Some Airtime With Castro
abstract: Cuban President Fidel Castro chatted with Hugo Chávez during the Venezuelan leader’s nightly live radio program.

headline: Korean Men Use Brokers to Find Brides in Vietnam
abstract: Many South Korean men are traveling abroad to pick wives and hold weddings in a matter of days.

headline: In a Shaky Economy, a Laggard May Find Its Legs
abstract: Why are many strategists convinced that this time around — despite last week’s stock market rally — investors are nearly done with risk taking?

headline: Iran Leader Calls Nuclear Sanctions Ineffective
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said his nation was becoming a superpower and that U.N. sanctions would not deter it from pursuing its nuclear program.

headline: Distributor of Medical Test to Buy a Rival
abstract: Beckman Coulter will acquire Biosite, a smaller maker of diagnostic blood tests, for about $1.55 billion.

headline: Hangings Fuel Sectarian Split Across Mideast
abstract: A pan-Muslim unity from the war between Israel and Hezbollah is waning and Sunni-Shiite tension is rising after the executions of  Saddam Hussein and two lieutenants in Iraq.

headline: 3 Parties Jostle Before Meeting in Jerusalem
abstract: A much anticipated meeting of Israelis, Palestinians and Americans on Monday seems likely to be overtaken by battles over a new Palestinian unity government.

headline: Agency That Harbored ‘Saatchi 17’ to Close
abstract: Agency That Harbored ‘Saatchi 17’ to Close.

headline: Britain to Trim Iraq Force by 1,600 in Coming Months
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair’s announcement of a withdrawal in southern Iraq was in sharp contrast to the continuing American troop buildup in Baghdad.

headline: Mortar Hits Baghdad School, Killing 5 Girls
abstract: The attack, in the Adel neighborhood, was the latest in a series of assaults on schools and those who educate the young.

headline: Utility and Sierra Club Deal Aims to Cut Carbon Dioxide
abstract: Kansas City Power and Light and the Sierra Club announced a deal on Monday under which the utility will take steps to cut carbon dioxide output.

headline: Another Group May Bid for Spanish Utility
abstract: The Italian utility Enel and the Spanish construction conglomerate Acciona said they were working on a bid for the Spanish utility Endesa.

headline: Pakistani Premier Faults Afghans for Taliban Woes on Border
abstract: Pakistan’s prime minister said the root of the problem was the Afghan government’s weak authority, not Pakistani support of the Taliban.

headline: Vodafone Said to Win Battle for Indian Phone Company
abstract: The deal for Hutchinson Essar, one of India’s fastest growing telecommunications companies, values the company at around $19 billion.

headline: Australian Muslims Go for Surf, Lifesaving and Burqinis
abstract: A beach program for Australia’s Muslims is challenging the perception of the blond, blue-eyed and sun-bronzed lifeguard.

headline: Canadian Rail Workers End Their Strike
abstract: The Canadian National Railway’s striking employees returned to work, a day after their union reached a tentative settlement for a new labor contract.

headline: Canada: Manslaughter Charge in Afghanistan Case
abstract: A soldier was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a fellow soldier in Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Jeffrey Walsh was killed Aug. 9 when a gun discharged during a patrol outside Kandahar in southern Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Robbie Fraser was charged with one count of manslaughter in the case and one count of negligent performance of duty. Master Corporal Fraser has returned to his base in Shilo, Manitoba. Both were in Afghanistan as members of the Princess Patricia’s Canadian Light Infantry.

headline: Tunisia Says Suspects in Gun Battle Had Blueprints of Embassies
abstract: The Tunisian interior minister said Islamic extremists had documents identifying foreign targets.

headline: G.E. Says Profit Rose 11%, but Its Shares Still Fall
abstract: Investor discomfort with the quality of earnings and with accounting issues sent shares down.

headline: Lebanese Army Tightens Security at Camp to Press Militant Group
abstract: The Lebanese Army maintained a heavy presence on Monday in a Palestinian refugee camp where an Islamic militant group is based.

headline: Israel Arrests 18 in Crackdown
abstract: The raid on a Palestinian Authority building near Ramallah appears to be part of a growing crackdown.

headline: 50 Protesters in Zimbabwe Are Set Free Without Charges
abstract: An unknown number remain hospitalized after riot police set upon a group at a prayer meeting on Sunday.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Dismissal of Abuse Suit
abstract: A German citizen who says he was kidnapped and abused by the Central Intelligence Agency cannot seek redress in court because his lawsuit would expose state secrets, a United States Court of Appeals ruled on Friday.

headline: Fed Weighs Words About Its Next Move
abstract: The Federal Reserve stopped using words that suggest the next move for interest rates will be upward.

headline: Of Tax Cuts and Those $10 Million Bat Mitzvahs
abstract: We’re in a war that the government cannot afford to pay, but the society at home is routinely having million-dollar bar mitzvahs?

headline: Switzerland: Bank Plans a Share Buyback
abstract: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, will use proceeds from the sale of its Winterthur insurance unit to buy back a record amount of stock and make money-management acquisitions. The bank plans to repurchase as much as 8 billion francs ($6.4 billion) of shares over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion francs for possible takeovers in the United States, the Middle East and Asia. “We have the requisite resources to grow our business, while at the same time returning capital to our shareholders,” the chief executive, Oswald J. Grübel, told investors in Zurich. Credit Suisse completed the sale of Winterthur to Axa of France for 12.3 billion francs last month.

headline: One Number That Will Ring All Your Phones
abstract: A new service called GrandCentral can unify your cellphone with phones at work and home and perform many other tricks.

headline: Vatican and China Open Talks on Improving Ties
abstract: A dispute over the right to appoint bishops has soured relations between the church and China.

headline: Vow at Citigroup to Fill Post Soon
abstract: The chief executive of Citigroup said he expected to name a successor quickly to Sallie L. Krawcheck as Citigroup’s finance chief.

headline: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million
abstract: EBay agreed to buy the online ticket reseller for $310 million to bolster its share in secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

headline: Bomb at Iraqi Mosque Kills 36 After Sunni Imam Condemns Militants
abstract: The blast near a Sunni mosque was unusual in that such bombings are usually directed at Iraqi police, or at Shiite sites or mixed neighborhoods.

headline: State Farm Ends New Property Coverage in Mississippi
abstract: State Farm, the largest insurer in the state, is facing hundreds of lawsuits over claims from Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

headline: Time Change a ‘Mini-Y2K’ in Tech Terms
abstract: Companies are scrambling to reset computing devices as daylight saving time begins three weeks earlier.

headline: China Media Battle Hints at Shift on Intellectual Property
abstract: A copyright lawsuit by one of China’s largest newspapers is setting off a media war that may shift policies toward intellectual property rights.

headline: New Crop of Books on the Evils of Wall Street Misses Old Standards
abstract: A new crop of books about Wall Street aims to capture, if not update, the rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.
