K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: How I Spent My Summer Vacation: Now a Major Motionless Book
abstract: Evaluating the ease and convenience of using Web photo sites to send, store and print photographs.

headline: An Endgame in Zimbabwe That Mugabe May Yet Win
abstract: Despite deep dissatisfaction with his rule, President Robert G. Mugabe seems poised to maintain his grip on the country he has ruled for 27 years.

headline: Can’t Tell Your Cokes Apart? Sue Someone
abstract: Coke Zero is being promoted with an unusual campaign about company executives suing each other.

headline: Leader of Far Right in France Joins (and Jolts) Race for Presidency
abstract: Jean-Marie Le Pen, whose candidacy shook up France in 2002, officially joined France’s already volatile race for president.

headline: As the Climate Heats Up, Lawyers Sharpen Their Wits
abstract: Emission-management tools pose the kinds of questions that the legal community eats up.

headline: Clear Channel Postpones Vote on Sale
abstract: Clear Channel Communications, the largest United States radio broadcaster, postponed a shareholder vote on its $19 billion sale by a month yesterday to improve the deal’s chances for approval.

headline: Olympic Construction Unearths Ancient Treasure Trove
abstract: Archaeologists have recovered more than 1,000 artifacts at sites being prepared for the 2008 Olympics, but elsewhere in China, they are often in a losing race against bulldozers.

headline: Bidding War for Roofing Products Maker Is Over
abstract: ElkCorp said that it planned to accept a bid for the company from Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group.

headline: Britain: Terrorism Suspect on the Run
abstract: The government said a terrorism suspect had absconded after being served with what is known as a control order, a form of house arrest that would require him to report daily to the police, surrender his travel documents and reside at an address known to the authorities. The man was not identified by name, but John Reid, the home secretary, said he “had recently been radicalized and wanted to travel abroad for terrorism-related purposes.” Mr. Reid said the man was not seen as “a direct threat to the public in the United Kingdom.”.

headline: Bomb Explodes Near U.N. Chief in Baghdad
abstract: Seconds before the mortar struck, the U.N. secretary general had been discussing security improvements in Iraq during a news conference.

headline: Applebee’s Explores a Sale of the Company
abstract: Applebee’s International, the operator of almost 2,000 restaurants, mainly in North America, said yesterday it might sell the company after its third-biggest shareholder accused management of failing to increase sales and cut costs.

headline: Britain: Police Send Poisoning Case to Prosecutors
abstract: The British police handed their findings in the poisoning death of a former K.G.B. agent to the Crown Prosecution Service, which will determine whether suspects should be charged.

headline: Seeing Future of Britain, and Blair, in the Snow
abstract: Some question whether Tony Blair will find a niche to enable him to return to Davos in the future in something resembling the post-political mode of Bill Clinton.

headline: Assault of the Hackers
abstract: Internet security can be expensive, but it can also be worth the price.

headline: In Europe and Elsewhere, Bush’s New War Strategy Is Greeted With Skepticism
abstract: President’s Bush’s new strategy has won few converts across a worried world, where dismay and hostility have grown.

headline: Inflation Slowed in December
abstract: But inflation at the wholesale level was still fast enough to be a potential worry for Wall Street and policymakers at the Federal Reserve.

headline: The Hard Drive as Eye Candy
abstract: Once relegated to a back shelf in the electronics store, external units will soon don brushed aluminum cases, decorator colors and glowing lights.

headline: It’s ‘Squawk Box’ Meets ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: The popularity of the Wallstrip Web site is only the latest sign of the growing use of video on financial Web sites.

headline: For the Well-Dressed iPod, a Leather Jacket in the Color of Your Choice
abstract: Rooting for Manchester United or the Giants to win? Get an iPod case in your team colors.

headline: Religious Surge in Once-Atheist China Surprises Leaders
abstract: Chinese experts say the growing popularity of religious belief has been driven by social crises involving corruption and the expanding gap between rich and poor.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 3 Islamic Militants in West Bank and Re-enter Nablus
abstract: Israel has been stepping up its operations in the northern West Bank, a center of Palestinian militancy throughout the past six years of violence.

headline: Want to Get Some Work Done? Wait Till April
abstract: Warning to employers: this might not be the best time to assign a big, complicated project.

headline: Russia: Bribe-Taking Inquiry of Traffic Police
abstract: The prosecutor general’s office announced a nationwide investigation of the country’s notoriously, often brazenly, corrupt traffic police.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
abstract: Plenty of newcomers — with names like hakia and Snap — are trying to beat Google at its own game.

headline: Most Viewed Business Articles of 2006
abstract: 1) Colliding With Death at 37,000 Feet, and Living

headline: The Toast of MySpace Tries the Music Business
abstract: Tila Tequila became famous for having the most friends on MySpace.com. Now she’s hoping to translate her fame into a music career.

headline: A Wake-Up Call to Microsoft's PR Team
abstract: Bribing bloggers, fabricating reviews and making up letters to the editor makes the company look worse, not better.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Resume Trade Talks
abstract: Trade experts say that while there is increasing skepticism that the agreement can be completed before President Bush’s “fast track” authority expires.

headline: Bush Administration, Under Criticism, Warns Iraq to Fulfill Its End of the Bargain
abstract: Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki must deliver on promises to quell violence, senior administration officials have said in recent interviews.

headline: The Future of Leisure That Never Arrived
abstract: Though the average hours at work have decreased in the last century, it doesn’t necessarily follow that leisure has increased.

headline: Israeli Leader Faces Inquiry Over Bank Sale
abstract: An Israeli prosecutor will investigate whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert tried to improperly influence the privatization of a bank.

headline: At $45 Billion, New Contender for Top Buyout
abstract: A group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group is near a deal to acquire the TXU Corporation.

headline: First Offering of a Hedge Fund Is Bid Up 67% on Opening Day
abstract: Investors stormed Fortress Investment Group, driving its shares up 67.6 percent in the first U.S. market debut of a hedge fund manager.

headline: Hershey Earnings Decline as Mars Cuts Into U.S. Market Share
abstract: Fourth-quarter profit fell 9.9 percent after sales declined for the first time in three and a half years.

headline: Canada: Profit Down at Auto Parts Maker
abstract: Magna International, the Canadian auto parts maker, said that fourth-quarter profit fell 65 percent because of lower profit margins and one-time charges. It cut its quarterly dividend to increase cash on hand. Net income was $29 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $83 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier, Magna said. Sales rose 8.7 percent, to $6.4 billion. The company, cut its quarterly divided in half, to 19 cents a share, adding $84 million in cash to the $1.9 billion the company had on hand at the end of 2006. Excluding one-time items, Magna earned 99 cents a share, missing the $1.16 a share that was expected by Wall Street analysts.

headline: NATO Calls Antimissile Worries Unfounded
abstract: Gen. John Craddock of the United States Army, who recently took over as the NATO supreme allied commander in Europe, said Russia had nothing to fear from a planned antimissile system that the United States wants to install in Poland and the Czech Republic. “It’s been clearly stated what the U.S. intention is,” he said, “and that is to provide defense against missiles from a rogue nation.” Although he did not name any country, the antimissile site would be designed to stop attacks by Iran against the United States and its European allies. Last weekend, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reacted angrily to the plan to install a missile defense system in former Soviet Bloc countries, saying it would set off a new arms race. On Thursday, Gen. Yuri N. Baluyevsky, the chief of the Russian military’s general staff, said that if the United States went through with the system, Russia might drop out of the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty of 1987, in which the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to eliminate land-based ballistic and cruise nuclear missiles with a range of 310 to 3,410 miles.

headline: Anemia Drugs Under Review by Congress
abstract: A House panel began an inquiry into the marketing and regulation of widely used anemia drugs that have raised safety concerns.

headline: Calm Prevails at Holy Site in Jerusalem
abstract: Despite calls by Muslim religious figures for mass protests, Jerusalem’s Old City was largely calm on Friday.

headline: Palestinian Government Is Approved
abstract: Cracks were immediately apparent in the new national unity government ratified in the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Dollar Still Almighty, for Now
abstract: The role of the dollar in international trade and finance — the real sign that New York is the world’s financial capital — is still taken for granted.

headline: Two Top Executives to Leave Discovery Communications
abstract: Leaders of Discovery’s cable channels will now report to the chief executive, giving him a more hands-on role.

headline: Keeping Up With Tiger Woods by Swinging a Remote
abstract: A golf game that it just like playing the real thing, aches and pains included.

headline: The Swimsuits Were Skimpy, but the Magazine Was Invisible
abstract: A Sports Illustrated spokesman has confirmed that the swimsuit issue was withheld from about 21,000 subscribers identified as “libraries or classrooms.”

headline: When to Violate the Top Two Commandments of Antigovernment Crusaders
abstract: Antigovernment crusaders are often the biggest obstacles to the achievement of economic efficiency.

headline: Northern Ireland Rivals Reach Deal
abstract: Sinn Fein’s Gerry Adams and the Protestant leader Rev. Ian Paisley held face-to-face negotiations.

headline: Somali Government Compound Hit by Grenade
abstract: The attack was yet another sign of a growing insurgency as security seems to be unraveling across the country.

headline: Neighbor Leaves Singapore Short of Sand
abstract: Singapore’s government is being forced to tap its sand hoard after Indonesia banned sand exports, the latest in a string of disputes between the country and its neighbors.

headline: Vocal Minority Wants the Stock Tables Back
abstract: The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal are restoring some stock market tables that were trimmed to reduce costs.

headline: Iran Cites ‘Aggression’ in Case of Captured British Personnel
abstract: Britain demanded “the immediate and safe return” of 15 naval personnel seized Friday near disputed waters.

headline: Ecuador: Court Renews Power Struggle
abstract: Congress was in turmoil after Jorge Cevallos, its elected leader, moved to void an effort to expel 57 opposition legislators for trying to block President Rafael Correa’s plan to rewrite the Constitution to make it harder for Congress to topple presidents.

headline: American Takes Over Command of NATO Force in Afghanistan
abstract: The force is still struggling to contain the Taliban, which mounted a strong comeback last year.

headline: Lebanon Revokes Visa of Israeli Journalist
abstract: The Washington-based Israeli journalist was traveling with the U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on his current Middle East tour.

headline: Attacks Across Iraq Kill at Least 109 Shiite Pilgrims
abstract: The attacks demonstrated that Sunni militants could still wreak grave damage inside or outside Baghdad.

headline: Cuba: 2 Foreign Reporters Ousted
abstract: Cuba effectively silenced foreign correspondents from The Chicago Tribune and the Mexican newspaper El Universal this week, denying them new press credentials and journalist visas. The Universal reporter, César González-Calero, was told yesterday that he must cease writing about Cuba because his coverage was not good for the government, the newspaper reported. On Wednesday, officials told Gary Marx of The Tribune that his credentials would not be renewed because the government was not pleased with his work, said George de Lama, the managing editor for news. Four other foreign news organizations — the BBC, Agence France-Presse, Reuters and El País — have yet to be told if they will be accredited again, journalists on the island said.

headline: Turkey: Prosecutors Open Investigation Into Prime Minister
abstract: Prosecutors in Ankara are investigating whether Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan once referred to Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader, by the honorific “Sayin,” or esteemed, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Praising a criminal or criminal organization in Turkey is itself a crime. According to reports, Mr. Erdogan referred to Mr. Ocalan by the honorific in an Australian radio interview in 2000.

headline: Trade Deficit Peaks and Declines, but It Remains Huge
abstract: After years of deterioration, the United States trade deficit appears to have finally peaked and started to decline.

headline: Israeli Panel on Lebanon War Lays Onus With Top Officials
abstract: The panel’s report heightens uncertainty about the future of the beleaguered prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and his government.

headline: Cheney Assails Those Favoring Iraq Drawdown
abstract: The vice president said today that lawmakers who pursue a withdrawal of forces are “undermining” the troops.

headline: Israeli Raid Overshadows Meeting in Egypt
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt called the Israeli raid in the West Bank a hindrance to the peace talks.

headline: France: French Doctor to Lead Global Disease Fund
abstract: Dr. Michel Kazatchkine, the top official in France’s battle against AIDS, was chosen as the new chief of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, the organization announced in Geneva. He succeeds Dr. Richard G. A. Feachem. The fund has disbursed $3.4 billion since 2001, provided AIDS treatment to more than 500,000 people in 127 countries and handed out 11 million mosquito nets to fight malaria. Dr. Kazatchkine has treated people with AIDS for more than 20 years.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Top U.S. General in Iraq Says New Plan to Pacify Baghdad May Take Months to Show Results
abstract: Gen. George W. Casey Jr. played down reports of tension between the American military and the Iraqi government.

headline: Iraqis Answer Global Critics by Tackling Troubling Issues
abstract: Iraqi leaders highlighted crackdowns on militias, progress on a national oil law and new examples of reconciliation with former Baathists.

headline: Thousands Flee as Sri Lankan Forces Strike at Rebels
abstract: The military started a fresh offensive to capture rebel-held areas in eastern Sri Lanka.

headline: Russia: Chechen Blames Moscow for Torture
abstract: Ramzan Kadyrov, the new president of the restive southern region of Chechnya, condemned what he acknowledged was systemic torture but sought to shift the blame to federal security officers, not local Chechen ones. His remarks came three days after the Council of Europe reported finding significant evidence of illegal detentions and torture of suspects in Chechnya, and accused Russian officials of ignoring the problem. The report noted that many of the accusations of abuse are leveled at Chechen forces loyal to Mr. Kadyrov. His remarks also underscored the tensions between Chechen and Russian officials, despite President Vladimir V. Putin’s open support of Mr. Kadyrov.

headline: Deadliest Bomb in Iraq Is Made by Iran, U.S. Says
abstract: The assertion of an Iranian role in supplying the device to Shiite militias reflects broad agreement among American intelligence agencies.

headline: Microsoft Agrees to Buy Maker of Voice-Recognition Software
abstract: The deal to buy Tellme Networks was said to be worth more than $800 million, making it Microsoft’s biggest acquisition since 2002.

headline: Mystery Arises Over Identity of Militia Chief in Najaf Fight
abstract: Iraqi officials declared that the leader of a militia that battled American and Iraqi troops last weekend was a Sunni militant who took control of the militia by masquerading as a Shiite.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: FIRST VERY LIGHT JET DELIVERED In what some aviation industry officials believe is the dawn of a new era in aviation, the first so-called very light jet, an Eclipse 500, was delivered to a customer on Sunday by Eclipse Aviation, based in Albuquerque.

headline: A Titan of Private Equity May Go Public
abstract: The Blackstone Group is preparing for an initial public offering that could value the firm at more than $30 billion.

headline: Offline Options for Backup
abstract: What are the alternatives for backing up a computer’s data if you don’t want to use an online service?

headline: Powered by Toys: The Story Continues
abstract: A company that snagged a lucrative toy-licensing agreement early on in its history has now established itself as a significant force.

headline: Cerberus Is Weighing a $38 Billion Offer for an Office REIT
abstract: If Cerberus bids for Equity Office, it would seek to top a deal reached last year to sell the company to the Blackstone Group for $36 billion.

headline: Strong Earnings Have Stocks Sizzling
abstract: The stock market turned in its best performance in months last week, with all three major indexes posting substantial gains.

headline: The Netherlands, the New Tax Shelter Hot Spot
abstract: Forget the Cayman Islands. The new hot spot for tax shelters is the Netherlands, which has drawn assets from the Rolling Stones, U2 and Sun Microsystems.

headline: Japan: Nikko Shareholder Says Bid Is Too Low
abstract: The largest shareholder in the Nikko Cordial Corporation has rejected a $10.8 billion takeover offer from Citigroup, saying that the price is too low. The shareholder, Harris Associates of Chicago, which manages money for individual and institutional investors, believes that Nikko is worth more than 2,000 yen a share, the chief investment officer, David G. Herro, said. The offer made by Citigroup was for 1,350 yen. The share price of Nikko, which is based in Tokyo, advanced 14 percent before the Citigroup offer was announced on Tuesday and it rose another 1.3 percent yesterday, closing at 1,357 yen a share. Harris owns about 7.5 percent of Nikko.

headline: Hedge Fund Is Charged Over Trades
abstract: Beacon Rock Capital has been charged with defrauding mutual funds of $2.4 million, the United States attorney in Philadelphia said.

headline: Homeowner Stares Down Wreckers, at Least for a While
abstract: One woman’s ability to hold out against the forces of large-scale development has drawn attention across China.

headline: A Political Flavor (Waffles Included)
abstract: Stephen Colbert, whose television persona opposes virtually everything that the founders of Ben & Jerry’s ice cream stand for, has his very own flavor.

headline: Borrowing Rose in November
abstract: The increase was the most in three months as Americans loaded up on credit card debt to purchase holiday gifts.

headline: Buying Into the Company, Not the Commodity
abstract: There is an easy way to get a shot at commodity-like returns, without investing directly in commodities or their indexes.

headline: Kenya Closes Border but Denies Turning Back Refugees
abstract: With the final throes of the conflict in Somalia on their doorstep, Kenyan officials said they had no choice but to close the border.

headline: Correction: When Buying a Diamond Starts With a Mouse
abstract: An article last Sunday about Blue Nile, an online diamond jewelry company, referred incorrectly to its relative standing among companies that sell the most diamond rings in the United States each year. Although jewelers do not provide comparable statistics about diamond-ring sales, Blue Nile does indeed rank behind Tiffany & Company. It also ranks behind at least one other competitor, the Signet Group, which operates Kay Jewelers.

headline: Beijing Orders Investigation of Health Agency
abstract: The government is concerned about a growing number of cases that involve the sale of fraudulent or dangerous medicine.

headline: AIDS Advocate Under House Arrest in China
abstract: The arrest prevented her from traveling to an awards ceremony in the United States held by a nonprofit group connected to Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: A New Cable to Connect
abstract: What is a high-definition multimedia interface?

headline: When Budgets Loom, It’s Time to Rent a C.F.O.
abstract: Nonprofits and private and public businesses of all sizes are turning to temporary finance chiefs.

headline: The Route From Research to Start-Up
abstract: Many universities now have offices of technology transfer looking to turn research into commercial ventures.

headline: Marsh & McLennan to Sell Putnam Funds to Canadian Group
abstract: The sale of Putnam Investments to the Power Corporation of Canada will allow Power to establish a foothold in the U.S. mutual fund business.

headline: Canada: Agloma Steel and German Suitor Part Ways
abstract: Algoma Steel said it had failed to reach agreement on a takeover by Salzgitter of Germany and had scheduled preliminary discussions with other potential buyers. Algoma said in mid-February that it might be acquired by Salzgitter at a price lower than where the company’s shares were trading at the time. Algoma negotiated with potential buyers in 2005 and renewed negotiations in February 2006 without reaching an agreement.

headline: In a Test of Capturing Carbon Dioxide, Perhaps a Way to Temper Global Warming
abstract: American Electric Power is planning the largest demonstration yet of capturing carbon dioxide from a coal-fired power plant and pumping it deep underground.

headline: Anywhere the Eye Can See, It’s Likely to See an Ad
abstract: Advertisers say the best way to reach time-pressed consumers is to try to catch their eye at  every turn.

headline: Will Other Mortgage Dominoes Fall?
abstract: It’s amazing how long it can take investors to see that the wheels are coming off a prized investment vehicle. Denial, after all, is a powerful thing.

headline: Gains in Wireless Customers Help Lift AT&T’s Earnings 17%
abstract: AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

headline: Europe Compromises With Automakers on Carbon Limits
abstract: The European Commission is expected to endorse a watered-down blueprint that would impose a limit on carbon dioxide emissions from new passenger cars.

headline: Stocks With Only One Direction to Go
abstract: Getting the word out, from deep in the bargain basement.

headline: Zimbabwe Opposition Groups Say Leaders Beaten
abstract: The groups said their leaders had been beaten and hospitalized after the police arrested them during the violent breakup of an antigovernment rally.

headline: Martial Law Declared in Guinea
abstract: The move came after labor unions vowed to resume a general strike on Monday, demanding that President Lansana Conté step down.

headline: Israel’s President to Be Indicted in Rape Case
abstract: Israel’s attorney general plans to indict President Moshe Katsav on charges of rape and other sexual offenses.

abstract: President Moshe Katsav faces criminal charges including rape, abuse of power, obstruction of justice and fraud.

headline: U.S. Discusses Releasing North Korean Funds
abstract: China and the United States are close to an accord to let North Korea regain some of the $25 million frozen in a bank in Macao.

headline: Wal-Mart Fights Back Over Firings
abstract: Wal-Mart filed a legal brief on Monday directly contradicting the statements of two former marketing officials who were fired late last year.

headline: Iraq Moves to Ease Restraints on Baath Party Members
abstract: Officials plan to introduce modifications to a law that restricts former Baathists  from holding government jobs.

headline: Iran Protests ‘Aggression’ in Case of Seized Britons
abstract: Britain demanded “the immediate and safe return” of 15 naval personnel seized yesterday near disputed waters.

headline: Greek Terror Group Claims It Bombed Embassy
abstract: The group, Revolutionary Struggle, claimed responsibility for the attack on the U.S. embassy in Athens two weeks ago.

headline: Australian Utility Giant Gets Buyout Offer From Managers
abstract: Alinta Ltd. has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank Ltd. in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout.

headline: Olmert Rejects Right of Return for Palestinians
abstract: The Israeli prime minister said that he could not accept the return of even a single Palestinian refugee to Israel.

headline: 3 at Florida-Based Hedge Fund Accused of Misleading Investors
abstract: The three principals of the KL Group were accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors.

headline: Northern Ireland: Blair Cuts Vacation for Talks
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair cut short a vacation in Miami and returned to London a day early as a new escalation of political hostilities between Northern Ireland’s main Protestant and Roman Catholic political parties threatened a timetable for power sharing in the province by March 26. There was no immediate sign of a breakthrough to end the standoff.

headline: Protests Prompt Thai Coup Leader to Request State of Emergency
abstract: A general’s request came in advance of planned rallies by pro-democracy groups as well as supporters of the ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra.

headline: Beyond the X’s and O’s, a Lesson in How to Be Big
abstract: For starters, protect the product by limiting its exposure.

headline: Britain: First Female Beefeater Appointed
abstract: The Tower of London, one of Britain’s most popular tourist attractions, has appointed a female guard for the first time in its 900-year history. She will join the ranks of the Yeoman Warders who wear a red-and-gold ceremonial uniform and are known as Beefeaters. The Yeoman Warders were officially appointed to guard the tower in 1485 and trace their origins even further back, to William the Conqueror’s reign in the 11th century. The origin of the term Beefeater is unclear. One theory is that the first guards were paid in beef. To join the 35-strong ranks of the Beefeaters, a candidate must have served 22 years in the armed forces.

headline: Updating an Old Way to Leave the Baby on the Doorstep
abstract: Advanced versions of the Middle Ages’  “founding wheel” are proliferating through Europe, allowing unwanted babies to be abandoned safely.

headline: Abe Rejects Japan’s Files on War Sex
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe contradicted the government’s longtime official position and denied that the military had forced foreign women into sexual slavery during World War II.

headline: From the Mind of a TV Producer, Satellite Television in a Portable Box
abstract: The Sat-Go is a mobile satellite and television system that folds up like a piece of luggage.

headline: U.S. in Talks With Britain on Installing Missile Defense System
abstract: Britain and the United States are discussing the possibility of stationing an American antiballistic missile defense system on British soil.

headline: Some Sectors in Europe Face a Labor Shortage
abstract: The most dynamic, future-oriented industries are having trouble finding qualified employees.

headline: Dismay Over New U.N. Human Rights Council
abstract: Critics say the new council is not a sufficient improvement over the former, widely discredited, Human Rights Commission.

headline: As Raids on Afghan Border Increase, U.S. Military Seeks More Troops
abstract: Attacks by militants crossing into Afghanistan from Pakistan have tripled since September along portions of the border, a senior American intelligence official said.

headline: Rice, Meeting Abbas, Promises U.S. Push on Mideast Peace
abstract: The Palestinian Authority president rejected suggestions for establishing a temporary state.

abstract: The Bush administration said there was no need for greater government oversight of the industry.

headline: Bush and Chávez Spar at Distance Over Latin Visit
abstract: President Bush ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, “Gringo, go home!”

headline: New Charges in Russia Against Oil Executives
abstract: The new charges against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky and one of his business partners include embezzlement and money laundering.

headline: Assembly Condemns Denial of Holocaust
abstract: The General Assembly adopted a resolution condemning the denial of the Holocaust, with only Iran, which was the host to a conference last month that cast doubt on the existence of the Holocaust, disassociating itself from the measure, which was drafted by the United States, co-sponsored by 103 countries and agreed to by consensus. Hossein Gharibi, the delegate from Iran, said that Israel exploited the sufferings of Jews as a cover “to commit new genocide and crimes” against the Palestinians. Dan Gillerman, the ambassador of Israel, responded, “While the nations of the world gather here to affirm the historicity of the Holocaust with the intent of never again allowing genocide, a member of the Assembly is acquiring the capabilities of carrying out its own.”.

headline: Assigning Ratings to Commercials Turns Out to Be a Tricky Task
abstract: A compromise by TV networks and advertisers on a system to count how many people watch commercials has hit a snag.

headline: A Disputed A.P. Source Turns Up, but Bloggers Are Not Appeased
abstract: The confirmation of an Iraqi source, whose existence had been called into question, hasn’t stopped bloggers from criticizing The Associated Press.

headline: Universal Near Deal With Video Site on Royalties
abstract: Universal Music Group is negotiating a settlement with Bolt.com, an online community that it sued over copyright infringement.

headline: Tips for Protecting the Home Computer
abstract: Botnet programs and other malicious software largely take aim at PCs running the Microsoft Windows operating system, because Windows’ ubiquity makes it fertile ground for network-based attacks.

headline: Tiffany to Hear Peltz Fund’s Ideas
abstract: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it would consider suggestions on strategy from Trian Fund Management, a New York investment firm that has become its largest shareholder. The company’s stock price rose more than 5 percent, reaching a three-year high of $45.06.

headline: U.S. Official Sees Opening for Revival of Trade Talks
abstract: Susan C. Schwab said she was optimistic that the Doha trade negotiations could be restarted, but added that there were still obstacles.

abstract: When the time comes, how can I move all of my bookmarks, music and other files from my old computer to a new Windows Vista PC?

headline: A Twisting Ride to the Web
abstract: Peter Sheinbaum, chief executive of Dailycandy.com, says his life is like a quilt rather than a blanket — he needs to collect experiences.

headline: Hey, George, What Song Do You Have Playing on My iPod?
abstract: The front panel of a new iPod dock from Perhaps Chestnut Hill Sound, called George, is removable and becomes an iPod remote.

headline: South Asians Taking Risky Route to Europe: Via Africa
abstract: South Asians, who long tried to enter Europe by land routes, are joining the ocean crossing from West Africa to the Canary Islands of Spain.

headline: Australian Held at Guantánamo May Go Home
abstract: David Hicks, who has been held at the American military base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for more than five years without trial, is to return to Australia by the end of the year.

headline: Digital Music Up 80% but Shy of Lost Revenue
abstract: Sales of digitally distributed music rose about 80 percent worldwide in 2006 but failed to make up for falling sales of compact discs.

headline: Belarus Learns That Days of Wine and Roses Are Over
abstract: Belarus faces the economic and political consequences of Russia’s hard-knuckled effort to cement its position as an energy power.

headline: Arrest Made in British Letter Bombings
abstract: A school janitor was arrested before dawn today in connection with a series of letter bombings that has injured at least nine people.

headline: 2 Car Bombs Kill Scores at Packed Market in Baghdad
abstract: The powerful blasts killed at least 88 people and wounded 160  in one of the worst scenes of carnage since the war began.

headline: Google Adds a Safeguard on Privacy for Searchers
abstract: Google is taking steps to make anonymous the logs it keeps of all searches that people conduct.

headline: Morgan Stanley Dissolves Partnership in India to Go Solo
abstract: Morgan Stanley will go it alone in India, lured by potential profits from the country’s quickly maturing corporate sector.

headline: A Review for ‘I Love New York’ Will Proceed Without Incumbent
abstract: A review to find an agency for the tourism campaign for Empire State Development will proceed without Eric Mower & Associates.

headline: Suicide Car Bomber Kills 7 Soldiers in Baghdad
abstract: BAGHDAD, March 10 — On one of the holiest days in the Shiite calendar, a suicide car bomber tried today to break through a military checkpoint on a bridge leading to Sadr City, a Shiite stronghold, apparently intending to ram into a crowd of people on the other side, the authorities said.

headline: In Guatemala, Officers’ Killings Echo Dirty War
abstract: Police corruption, lawlessness and drug traffic plague much of Central America, particularly Guatemala.

headline: Egypt Rebuffs U.N. Chief on Darfur
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was seeking help in influencing Sudan to accept U.N. peacekeepers.

headline: Acquisition Ban Lifted at Career Education
abstract: The Career Education Corporation said that the Education Department lifted a ban imposed in June 2005 that limited acquisitions and expansion.

headline: Ethiopian Premier Says His Troops Won’t Stay in Somalia
abstract: Ethiopia, one of the poorest countries in the world, could not afford to keep troops in Somalia, the leader said.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:.

headline: Siemens Executive Arrested
abstract: German prosecutors arrested Johannes Feldmayer as part of an investigation into suspected bribery.

headline: Renewal, in Real Estate and in Culture, for Ancient People
abstract: High real estate prices in Rome are driving the last Jews from their homes in the old ghetto, which is transforming itself into a trendy enclave.

headline: This Week’s Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:.

headline: In Gadgets, Excitement Is in the Price
abstract: For consumer electronics makers, the faster pace of price-cutting seemed to be even more of an obsession than a revolutionary new device.

headline: U.S. Seeks Account of North Korean Nuclear Effort
abstract: North Korea must fully disclose its efforts to produce highly enriched uranium, the chief U.S. negotiator said.

headline: Guatemala: Policemen Arrested in Killings of 4
abstract: The authorities arrested four police officers in connection with the killings this week of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver outside Guatemala City. Officials have speculated that the killings were politically motivated and linked to organized crime.

headline: Life Magazine, Its Pages Dwindling, Will Cease Publication
abstract: Life magazine will cease publication next month, the third time since Life’s founding in 1936 that its owner has pulled the plug.

headline: Venezuelan Plan Shakes Investors
abstract: Investors reacted with alarm to a plan by President Hugo Chávez to nationalize crucial areas of the economy.

headline: That’s Great, but How’s Productivity?
abstract: As the Federal Reserve warns  about the risk of inflation, a report this Wednesday on fourth-quarter productivity could carry considerable weight.

headline: Tech Shares Fall as Earnings Disappoint
abstract: Technology earnings reports that failed to meet Wall Street’s expectations pulled down the Nasdaq composite index last week, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed a small gain.

headline: 2 Key Lebanese Leaders Meet
abstract: The meeting was widely seen as a significant thaw in the months-long stalemate that has brought Lebanon to a political halt.

headline: Hedge Funds, the Usual Suspects, Blamed for Volatility in Asia
abstract: Traders and brokers in the region say hedge funds are going to create even more unpredictable gyrations in the future.

headline: Shiite Cleric Condemns U.S. as His Militia Takes to Streets
abstract: Searing speeches at Friday prayers and street battles against Iraqi Army soldiers in Baghdad suggest a possible resurgence of Moktada al-Sadr’s Mahdi Army.

headline: Nowadays, Angola Is Oil’s Topic A
abstract: Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and others have poured billions into Angola in the last decade to unlock petroleum resources, and the payoffs are finally coming in.

headline: Health Guidelines Suggested for Models
abstract: The fashion industry has issued guidelines to designers, aimed at promoting healthier behavior among models.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Brian Addison joined Wirestone, Chicago, as a director for brand strategy. He had been United States brand manager for Jim Beam bourbon whiskey at Beam Global Spirits and Wine, Deerfield, Ill.

headline: Conoco Posts First Decline in Earnings Since 2002
abstract: Warm weather and increased supplies dragged down energy prices from the record highs of a year earlier.

headline: Price of a Good Name? For Louvre: $520 Million
abstract: Abu Dhabi agreed today to pay that much to attach the Louvre’s name to a new museum it hopes to open in 2012.

headline: Plan to Revive Trade Talks Is Offered in Davos
abstract: Leading ministers at the World Economic Forum embraced an unusual plan for reaching agreement on trade negotiations.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Assistant Managing Editor Glenn Kramon
abstract: Glenn Kramon, The Times's assistant managing editor for enterprise, is answering reader questions this week.

headline: Senegalese Vote Hinges on Views of Economic Growth
abstract: Abdoulaye Wade has struggled to convince young voters hoping for economic growth that he deserves another term.

headline: A Deadline May Be Extended for Claims in Holocaust Case
abstract: An Italian insurance company has agreed to give heirs of Holocaust victims another 18 months to uncover documentation on unpaid life insurance policies at long-sealed Nazi archives.

headline: Ethiopian Adviser Denies New York Times Report
abstract: The report detailed the close and largely clandestine collaboration between Ethiopia and the United States to kill or capture leaders of Al Qaeda in the Horn of Africa.

headline: Yahoo Planning to Add 100 Web Sites for Entertainment
abstract: The company’s effort is intended to create online destinations for individual movies, television shows, bands, celebrities, games and other types of entertainment.

headline: Prince Harry of Britain to Serve in Iraq
abstract: Harry, 22, is a junior officer in the upper-crust Blues and Royals regiment of the Household Cavalry.

headline: Poland: Privatization Plan for Exchange
abstract: The Polish government is preparing a plan to privatize the Warsaw Stock Exchange by selling shares exclusively to Polish companies, possibly in defiance of European Union rules that require equal treatment for all members of the bloc. In a little-noticed speech filled with patriotic themes, the treasury minister, Wojciech Jasinski, outlined a strategy last month to sell 49 percent of the government’s holdings to “Polish investors” in blocks of 5 percent to 10 percent. The government also intends to introduce rules to prevent companies listed on the exchange from being taken over by foreign companies to ensure that the exchange retains its Polish character, Mr. Jasinski said. The plan appears ripe for a conflict with European Union rules, which require privatizations to be open to all union members. Catherine Bunyan, a spokeswoman for Charlie McCreevy, the union commissioner for the internal market, said Brussels was not aware of Warsaw’s plans.

headline: Home Sales Figures Signal a Slowing Market
abstract: Sales of existing homes declined 0.8 percent in December, according to the National Association of Realtors.

headline: Iraq: U.S. Forms Refugees Task Force
abstract: With concern mounting in Congress about the slow pace of resettling Iraqi refugees in the United States, the State Department has announced the creation of a new task force.

headline: When Money’s Involved, the Truth Can Take a Beating
abstract: Gerald Grinstein is just the latest executive who, faced with an unsolicited offer, seems to be speaking out of both sides of his mouth.

headline: Lives Entwined by War Enter a Long, Arduous Chapter: Recovery
abstract: Petty Officer Third Class Dustin E. Kirby and Marine Lance Cpl. Colin Smith were thrown together on a battlefield in Iraq.

headline: Delays Limit Robust Sales at Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft reported strong sales but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.

headline: U.S. Tries to Ease Concerns in Russia on Antimissile Plan
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said American plans to base missile defenses in Eastern Europe were solely intended to counter Iran.

headline: Zimbabwe Police Release Opposition Leader
abstract: The actions came as the country’s longtime president headed for regional talks over unrest there.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Global Markets Fall Again on Fears About U.S. Economy
abstract: Stock markets fell sharply across most of Asia again today and continued declining in Europe, as investors worried about the drop on Tuesday in American stock indices. Share prices rose initially today at the New York Stock Exchange.

abstract: Large companies that bought subprime lenders during a boom in the market are now scrambling to sell them or scale back their exposure.

abstract: Stocks prices on Wall Street rebounded today from a steep decline at the opening bell of the New York Stock Exchange.

abstract: For the first time since the Internet bubble burst at the start of this decade, technology stocks really matter.

abstract: Toyota and the Speed Channel cable network have joined forces to produce an unusual program in which the Toyota FJ Cruiser plays a starring role.

abstract: The takeover battle for the troubled Mills Corporation appeared to have ended Friday, with the mall operator Simon Property Group emerging as the victor.

headline: China Nears Passage of Landmark Property Law
abstract: Two pieces of legislation are intended to protect private wealth and create a more coherent tax code.

headline: For a Media Room Away From Home, a Remote for the Laptop
abstract: The Interlink ExpressCard Media Remote lets an average laptop act like a media center, complete with a couch-potato-worthy remote control.

headline: Japan: Minister Critical of ‘Blond’ Envoys
abstract: Foreign Minister Taro Aso said “yellow-faced” Japanese could play a more constructive role in Middle East diplomacy than Americans. “Japan is doing what Americans can’t do,” he said, according to the newspaper Nikkei. “Japanese are trusted. If you have blue eyes and blond hair, it’s probably no good.” Mr. Aso is often mentioned as a successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

headline: Storm May Cost JetBlue $30 Million
abstract: Last week’s storm has cost the airline $10 million in refunds, $16 million in travel vouchers and $4 million in expenses like overtime.

headline: For the Super-Rich, Too Much Is Never Enough
abstract: The recent philanthropic moves by Warren E. Buffett raise the question of exactly what other billionaires have in mind for their money.

headline: Heads of Arab States Prod Israel to Embrace Peace Offer
abstract: The leaders of 21 Arab governments called on Israel to withdraw from the land it occupied in the 1967 war in exchange for full diplomatic relations with them.

headline: Nepal to Seize Property Acquired by Its King
abstract: A panel has been set up to collect details of property earned by King Gyanendra after he ascended the throne and recommend procedures to nationalize it.

headline: G.M. Posts Fourth-Quarter Profit on Cost Cuts
abstract: G.M. showed its largest quarterly profit in more than two years as its restructuring plan drastically cut expenses.

headline: Ethiopian Forces Start Leaving Somalia
abstract: The Ethiopian troops who helped install Somalia’s fledging government began to pull out Tuesday.

headline: To Settle Suit, Maker Agrees to Withdraw Growth Drug
abstract: A drug to spur growth in extremely short children will be removed from the market to settle patent infringement charges.

headline: Start-Up Aims for Database to Automate Web Searching
abstract: Metaweb Technologies is setting out to create a vast public database, paving the way for a more automated Internet.

headline: Major Indexes Gain as Global Markets Rebound
abstract: Global stock markets bounced back last week, and on Wall Street the three major stock indexes posted healthy gains.

headline: Afghanistan: Kabul Suicide Attack Kills 4
abstract: A suicide bomber on foot detonated his explosives close to the car of a high-ranking Afghan intelligence official and near a crowded bazaar in Kabul.

headline: Murdoch Said to Join Tribune Bid
abstract: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for the Tribune Company — Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post.

headline: Iran’s President Reaffirms Nuclear Ambitions
abstract: President Ahmadinejad said today that U.N. sanctions will not deter Iran from pursuing its nuclear program.

headline: Homeowners, Call Your Bankers Before They Call You
abstract: With many adjustable-rate mortgages about to reset at a higher rate, it is important to take action before the lender does.

headline: 2 Plan a Production Company
abstract: Two Hollywood executives who formerly ran network entertainment divisions have created a company to produce entertainment for TV, films and the Internet.

headline: Iranian Diplomat Kidnapped in Baghdad by Iraqis With Official ID
abstract: Serious questions were raised about whether Iraqi government forces were involved in the abduction.

headline: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
abstract: President Bush announced tonight that he is sending more than 21,000 troops to Iraq, while conceding that he provided neither enough troops nor enough resources to control the chaos last year.

headline: German Bishops’ Remarks on West Bank Are Denounced
abstract: Jewish groups are condemning comments that drew a link between the plight of Palestinians in the West Bank and Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto during World War II.

headline: It’s Alive! Meet One of Biotech’s Zombies
abstract: In its 25 years in drug research, Xoma has burned through $700 million and never earned an operating profit nor brought a product to market.

headline: Bank Poses Obstacle in North Korea Nuclear Talks
abstract: The agreement for the release of $25 million from a Macao bank has been rejected by the largest account holder.

headline: U.S. Freezes Assets in Latvia in Stock Inquiry
abstract: Regulators froze a Latvian account suspected of being used to hack into online brokerage accounts and manipulate stock trading.

headline: Gambian Defends the International Criminal Court’s Initial Focus on Africans
abstract: All of the cases set to be taken up by the International Criminal Court so far involve Africa, drawing concern among Africans that their continent is the new court’s principal target.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: A380 ARRIVING An A380 airliner with about 500 passengers aboard will arrive at Kennedy International Airport from Frankfurt around noon on March 19 in a test flight to demonstrate what its operator, Lufthansa, and its manufacturer, Airbus, call the A380’s “operational maturity.” It will mark the first time the so-called super-jumbo airliner has been flown overseas with a full passenger load and meal service. Most of the passengers will be Airbus and Lufthansa employees, though some reporters and photographers will also be aboard. Lufthansa has ordered 15 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2009. Meanwhile, another Airbus A380  this one without passengers and operated by a crew from the Australian airline Qantas  is expected to arrive on the same day and at about the same time at Los Angeles International Airport, according to a joint statement by Airbus, the airport, the Los Angeles mayor’s office and Qantas. That flight will depart from Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France, where the A380 program has had unexpected manufacturing delays. Los Angeles International has long lagged in making the extensive renovations to terminal gates and taxiways to accommodate the double-decker airliner, and is still some time away from doing so. The A380 will park on a ramp at Los Angeles for publicity and ground-based tests. Airbus and some airlines with A380 orders have criticized Los Angeles International for falling behind on the renovations. The airport, which is competing with San Francisco as a major Pacific overseas gateway, recently began a $723.5 million modernization of its international terminal that will include at least two gates that can accommodate the A380. Qantas has ordered 20 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2008.

headline: In London, a Trial Over an Anonymous Blog
abstract: Testimony has offered new insights into the hands-on style of the chief executive of the WPP Group, and the strong feelings it has sometimes produced.

headline: Voice Lesson: An Outsider in Charge
abstract: Under New Times, The Village Voice, which has always been the home to permanent revolution, continues to flop from one crisis to another.

headline: Apple TV Has Landed
abstract: Apple TV can connect your computer to your TV without wires — as long as you have a wide-screen TV.

headline: Big Investors Still Crave Commercial Real Estate
abstract: In 2006, institutions like pension and private equity funds pumped capital into real estate investment trusts.

headline: This Time, No Roadside Assistance
abstract: Back then, it was Lee Iacocca and the federal government bailing out Chrysler. Today the German owners must figure out how to fix the company.

headline: On the Way Out but Feeling O.K.
abstract: What’s one year and 335 days between brothers? At Alcoa, it is nothing.

headline: Fusing Arab and Western Couture as Brother Leader Watches
abstract: Rabia Ben Barka’s gowns are what some people would like to see Libya become — a blending of the traditional and the modern.

headline: South Korea: Samsung Forecast
abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company forecast record profit from consumer electronics this year, helped by television sales. Profit this year from the digital media division, including earnings from overseas affiliates, will probably exceed 1 trillion won ($1.1 billion) for the first time, Choi Gee Sung, president of the division, said in a statement. Samsung plans to sell 11 million L.C.D. televisions in 2007, up from 6.2 million units last year, the company said. Samsung, which is based in Suwon, South Korea, also forecast its shipments of plasma TVs to rise to 2.5 million units this year, compared with 1.3 million sets in 2006.

headline: Listening for Clues on Spending
abstract: The thirst to acquire new neat stuff never seems to go away.

headline: Tug of War Between TV News Rivals Sends Anchor to CNN a Day After Fox Cut Her Loose
abstract: A little-known anchor named Kiran Chetry is the subject of the latest dust-up between the bitter rivals Fox News and CNN.

headline: Taliban Stepping Up Attacks in Afghanistan
abstract: Attacks by Taliban insurgents in southern Afghanistan have increased in recent days in what seems to be the opening of the fighting season, officials said Saturday.

headline: How to Soften the Edges of Technology
abstract: Some companies will now encase both a computer and its peripherals in a back-to-the-future covering of a different sort: warm, glowing wood.

headline: Thais Struggle With Violent Insurgency
abstract: Since a new government policy of conciliation toward Muslim separatists, violence has grown worse in southern Thailand.

headline: Ukraine: Pro-West Foreign Minister Quits
abstract: Boris I. Tarasyuk, the foreign minister, resigned after a constitutional dispute over his post. Mr. Tarasyuk has been a close ally of President Viktor A. Yushchenko and the most vocal proponent of leading Ukraine closer to the European Union and NATO. Parliament voted to dismiss him in December and later moved to remove the president’s power to appoint ministers overseeing foreign and defense matters, a move a weakened Mr. Yushchenko declared unconstitutional. Mr. Tarasyuk, in televised remarks reported by news agencies, said he resigned after a court hearing in the dispute was postponed. Mr. Yushchenko’s office declared that he would appoint a successor.

headline: Courts Turn to Wikipedia, but Selectively
abstract: More than 100 judicial rulings have relied on Wikipedia, beginning in 2004, including 13 from circuit courts of appeal.

headline: Internet Boom in China Is Built on Virtual Fun
abstract: Instant messaging and game-playing are major obsessions, now central to Chinese culture.

headline: China: Google Invests in Internet Firm
abstract: In a move to expand beyond the search business in the world’s second-largest Internet market, Google has made an investment in Xunlei NetworkTechnology, a Chinese Internet video firm, the company said. A Google spokesman said that the investment in Xunlei would be announced today in Beijing, but he declined to give details. According to wire services, the China Daily reported that Google will team up with Ceyuan Ventures, a venture capital firm in Shangai, to buy a stake in Xunlei, which is in Shenzhen. According to the reports, Xunlei’s Web site attracts more than 50 million visitors a day and more than 80 million users have downloaded its software. The Xunlei deal would be Google’s second in as many days in China. Google is also teaming with China Mobile, that country’s largest mobile telecommunications carrier, to deliver search services to cellphones.

headline: State Street to Acquire Investors Financial for $4.5 Billion
abstract: In a $4.5 billion stock transaction, the two will join forces to challenge the recently announced combination of Bank of New York and Mellon Financial.

headline: The Future of Economics Is Not So Dismal
abstract: Economists have been using their tools, mainly the analysis of enormous piles of data to tease out cause and effect, to examine everything from politics to French wine vintages.

headline: Estonia: President Rejects Vote to Remove Soviet Monuments
abstract: President Toomas Hendrik Ilves said he would veto legislation to authorize the removal of Soviet war monuments, specifically a memorial in the capital, Tallinn, known as the Bronze Soldier. The monument, viewed by many in Estonia as a symbol of Soviet occupation after World War II, has become the focus of intense protests in Estonia and had prompted furious denunciations from Russia. Parliament had narrowly approved the legislation to relocate the Bronze Soldier in a third and final vote earlier in the day, but in a statement Mr. Ilves called aspects of the legislation unconstitutional, though he did not elaborate.

headline: Less Shoplifting in Health and Beauty Aisle
abstract: Cosmetics and health-care products were the items most likely to be shoplifted in 2000. They fell to third in 2006, after meat and analgesics.

headline: Pakistan Wants Afghan Refugees Resettled
abstract: Pakistan’s prime minister said today that three million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan must be resettled in their native country.

headline: High Security as Iraqi Leader Visits Restive Anbar
abstract: Officials said the visit was an opportunity for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to exchange ideas on how to quell the violence and improve the quality of life.

headline: Russia Moves to Restrict Foreign Ownership of Energy Fields
abstract: Investors said they interpreted the new rules as traffic signals that could smooth the flow of capital into Russia.

headline: Hong Kong and Shanghai Duel for Financial Capital
abstract: The battle over economic dominance in China is partly a contest between traditional power and international influence.

abstract: Charles W.
