headline: Russian Police Trample Anti-Putin Protest
abstract: Riot police officers swarmed on a group of several dozen journalists and demonstrators, cutting off a protest against the government of President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Dogs at the Office: Not Always So Cute
abstract: Tension between the indulgent and the resistant.

headline: Super Bowl Ads of Cartoonish Violence, Perhaps Reflecting Toll of War
abstract: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.

headline: Britain: An Increase in Profit at the London Stock Exchange
abstract: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a “strong performance” in fiscal 2008. Net income rose to £31 million ($59.8 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from £28.2 million a year earlier, the exchange said. Revenue increased 11 percent, to £89.9 million ($173.5 million). The third-quarter results “support the board’s rejection of Nasdaq’s offer, which significantly undervalues the business and the exchange’s unique strategic position,” the exchange’s chief executive, Clara Furse, said. “Our strong growth prospects will continue to enhance the quality of our markets.” The exchange, Europe’s biggest equity market, released its earnings about three weeks ahead of schedule and two days before Nasdaq’s offer to pay £12.43 a share expires.

headline: Insurgents Battle Somali Forces in Capital
abstract: Mogadishu exploded in violence this morning after insurgents attacked a government barracks overnight.

headline: New Warsaw Archbishop Quits Over Communist Collaboration
abstract: Stanislaw Wielgus resigned after admitting that he had worked with the Polish Communist-era secret police.

headline: Italian Prime Minister Resigns
abstract: Romano Prodi resigned after his ruling coalition lost a key vote on foreign policy in the Senate.

headline: It’s a Brawl. China’s Gamblers Are the Prize.
abstract: Stanley Ho’s casino empire in Macao is under assault from a group of ambitious Las Vegas tycoons.

headline: AT&T Megastore Aims to Make It Fun to Buy a Phone
abstract: A former Cingular Wireless outlet has been remade into AT&T’s answer to Apple’s successful retail stores.

headline: Merger Activity Lifts Lazard to Record 4th-Quarter Profit
abstract: Lazard said that strength in its merger-advisory business helped lift its fourth-quarter profit 50 percent, to a record $85.8 million.

headline: Amgen Finds Anemia Drug Holds Risks in Cancer Use
abstract: The biotechnology company said its anemia drug Aranesp increased the risk of death when used to treat certain cancer patients.

headline: Economic Powers Vow Closer Look at Hedge Funds
abstract: Finance ministers from the world’s leading economies said they would scrutinize the hedge fund industry closely with an eye toward encouraging more self-regulation.

headline: The British Like to Control TV With Their DVRs, Too
abstract: Sales of digital video recorders through British Sky Broadcasting have surged in England.

headline: Yahoo Introduces Mobile Service Software
abstract: Yahoo’s Go for Mobile 2.0 will let users find information like news, stock quotes and sports scores more quickly on their cellphones.

headline: Romania: a Bid for Dracula’s Castle
abstract: Dracula’s castle may sell for 60 million euros ($78 million) after the local government offered to buy the Transylvanian fortress to increase tourism revenue. The Brasov County Council in central Romania is in talks with a foreign bank on a 10-year loan for that amount to get back the castle from its current owners living abroad, Aristotel Cancescu, president of the municipality, said in a telephone interview. Built in 1212 by Teutonic knights, the castle was briefly used two centuries later by the Romanian ruler Vlad the Impaler, who inspired Bram Stoker’s legend of Count Dracula. The castle’s current owners are Dominic von Habsburg, an industrial designer who lives in New York, and his sisters, Elisabeth Sandhofer and Maria-Magdalena Holzhausen, who both live in Austria.

headline: The Alarm Clock as a Moving Target. Catch It if You Can.
abstract: This alarm clock doesn’t just make noise, it rolls off the nightstand and runs away.

headline: Rice Speaks Softly in Egypt, Avoiding Democracy Push
abstract: The secretary of state’s visit indicated that the United States has decided that stability, not democracy, is its priority in the region.

headline: New Data, New Worry on Housing
abstract: One analyst anticipates further signs of economic weakness this week.

headline: Bank Blocks Plan to Release Frozen Funds to North Korea
abstract: The agreement between the United States and North Korea for the release of $25 million frozen in accounts in Macao has been rejected by the largest single account holder.

headline: Wholesale Inflation Surged in February
abstract: The prices that businesses charge one another rose 1.3 percent, a sign that inflation remains a threat.

headline: Can Your Dog Humanize the Office?
abstract: It had been thought that the patter of paws would go the way of casual Fridays and massages at your desk, but, the dogs, it seems, are here to stay.

headline: TJX Says Customer Data Was Stolen
abstract: The retailer that operates T. J. Maxx said that sensitive customer financial data was pilfered by identity thieves.

headline: Intel to Build Advanced Chip-Making Plant in China
abstract: The $2.5 billion chip-manufacturing plant is set to become the company’s first major production site in Asia.

headline: Levi’s Turns to Suing Its Rivals
abstract: The design for a Levi’s pocket, first used 133 years ago, has become the biggest legal battleground in U.S. fashion.

headline: Big Stake Is Bought in Struggling Studio
abstract: Nu Image acquired a controlling interest in the troubled First Look Studios, an independent film distributor.

headline: Most Viewed Technology Articles of 2006
abstract: 1) A Ring Tone Meant to Fall on Deaf Ears

headline: Israel Transfers $100 Million to Abbas
abstract: The transfer was part of a plan to bolster him and keep money out of the hands of the Hamas government, officials said today.

headline: Masco to Cut Jobs After Quarterly Loss
abstract: The Masco Corporation, the maker of Behr paint and Delta faucets, posted its first loss in five years and is laying off about 16 percent of its work force as a result of a slump in the housing market.

headline: West Adds to Strains on Iran’s Lifeline
abstract: The world’s fourth-largest oil exporter is forced to import 40 percent of its gasoline because of sanctions and booming consumption.

headline: A CBS Take on the YouTube Madness
abstract: A new campaign is capitalizing on the user-generated content craze by inviting basketball fans to upload video clips taunting supporters of opposing teams.

headline: Ryszard Kapuscinski, Polish Writer of Shimmering Allegories and News, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Kapuscinski’s writing, often tinged with magical realism, brought him critical acclaim and a wide international readership.

headline: Volkswagen Withdraws Ad That Involved Suicide
abstract: For the second time in a week, an automaker has agreed to stop running a television commercial that activists complained made light of suicide.

headline: Big Money Still Learning to Lobby
abstract: The hedge fund industry seems resigned to no longer be a wallflower in Washington as it joins the lobbying dance with Congress.

headline: Raytheon Surpasses Sales and Profit Forecasts
abstract: Raytheon said fourth-quarter profit rose 26 percent on higher foreign sales and electronics work for a new Navy ship.

headline: A Cry to Limit Chinese Imports Rings at Paper Mill
abstract: U.S. paper mills are a test case for a possible confrontation with China over tariffs on imports of Chinese-made paper.

headline: There Is Life After Hospice, and Even Golf in Florida for Some
abstract: Some people find that supportive hospice care may actually lengthen their lives, and that the doctors’ predictions of imminent demise may simply be wrong.

headline: China: Editor Freed After Three Years
abstract: A Chinese newspaper editor imprisoned for corruption after his newspaper broke articles about police abuse and a medical cover-up in Guangdong Province was released from prison three years early. Reporters Without Borders, a media watchdog group, said the editor, Li Minying, of Southern Metropolitan Daily, had his six-year prison term cut in half. Another editor of the paper, Yu Huafeng, is still serving a six-year sentence, also on corruption charges. The prosecution of the two men was widely viewed as retribution for reporting on matters that embarrassed powerful Communist Party officials.

headline: Someone (Other Than You) May Own Your Genes
abstract: Is it time to consider an alternative to patenting life forms?

headline: When the ‘Real’ Numbers Are Rosy, but the Others Are Less So
abstract: The nominal numbers reported about the economy are in some ways more real than the real ones.

headline: Consumer Price Gauges Rise More Than Expected
abstract: A small jump in consumer prices last month may result in the Fed raising interest rates. Any cuts, it seems, will have to wait.

headline: How Solid a Line Against Development?
abstract: The future of the Urban Development Boundary is up for grabs in Miami-Dade County as farmers and environmentalists face off about new construction.

headline: Bid to Secure Baghdad Relies on Troops and Iraqi Leaders
abstract: With his new plan to secure Iraq, President Bush is in effect betting that Iraqi leaders are committed to building a multisectarian state.

headline: Street Violence by Paris Youths Intrudes Again Into French Politics
abstract: The fights were a reminder of the tensions still simmering 18 months after rioting swept immigrant neighborhoods across France.

headline: Israeli Officials Praise Saudi Peace Initiative
abstract: Officials spoke of “positive” elements in the Saudi proposal, which was dismissed when it was offered in 2002.

headline: Bank Freeze Stalls North Korea Talks
abstract: Pyongyang has demanded the return of up to $25 million frozen in a Macau bank before it continues negotiations.

headline: South Korea and Japan Split on North Korea Pact
abstract: The South Korean government invited North Korea to resume ministerial talks, while Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan came under attack for his government’s refusal to provide assistance to the North.

headline: Taiwan Court Charges Leader of Opposition With Corruption
abstract: The indictment further upsets politics in Taiwan and raises uncertainties about how the race to succeed the current president will affect relations with China.

headline: Warner Music Makes Another Bid for EMI
abstract: A seven-year dance between music rivals continues as the industry grapples with online music downloads, piracy and a decline in CD sales.

headline: Afghanistan: Blast Wounds Tribal Elder
abstract: A senior tribal elder, Mullah Naquibullah, a close ally of President Hamid Karzai, and five others were wounded in a remote-controlled mine explosion in southern Kandahar Province, police officials said. The attack came after two suicide bombers struck NATO military convoys on the edge of the city of Kandahar on Thursday, wounding five civilians but causing no military casualties. In northern Afghanistan on the same day, a German engineer was killed by gunmen.

headline: Crash in Indonesia Exposes Deep Safety Problems
abstract: Industry regulators and airlines has not succeeded in correcting a deep aviation problem in Indonesia.

headline: New Suitor for Exchange in Chicago
abstract: Intercontinental Exchange made a $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Azerbaijan: Web Site Publisher Held
abstract: Bakhtiyar Hajiyev, a youth leader who called for protests against corruption and recent price increases for fuel and utilities, was arrested Saturday, opposition members and advocates for a free press said. Mr. Hajiyev founded a Web site, susmayaq.biz, which translates as “Let’s not keep silent.” The site apparently angered the government of President Ilham Aliyev, said Emin Huseynov, director of the Institute for Reporters’ Freedom and Safety, a private Azeri organization.

headline: Israel Releases $100 Million Withheld From Palestinians
abstract: Israel transferred $100 million in Palestinian tax revenues to the office of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.

headline: Court Declares Bosnia Killings Were Genocide
abstract: The court cleared Serbia of intent to commit genocide, but said it had failed to prevent the Srebrenica massacre.

headline: Pfizer to Lay Off 10,000 Workers
abstract: The world’s largest drugmaker is seeking to cut costs by up to $2 billion a year amid fierce competition.

headline: Adelphia Bankruptcy Plan Is Approved
abstract: The plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in U.S. history was approved by a judge in New York.

headline: Option Lies May Be Costly for Directors
abstract: New rules in Delaware hold members of a company’s board personally liable for options shenanigans.

headline: Judge Is Urged to Back Deal on Hurricane Damage Claims
abstract: A lawyer who helped engineer a settlement with State Farm argued that the deal should be approved because it could give millions to victims of Hurricane Katrina by the end of the year.

headline: U.S. and North Korean Envoys Hold Talks
abstract: The United States was seeking to revive stalled negotiations to end North Korea’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: I Want My Howard Stern and Oprah
abstract: When it comes to new and emerging technologies like satellite radio, what exactly constitutes competition?

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Tax Loans Are Losing Some Allure
abstract: Refund anticipation loans, the money-making service provided by tax preparers, appear to be falling on hard times.

headline: ImClone Shares Rise on an Erbitux Study
abstract: ImClone said that its Erbitux cancer drug works as a first-choice treatment for bowel cancer.

headline: As Egypt Votes on Laws, Cynicism Rules the Street
abstract: Issues of politics were overshadowed by more basic concerns, like lack of jobs, inadequate housing and the price of food.

headline: In Japan, a Historian Stands by Proof of Wartime Sex Slavery
abstract: Yoshiaki Yoshimi found a rare trove of official documents that uncovered the Japanese military’s direct role in managing brothels during World War II.

headline: It Can Hold 853 Passengers, but Why Should You Share?
abstract: For some, an Airbus A380, the largest passenger plane, is just the right size for a private jet.

headline: U.S. Military Contractors Seek Deals at Bangalore Air Show
abstract: As India and the United States gradually relax policies on military collaboration between the two countries, American companies hope to compete for contracts worth billions of dollars.

headline: For Sale: Hussein’s Riviera Villa
abstract: In the hills outside this small southern French town sits a peaceful stone villa once acquired for the family of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Earnings at Goldman Were Up 29% in Quarter
abstract: Goldman Sachs reported profit of $3.2 billion, setting a record amid growing concern over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

headline: S.E.C. Query to Adobe
abstract: Adobe Systems, which makes design software, said yesterday that it had received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission asking for more information about its stock option practices.

headline: Afghan Lawmaker Is Killed in Shooting
abstract: A member of Afghanistan’s Parliament was gunned down while he was walking to a mosque, officials said.

headline: U.N. Commander in Kosovo Resigns After Deaths
abstract: The resignation followed violent clashes between the police and demonstrators that left two protesters dead.

headline: Staying Updated  on Security
abstract: Why does Windows say my antivirus program is out of date when I just recently installed it?

headline: No Proof of C.I.A. Illegality, Portuguese Premier Says
abstract: Prime Minister José Sócrates responded to allegations that the United States had conducted illegal counterterrorism activities on an American air base in Portugal.

headline: 1,000 Journalists Killed in 10 Years While Reporting
abstract: The three deadliest countries for journalists in the last decade were Iraq, Russia and Colombia.

headline: More Than 100 Are Killed in Iraq as a Wave of Sectarian Attacks Shows No Sign of Letting Up
abstract: The deadliest attacks on Thursday were aimed at predominantly Shiite neighborhoods and appeared to be part of a fierce campaign by Sunni Arab insurgents.

headline: Britain Signals Plans to Reduce, Not Increase, Troop Levels in Iraq
abstract: Britain said that it would proceed with plans to hand over security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

headline: Israel Sets Curfew in West Bank City
abstract: The Israeli Army put Nablus under curfew today in one of the largest military operations there in two years.

headline: Chirac Discusses Life After Politics in TV Interview
abstract: President Jacques Chirac has given his first hint that he may not run for a third term in the French elections in April.

headline: A Film Star in Kampala, Conjuring Amin’s Ghost
abstract: “The Last King of Scotland” depicts an era Ugandans like to forget, but they are proud it is about their country.

headline: For a Press Baron, a Showdown in a City He Barely Knew
abstract: It is worth reflecting that had Conrad M. Black not coveted the profile that The Sun-Times was intended to help give him, he would not be in the pickle he is in.

headline: Islamist Fighters Captured Fleeing Somalia
abstract: Several Somali Islamist fighters and possibly some of their leaders were arrested trying to escape into Kenya, Kenyan authorities said today.

headline: Global Battle Against Measles Is Said to Save 2.3 Million Lives
abstract: Unicef and the World Health Organization reported that the goal of halving measles deaths worldwide by 2005 has been surpassed.

headline: Sourcefire I.P.O. Prices Above Expectations
abstract: Shares in Sourcefire, a network security company, priced at $15 a share Thursday evening, exceeding its pricing range and raising more than $70 million for the company, the Baltimore Sun reported Friday. That price now values the company at $346.7 million. John E. Fitzgibbon Jr., an analyst at IPOScoop.com, said that the offering was oversubscribed and that the I.P.O. should enjoy a healthy debut Friday.

headline: The Land of Rising Conservation
abstract: Japan, the most energy-efficient developed country, offers a lesson in using technology to reduce energy consumption.

headline: Italian Premier Resigns After Losing Foreign Policy Vote
abstract: Italy’s fragile government snapped over internal divisions and skepticism about Europe’s role in fighting terrorism.

headline: Analysis Is Bleak on Iraq’s Future
abstract: A new National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq expressed deep doubts about the abilities of Iraqi officials to hold the country together.

headline: Letters
abstract: Why Forecast Recessions?.

headline: Iraq's Premier Pleads for Help to Curb Violence
abstract: Addressing representatives of 13 nations and 3 international groups, Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki opened a regional conference in Baghdad.

headline: Britain Drafts Laws to Slash Carbon Emissions
abstract: Some of the measures in the plan could be unpopular with voters even as they inspire politicians’ acclaim.

headline: Britons Harvest Ship’s Bounty, From BMWs to Bibles
abstract: Ignoring health warnings and threats of prosecution, hundreds of people foraged among containers washed from a cargo vessel on the southern English coast.

headline: Lycos, Early Search Engine, in a U.S. Remake as Jubii
abstract: Lycos Europe is remaking itself for the U.S. market using the brand and services of Jubii, its Danish search and community business.

headline: Video Gear Helps to Lift Cisco’s Profit and Shares
abstract: The Internet equipment maker benefited from growing demand for bigger, faster networks that can handle video.

headline: 2002 Saudi Plan Revived as Spur to Arab-Israeli Talks
abstract: Israeli officials, pressed by Washington, are suddenly finding much to praise in a Saudi peace proposal offered at the height of a series of Palestinian suicide bombings.

headline: Denial Reopens Wounds of Japan’s Ex-Sex Slaves
abstract: Furor over the issue of war-era sex slaves has highlighted yet again Japan’s unresolved history in the region.

headline: Israel May Have Violated Arms Pact, U.S. Says
abstract: At issue is Israel’s use of American-supplied cluster munitions during its fight in Lebanon last summer.

headline: Icahn Makes Bid for Florida Home Builder
abstract: The investor Carl C. Icahn bid $955.9 million yesterday for WCI Communities, the Florida builder of condominiums and single-family homes, after saying he wanted to oust the board because the stock was undervalued.

headline: Europe Sets Ambitious Limits on Greenhouse Gases
abstract: The European Union approved a compromise agreement on Friday that would make Europe the world leader in the fight against climate change.

headline: Canada: Five Dead in 20-Vehicle Crash
abstract: Five people were killed in a multi-vehicle pileup east of Toronto that brought traffic on Canada’s busiest route, Highway 401, to a standstill. As heavy snow fell and people worked to rescue victims trapped in cars, a tanker truck, one of at least 20 vehicles involved in the accident, burst into flames, producing a plume of black smoke that marked the site for hundreds of cars and trucks backed up for miles in both directions.

headline: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
abstract: A task force will investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company, the latest in a string of legal battles.

headline: Icahn Offers to Acquire Rest of Auto Parts Company
abstract: Carl C. Icahn. who recently spent $200 million to increase his stake in Lear to nearly 16 percent, has offered to acquire the entire company.

headline: Jordan’s King Urges U.S. to Pursue Peace in Mideast
abstract: King Abdullah II told Congress today that U.S. leadership was essential for an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal.

headline: Long Delays Hurt Image of JetBlue
abstract: Can one very bad week for JetBlue Airways wipe out years of industry-leading customer satisfaction ratings?

headline: Egypt Voters Approve Constitutional Change, Government Says
abstract: Voters overwhelmingly approved amendments to the country’s constitution despite opposition organizations calling for a boycott.

headline: The Year That Made Deal Makers Giddy
abstract: Mergers, takeovers and buyouts broke all records in 2006, and the party may well go on into 2007.

headline: Tensions Over French Identity Shape Voter Drives
abstract: France’s presidential campaign has been seized by a subject dear to the extreme right: how best to be French.

headline: Hard-Liners Win in Northern Ireland Election
abstract: In elections for a new provincial government, moderate groups on both sides of the sectarian divide lost seats.

headline: Thinks Big About the Little Guy
abstract: A boss tackles problems of the working poor while reducing turnover and increasing profits.

headline: Hedge Fund Plans to Solicit Proxies
abstract: Pirate Capital plans to solicit proxies in support of its push to persuade the Brink’s Company to hire an investment bank for a possible sale.

headline: Record Opium Crop Possible in Afghanistan, U.N. Study Predicts
abstract: Afghanistan’s opium harvest could be bigger than last year’s record crop, with nearly half of the provinces showing an increase in planting this year.

headline: France: Doctors Petition for Euthanasia
abstract: More than 2,000 French doctors and nurses have signed a petition admitting that they had helped terminally ill patients die and calling on the government to legalize euthanasia. The petition, which was published Thursday in the newsmagazine Le Nouvel Observateur, comes days before the trial of a doctor and a nurse charged with administering a fatal dose of potassium to a woman suffering from terminal pancreatic cancer in 2003. Actively ending a patient’s life is illegal in France, though withholding treatment with a patient’s consent is allowed under some circumstances.

headline: Saudi Arabia Bars Israeli Journalist Traveling With U.N. Chief
abstract: Orly Azoulay, the Washington bureau chief of Yediot Aharonot, was unable to obtain a visa.

headline: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy
abstract: The maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics filed for bankruptcy protection and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million.

headline: Cupid Takes to the Road, Too
abstract: Workplace love affairs have been thoroughly studied, but romances forged on business trips remain largely unexamined.

headline: Switzerland: UBS Names U.S. Official
abstract: UBS, the Swiss bank, said it had appointed Teresa Mullett Ressel, a former United States Treasury assistant secretary, to be the chief executive of its United States brokerage unit, UBS Securities. Ms. Ressel will maintain her role as chief operating officer for the company’s United States investment banking unit, UBS said. Based in Zurich, UBS hired Ms. Ressel in 2004 from the Treasury, where she was assistant secretary and chief financial officer.

headline: Saudis Endorse New U.S. Strategy for Iraq
abstract: The Saudi foreign minister also doubted whether the Shiite-led government in Baghdad can protect Sunni interests.

headline: Venture Capitalists Want to Put Some Algae in Your Tank
abstract: Investors are now searching for a holy grail that symbolizes wealth in both profits and what’s good for the environment.

headline: Groups in Brazil Aim to Call Military Torturers to Account
abstract: A recent civil case is the first time that a military officer has been formally called to account for the torture of political prisoners.

headline: Enchanting TED
abstract: David Pogue touts the Technology, Entertainment, and Design conference, and urges readers to go online to get a lesson in cutting-edge technologies.

headline: U.S. Governor Brokers Truce for Darfur
abstract: Sudan’s president and leaders of rebel factions agreed to a 60-day cease-fire in meetings with Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico.

headline: Chrysler Is Only U.S. Carmaker to See Sales Gains
abstract: The December report closed out a tough year for the Detroit auto companies, and 2007 may not be any easier.

Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

abstract: A campaign for sunglasses carries a theme — “Never hide” — that seems counterintuitive when you consider the product.

abstract: Opening up electricity markets to competition lead to soaring prices and the power industry is warning of a looming crisis.

Publicis had $500 million of net new business in the fourth quarter as it won business from Renault, Walt Disney and the Marriott Group, among others. Revenue in Europe was 530 million euros in the fourth quarter, a gain of 5.5 percent, excluding acquisitions and currency swings.

abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation reported income of 426.7 billion yen, or about $3.7 billion, due in part to strong American sales of its Camry sedan and the remodeled FJ Cruiser sport utility vehicle.

abstract: The Gap’s directors are participating in a broad review of the company’s strategy to pull it out of a protracted sales slump.

abstract: The turnaround has defied predictions from many analysts and critics of Russia, who believed that its army was hopelessly bogged down.

abstract: Taliban fighters who seized control of an Afghan town have started a campaign of arrests and reprisals against tribal elders and townspeople.

abstract: The Super Bowl ads for Snickers were criticized for being homophobic and were quickly pulled. However, Snickers.com’s share of all Web visits was almost 16 times larger than it had been a week earlier.

abstract: The Interior Ministry said seven Saudi nationals who had been detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, had been freed and transferred to Saudi custody.

headline: Japan: Inflation Slowed as Spending Climbed
abstract: The minister of economic and fiscal policy, Hiroko Ota, said there had been little change in price trends in January, after a report showed inflation slowed to zero percent for the first time since May. “Prices continue to be flat,” Ms. Ota said. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, were unchanged from a year earlier, matching the median estimate of economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Household spending climbed 0.6 percent in January, the statistics bureau said, the first increase since December 2005. Economists expected a 0.3 percent drop. The jobless rate was 4 percent, unchanged after the previous month’s figure was revised from 4.1 percent, the agency said.

headline: Chief Sees Difficulties in Splitting Off Chrysler Brands
abstract: Dieter Zetsche, DaimlerChrysler’s chief executive, said it would be difficult to separate and sell single brands.

headline: Gunmen Kill 3 French Sightseers on Road Near Saudi Holy City
abstract: The attack was a brazen reminder that foreigners are still targets despite an aggressive three-year security crackdown.

headline: Iran Shows Video of Britons as Dispute Heats Up
abstract: Britain froze all “bilateral business” with Iran and the Iranians displayed some of the prisoners on television. Iran indicated one sailor could be released soon.

headline: Halliburton to Complete Split With KBR
abstract: Halliburton, the oil field services provider, said yesterday that it would complete its separation from KBR Inc. by offering current stockholders the remaining 81 percent stake in KBR, its former subsidiary.

abstract: The head of Russia’s oil pipeline monopoly accused Belarus of illegally siphoning off oil on Saturday.

headline: Canada: Gateses Join in Aids Vaccine Search
abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation pledged $119 million for an AIDS research center in Canada to develop a safe AIDS vaccine within a decade. Appearing with Mr. Harper in Ottawa, Mr. Gates said his foundation would contribute $24 million to the project. Mr. Harper was criticized last August when he declined to attend a global AIDS conference in Toronto that featured Bill Clinton and the Gateses.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: West Bank: Israeli Forces Leave Nablus

The operation had placed the central casbah area under a curfew and kept tens of thousands of residents confined to their homes. Israel arrested five suspected militants and found three bomb-making laboratories, according to the military. A Palestinian man was killed during the operation.

abstract: The vice president delivered  a tough message to Gen. Pervez Musharraf that U.S. aid could be cut unless he becomes more aggressive in hunting Al Qaeda leaders.

abstract: Saturday’s toll brought the number of dead to at least 18 in violence that began Thursday night.

abstract: Private equity firms seeking to buy the airline extended the deadline for completing a deal by two weeks.

abstract: Businesses added many more workers last month than economists expected, and their pay rose at a healthy clip.

abstract: The effort was described by U.S. officials as a qualified success that disrupted terrorist networks in Somalia.

abstract: Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee war: a “stomach friendly” coffee for Americans who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff.

abstract: Good voice and presentation skills can help entrepreneurs come into their own and even compete against larger competitors with big marketing budgets.

abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that profit fell 22 percent after its largest bottler wrote down the value of its North American unit on reduced soda sales and higher raw material costs.

abstract: Microsoft plans to announce a contest to develop the next great digital diversion for the company’s Xbox 360.

abstract: The Sprint Nextel Corporation said fourth-quarter profit increased 32 percent after acquisitions increased revenue.

abstract: Ford has rapidly seen its position in the auto industry and in its hometown eroded by its failure to combat foreign competition.

abstract: Although the dollar has lost a lot of ground, the nation’s trade imbalance with the world has continued to rise.

abstract: KeyBanc Capital Markets said in a report that a Canadian parts supplier had offered to bid about $4.7 billion for the automotive unit.

abstract: The government had tried to block news coverage of a scandal, arguing that it jeopardized the investigation.

abstract: You're looking for a new career. But who's looking over your shoulder?

headline: Germany: Bavarian Leader Leaves the Stage
abstract: Edmund Stoiber, a leading conservative powerbroker and an ally and irritant to Chancellor Angela Merkel, said he would step down in September as Bavaria’s prime minister and leader of the Christian Social Union, a sister party of Mrs. Merkel’s Christian Democrats. Mr. Stoiber, the governor of Bavaria, Germany’s largest state and its economic powerhouse, for almost 14 years, had been under attack from within his party as opinion polls showed his and the party’s ratings sinking. Last month, he was forced to accept the resignation of his chief of staff after a party member critical of Mr. Stoiber accused the aide of snooping on her private life. The polls also shook Mrs. Merkel’s party, which relies on the muscle of the Bavarian conservatives in federal elections.

headline: Companies Pressed to Define Green Policies
abstract: Shareholders are calling upon companies to provide proof that their business decisions also consider issues involving climate change.

headline: One Path to Rebirth in New Orleans
abstract: While New Orleans haggles over a master redevelopment plan, people in some neighborhoods have been rebuilding on their own.

abstract: The negotiations appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Korea’s demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity.

headline: Bank of Japan, in a Split Vote, Decides to Hold Rates Steady
abstract: The nation’s central bank apparently concluded that the economy was too weak to bear a rate increase.

headline: Blast That Killed U.S. Diplomat Tied to Qaeda
abstract: Pakistan presented evidence that the bombing last March was masterminded by an operative of Al Qaeda.

abstract: Stocks rallied despite uncertainty, suggesting investor optimism, in part because of acceleration of the sustained fall in energy prices.

headline: Peru: President Questioned in 1986 Massacre
abstract: President Alan García was questioned by a judge about his actions during the killing of more than 100 suspected Maoist guerrillas during his first presidency in the 1980s. Peru’s Congress declined to bring criminal charges for the deaths against Mr. García in 1990 for the incident, in which Peruvian soldiers suppressed a rebellion at El Frontón prison in 1986 and then transferred the bodies of prisoners to anonymous graves on Lima’s outskirts. Reuters reported that Mr. García was not a target of the judge’s investigation. The questioning of Mr. García raises uneasy memories of his first term, which was haunted by political and economic chaos.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Germany Agonizes Over a Brain Drain
abstract: The steady exodus in recent years has become a hot topic in a land already saddled with one of the most rapidly aging and shrinking populations of any Western nation.

headline: 2 European Bank Chiefs Got Big Raises in 2006
abstract: The top executives of Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse received substantially bigger pay packages last year, but they still lagged behind their American counterparts.

headline: AT&T Posts 17% Rise in 4th-Quarter Earnings
abstract: AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits today driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

headline: F.D.A. Warns of Odd Effects of Sleep Pills
abstract: The F.D.A. ordered makers to print label warnings about risks and side effects like driving and eating while asleep.

headline: Harry Falk, 66, Chief of New York Board of Trade, Dies
abstract: C. Harry Falk became the chairman of the exchange’s board in 2000 and helped guide it after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. But it is unlikely that the program will initially offer shoe-scanning technology, said Larry Zmuda, the company’s partner for homeland-security-related business. In an interview, Mr. Zmuda said the major concern for Unisys was ensuring the program’s “predictability” for members, who will undergo a federal background check and pay an annual fee to receive biometrically encoded I.D. cards and access to a special lane for expedited passage through the security checkpoint. Mr. Zmuda cited early snags with shoe-scanning technology being tested in Orlando by Verified Identity Pass, which already operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear at Orlando and four other airports. The Clear shoe-scanning technology, developed by General Electric Security, was intended to detect traces of explosives and suspicious metal, and to allow most travelers to pass through Clear lanes without having to remove their shoes. But the scanner rejected an unexpectedly high number of travelers’ shoes in Orlando, requiring members to remove their shoes just as they would at regular checkpoints. Mr. Zmuda said Unisys, which plans to be operating in 6 to 10 airports within a year, will probably offer only a special lane for the I.D. cards in Reno while the company continues to study options that will provide more benefits. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, has said that not having to remove shoes is the biggest potential benefit sought by customers. But Mr. Zmuda said that “all of our survey data” show that not having to remove laptops from cases is the biggest benefit sought by potential members.

headline: Singapore: Growth Spurt in Quarter
abstract: Singapore’s economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in a year as a record number of tourists and an all-time high stock market spurred service industries and helped offset lower electronics exports. Its economy grew an annualized 7.6 percent in the final three months of 2006, after expanding a revised 5.6 percent in the third quarter, the trade ministry said. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in his New Year’s message that the pace of expansion may ease in 2007 because of an economic slowdown in the United States and weaker global demand for electronics, which account for about half the $118 billion economy’s exports. The economy may expand between 4 percent and 6 percent this year, Mr. Lee said.

headline: Chirac Hints He Won’t Run for Third Term
abstract: Officials played down the significance of President Jacques Chirac’s comments, saying they were of a general nature.

headline: Iran Is Playing a Growing Role in Iraq Economy
abstract: Iranian goods are flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities are looking to Iran for basic services.

headline: A Move to Heal Anglican Rift, but Short of Conservatives’ Goal
abstract: The Episcopal Church has not compromised as much as conservative Anglican leaders have demanded, a report issued at a crucial meeting of the Anglican leadership said on Thursday.

headline: Israel: Army Says It Uncovered Hezbollah Bombs
abstract: The Israeli military said that it found and detonated four bombs placed just on its side of the border with Lebanon and that it believed Hezbollah guerrillas were responsible. The bombs, disguised to look like rocks, were placed near a road used by Israeli soldiers, it said. Israel and Lebanon fought a month-long war last summer, and an enlarged United Nations peacekeeping force is now monitoring the Lebanese side of the border.

headline: Zimbabwe: Takeover of Diamond Mines
abstract: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, below, said he plans to take control of the nation’s diamond mines in response to allegations of smuggling and a diamond rush in the eastern district of Marange. Zimbabwe has two diamond mines, one known as Murowa, owned by Rio Tinto and RioZim, and the other as River Ranch, which is held by private investors. “Only government will mine diamonds,” Mr. Mugabe said in a televised interview on Tuesday. It is unclear whether Mr. Mugabe’s pronouncement will be made law, said David Murangari, chief executive of the Chamber of Mines, a business association that represents most mining companies in the country. Andrew Cranswick, chief executive of African Consolidated Resources, criticized the measure. “If the state takeover of diamond mines is passed into law, it will destroy diamond exploration in this country,” he said.

headline: Nepal: U.N. Creates New Political Mission
abstract: The United Nations Security Council voted to set up a mission to oversee a disarmament and cease-fire accord between the government and former Maoist rebels and plan elections of a constitutional assembly in June.

abstract: The maker of battlefield communications systems was asked by the S.E.C. for information on past stock option practices.

abstract: Martti Ahtisaari, the secretary general’s envoy for Kosovo, said independence was the only way Kosovo could become economically viable and politically stable.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief Meets Blair, Seeking Support for Iraq Plan
abstract: Robert M. Gates sounded out senior British officials on whether they planned to begin withdrawing troops from Iraq this year.

headline: South Korea: Growth Revised Upward
abstract: South Korea’s economy expanded 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter, more than first estimated, as exports declined less than initially anticipated, the Bank of Korea said. The figure was revised from an initial estimate of 0.8 percent and was down from a revised 1.2 percent rate in the third quarter. Goods exports fell 0.5 percent, less than the initial estimate of a 1 percent decline, the report showed. It was the first quarterly drop in exports since the three months ended Sept. 30, 2004. Business investment rose 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months and construction climbed 0.6 percent in the quarter. Private spending advanced 1 percent in the quarter, compared with an earlier estimate of a 0.8 percent increase, the report showed.

abstract: The Blackstone Group raised its offer to acquire Equity Office Properties to about $39 billion, E.O.P said shortly after 1 a.m.

abstract: A proposal amending Russia’s Constitution to allow Vladimir V. Putin to extend his presidency beyond its legal end in 2008 seemed to gain new life on Friday.

headline: Here’s the Online Line on Online Politics
abstract: Techpresident.com, which officially began publishing Monday, will cover the online aspects of the coming presidential campaign.

headline: Three Agencies Compete for Sprint Nextel Account
abstract: Sprint Nextel has named three agencies — for now — to compete for its creative account in a review that began in early January.

abstract: Most of the dead were Islamist leaders fleeing in armed pick-up trucks, according to Somali officials.

headline: Ex-Qwest Official Says Nacchio Ignored Advice
abstract: The former chief of Qwest Communications insisted on telling analysts the company could meet revenue targets that were later revised, an ex-finance chief testified.

headline: Japan: Airline’s Office Raided in U.S.
abstract: The All Nippon Airways Company had its offices in Los Angeles searched for nine hours yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to a statement from the carrier. The FBI declined to say why the office was searched. ”We don’t know why they raided the office, but we confirmed with our staff there that it wasn’t anything to do with the operation of the aircraft or terrorism,” a spokesman at All Nippon, Rob Henderson, said. The customer service center in Los Angeles is the headquarters of the airline’s North American operations and is responsible for passenger and cargo sales for the western and southern United States.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Germany: Strong Results at Insurer
abstract: Allianz, the European insurer, said fourth-quarter profit rose 57 percent, helped by a tax gain and fewer claims from natural disasters. Income rose to 1.37 billion euros ($1.8 billion), or 3.15 euros a share, from 872 million euros, or 2.13 euros, in the period a year earlier. Lower costs helped increase profit as revenue declined 1.5 percent, to 24.8 billion euros.

The charities were added to a similar United Nations list in 2005, and the state interior minister, Zafar Iqbal Warraich, told Parliament that the United Nations had notified Pakistan that it would impose sanctions if it did not ban them.

headline: Colombia: Ex-Minister’s Father Ordered Arrested
abstract: Prosecutors ordered the arrest of Álvaro Araújo Noguera, the father of Colombia’s former foreign minister and an influential regional political leader, amid a widening scandal revealing ties between supporters of President Álvaro Uribe and paramilitary death squads. Mr. Noguera, 74, was implicated in the kidnapping of Víctor Ochoa Daza, a member of a rival political family. Mr. Araújo’s daughter, María Consuelo Araújo, resigned as foreign minister last month; investigators have also jailed her brother on kidnapping charges. The scandal has also resulted in the arrest of Mr. Uribe’s former domestic intelligence chief, accused of handing over to paramilitary leaders the names of union officials and academics who became targets for assassination.

headline: Tiny Bones Found at India Hospital
abstract: The police in central India discovered 396 small bones and bone fragments that they say could be the remains of newborn babies or fetuses.

headline: Building a Memorial to a Son, One Child at a Time
abstract: By helping children abroad, an American couple sought to create a legacy for their son, who died of a heart ailment.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Ivory Coast: U.N. Extends Mandate of Troops

The Council has twice extended the term of President Laurent Gbagbo, which ran out in 2005, in anticipation of elections but has authorized a political opponent, Charles Konan Banny, the prime minister, to organize the vote, an arrangement that Mr. Gbagbo has challenged.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: LATE TO THE GATE Airlines last year had the lowest percentage of on-time arrivals since 2000, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics in the Transportation Department. In 2006, domestic aircraft arrived on schedule 75.45 percent of the time, compared with 72.59 percent in 2000. The five airlines with the worst on-time arrival rates last year were Skywest (63.9 percent); American Eagle, owned by AMR (64.3 percent); JetBlue Airways (64.8 percent); Alaska Air (66.3 percent); and Northwest Airlines (66.6 percent). As for luggage, with a sharp increase in the number of checked bags because tighter security procedures reduced the number of carry-on bags, airlines mishandled bags at a rate of 6.73 per 1,000 passengers, a slight increase over 2005 (6.64 per 1,000 passengers).

Sentencing will be in April. Prosecutors said he appeared to lead protesters in chants of “Bomb, bomb Denmark. Bomb, bomb U.S.A.” Mr. Javed told the court that they were “just slogans, sound bites,” and that he regretted saying them. “I did not want to see Denmark and the U.S.A. being bombed,” he said.

headline: Mexico: Pemex Oil Field Declining
abstract: Production at Mexico’s giant Cantarell oil field will fall by 15 percent this year, Jesús Reyes Heróles, left, the director general of Petróleos Mexicanos, Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly, said. Output dropped 13.1 percent last year. Mr. Reyes Heróles, a former energy minister who took over at Pemex in December, said other projects would help make up for the shortfall at Cantarell, which last year accounted for about 55 percent of Pemex’s overall production of 3.26 million barrels a day. Mexico is a top supplier of imported oil to the United States. Mr. Reyes Heróles said that the company needed additional investment of $8 billion to $10 billion a year to keep up production, develop new reserves, expand its refining capacity and modernize its storage and transport network. But Pemex is closed to private investment and cannot finance the investment itself. Last year, Pemex sales surpassed $100 billion but it paid $79 billion in taxes, which accounted for almost 40 percent of Mexico’s federal budget.

abstract: A reporter for The Washington Post said she could not set aside her personal feelings about Vice President Dick Cheney in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr.

headline: A Burst of Numbers to Distill
abstract: Clues about the course of the economy will be revealed in reports on inflation, manufacturing, housing and consumer confidence.

headline: Iranian President Cancels U.N. Trip, Blaming U.S.
abstract: Iran’s president canceled his plans to address Security Council members before the expected vote  on a resolution imposing sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: The Ex-Elite Flier Club
abstract: Frequent fliers who take a hiatus from traveling for family or other reasons often find their elite status gone when they return.

headline: Packing 100 Pairs of Shoes
abstract: Delivering shoes to people in the developing world proves to be an adventurous, and sometimes dangerous, job.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Giuliani Is Expected to Sell His Investment Bank
abstract: the former Mayor of New York Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently taken steps to sell the biggest division of his consulting business as he considers running for the presidency, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the firm’s plans. The sale of the division, Giuliani Capital Advisors, a boutique investment bank, is being pursued to prevent its clients’ activities from being used against Mr. Giuliani in a heated political campaign, said that person, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Hutchinson Shareholders OK Vodafone Deal
abstract: Shareholders of Hutchison Telecommunications International have approved the $11.1 billion sale of its Indian unit to Vodafone Group, a transaction that will finance a special dividend and expansion in Southeast Asia. Stockholders representing a majority of Hutchison Telecom’s shares approved the sale at an extraordinary general meeting in Hong Kong, Tim Pennington, chief financial officer of Hutchison, said Friday. The plan got “overwhelming support,” he said.

headline: Battery Technologies Recharges with $6.2 Million
abstract: Battery Technologies, which makes an ultrathin carbon-zinc battery, has raised $6.2 million to expand production. SunBridge Partners led the Series A financing round, which also included Early Stage Partners, Key Capital and Orix Capital.

headline: How a Hedge Fund May Have Kicked Off a Bank Sale
abstract: In the merger talks between Barclays, the British bank, and ABN Amro, a Dutch rival, hedge fund The Children’s Investment Fund is the proverbial the grease for the wheel. Its activism in several deals, including the scuppered merger between the Deutsche Borse and the London Stock Exchange, has garnered the fund a lot of attention recently.

headline: For Some, a Bacchanalian Bonus
abstract: It’s not uncommon for companies to offer product discounts to executives and directors. But there aren’t many companies whose perks include a fixed amount of money specifically for buying wine. In a recent regulatory filing, UST, which makes wine in Washington State and California, said it provided its chairman and chief executive, Vincent A. Gierer Jr., with a $5,000 “wine allowance.”

headline: Medical Product Firm Buys Back $2 Billion of Its Shares
abstract: The medical products maker Baxter International said Wednesday its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional $2 billion of its common stock. The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said the repurchase would be executed “upon completion of its existing share repurchase program.” Baxter said it has about $800 million of “remaining authorization under the $1.7 billion program” the board approved in February 2006.

headline: Evercore’s Secret to Getting Big? Staying Small
abstract: One could almost imagine the story of Roger C. Altman set to the soundtrack of “Rudy” or “Field of Dreams.” As written by Investment Dealers’ Digest, his is a tale of setbacks — a heart transplant and a tenure in the Clinton administration cut short by Whitewater — overcome by courage and savvy. Now Mr. Altman is known as the chief of the boutique investment bank Evercore Partners, a man smart enough to have advised on AT&T‘s $90 billion acquisition of BellSouth, humble enough to have refused naming his firm after himself. (He makes sure to point the latter out.)

headline: Producers to Start Club for Real First Wives
abstract: In advance of the spring 2008 opening of their Broadway production of The First Wives Club–based on the popular book and movie–producers Paul Lambert and Jonas Neilson plan to start up First Wives World, an online social networking site for divorcees, according to BusinessWeek. The two producers will invest $8 million to $10 million to get the site, which will offer ticket sales, forums, blogs, and, soon after, a dating service, off the ground this spring.

headline: Europeans Lash Out at Hedge Funds, Private Equity Investors
abstract: With the influence of hedge funds over publicly traded companies back in the spotlight thanks to developments at Dutch financial services giant ABN Amro Bank, both hedge funds and private equity investors came under fire on several European fronts Thursday. Political leaders urged talks at the European Union level and Socialists in the European Parliament released a critical report on “secretive financial deals.”

headline: How China Is Going Green
abstract: On the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been “alternative energy” and “China.” Are the two worlds about to collide? Seed investors are financing, or considering financing, start-ups in China that are developing equipment for wind and solar power, clean water and food alternatives and technology to promote energy efficiency. While this may seem to be an arbitrary combination of two of the hottest trends in venture capital – sort of like the first person who mixed peanut butter and chocolate – there is a growing number of investors who believe that the potential reward in China is worth the tremendous risk.

headline: Gateway Says It Is Not In talks With Acer
abstract: Talk of a deal between the computer maker Gateway and strong>Acer of Taiwan has been rampant ever since Acer’s chief executive, JT Wang was quoted earlier this month as saying he planned to make an acquisition in the PC industry this year.

headline: Pricing the iPhone
abstract: Rob Glaser, chief executive of Real Networks, on Apple’s new iPhone.

headline: The iToaster, the iWatch and the iRon?
abstract: Designs for nonexistent Apple products.

headline: Goldman and CanWest Team Up for Alliance Bid, Report Says
abstract: Goldman Sachs has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications to make an offer for Alliance Atlantis Communications, a Canadian media company, The Globe and Mail said. The report said that the two could offer as much as 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.1 billion) for Alliance, which was put on the block in December.

headline: Advertising at the Speed of Private Equity
abstract: It seems everyone wants a piece of the buyout boom. As private equity firms continue to spend billions of dollars to acquire public companies, M&C Saatchi, the advertising group, is creating an agency to serve the businesses they buy. Why would private-equity-backed companies advertise any differently than anyone else? The theory, according to Reuters’ article on the new firm, goes like this: To maximize their profits, buyout shops need to turn around their investments quickly. So they need to act faster to burnish their brands.

headline: Private Equity Stirs Canada’s Record Mergers Boom
abstract: Foreign buyers have stoked the biggest mergers-and-acquisition boom in Canada ever, snaring once untouchable Canadian trophy companies such as Inco, Dofasco, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts and Four Seasons Hotels. According to Thomson Financial, the value of mergers and acquisitions involving Canadian companies soared to $230 billion last year, nearly doubling the action a year earlier. The biggest player: private equity firms.

headline: A One-Time Denim King Turns to the Courtroom
abstract: Levi Strauss is becoming a leader in a new arena: lawsuits. The company, once the undisputed king of denim and now a case study in missed opportunities, has emerged as the most litigious in the apparel industry when it comes to trademark infringement lawsuits, firing off nearly 100 against its competitors since 2001. That’s far more than General Motors, Walt Disney or Nike, according to an analysis by a research firm, Thomson West.

headline: Hearst Tried to Sell Chronicle
abstract: Hearst has recorded $330 million in losses in its investment in the San Francisco Chronicle and attempted to sell the newspaper to MediaNews Group, according to court documents made public Thursday in a media antitrust case. Terms of the 2005 proposal were not revealed. But MediaNews did not offer enough, so no deal was made, James Asher, Hearst’s chief legal officer, said in the documents. The New York-based publisher acquired the Chronicle for $660 million in 2000.

headline: Ugly Bears and Bulls
abstract: Will ugly bears destroy the Goldilocks Economy?

headline: Hercules to Acquire Rival Todco for $2.3 Billion
abstract: Hercules Offshore, an oil and gas drilling company, said Monday that it would acquire a larger rival, Todco, for about $2.3 billion in cash and stock, gaining a larger footprint in the global oil rig market. Under the terms of the deal, Todco shareholders will receive .979 Hercules shares and $16 in cash for each of their shares, for a total of $42.01 per Todco share. The deal represents a 28 percent premium to Todco’s closing price Friday.

headline: Former Technology Analyst to Join Brunswick Group
