abstract: A veteran technology analyst, Steven Milunovich, will become a New York-based partner at the Brunswick Group to help strengthen the public relations firm’s investor relations business, the company said Wednesday. Mr. Milunovich spent many years as a top-ranked computer hardware analyst and managing director at Merrill Lynch until he left the firm in 2005 to start his own hedge fund, Financial News reported. He returned to Merrill in early 2006.

headline: Tata Steel Wins Corus With $12 Billion Bid
abstract: When the bidding was over, Tata Steel stepped away as the winner in a heated battle for its European rival, the Corus Group, topping an offer from Brazil’s Companhia Siderurgica Nacional. Tata agreed to pay at least $12.2 billion for Corus.

headline: FCStone I.P.O. Shines in Turbulent Market
abstract: The FCStone Group, a commodities risk management firm, rocked the market for initial public offerings on Friday, rising 30 percent after pricing at the high end of its estimated range. FCStone offered 5.1 million shares at $24 a share, at the top end of its $21-$24 range, raising $122 million. The stock opened at $27.50 and rose to end its first trading day at $31.13.

headline: Green’s Air America Bid Rings In at Just $4.25 Million
abstract: Stephen L. Green has offered $4.25 million for the assets of Air America Radio, the liberal talk-radio network, setting up an auction for the company, court documents show.

headline: When Budgets Loom, It’s Time to Rent a C.F.O.
abstract: The chief financial officer just left, paperwork is stacking up and the budget needs to be written. A small-business owner could try doing the work, but would not have enough time to run the company, look for a replacement and oversee the finances. So what to do?

headline: Patent Dispute Pits Tech Companies Against V.C.’s
abstract: A rift has arisen among larger technology companies and smaller venture capital firms over whether dramatic changes to U.S. patent law are necessary, CNet News.com reported Thursday. The differences in opinion played out during a Thursday hearing in the House of Representatives’ Small Business Committee, which doesn’t have the power to write patent laws but aimed to explore the small-business implications of Congress’ ongoing push for sweeping changes in the area.

headline: Ford Closes in on Aston Martin Deal
abstract: Ford Motor is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies in a deal that will be announced Monday, according to The New York Times. The Times said that Ford, which put Aston Martin up for sale last August, will retain a 15 percent stake in the marque.

headline: Copper Merger Gets Thumbs Up from Shareholders
abstract: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold‘s $25.9 billion cash-and-stock acquisition of a rival, Phelps Dodge, was approved Wednesday by shareholders of both companies. The deal would create the world’s largest publicly traded copper company. In separate votes by shareholders of Freeport, which is based in New Orleans, and Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, the buyout was approved by about 98 percent of the votes cast, the companies said in a joint statement.

headline: Is Citi’s Long Slump Finally Over?
abstract: Citigroup has been down so long, it looks like up to John McDonald, an analyst at Banc of America Securities. Mr. McDonald on Wednesday raised his rating on Citigroup’s stock to “buy” from “neutral,” writing that “years of disappointing fundamental and stock price performance have set the bar low for Citi shares.” The upgrade follows reports that Citi is preparing for its first major overhaul since being formed from the merger of Travelers and Citicorp a decade ago. In his research note, Mr. McDonald said that “even modest improvement in management execution and financial results could be positive catalysts for the stock.”

headline: Now You, Too, Can Enter the World of 007 Finance
abstract: Compared with buttoned-down stock jockeys at Fidelity or T. Rowe Price, hedge fund managers may be the James Bonds of the financial world. They have a reputation for being secretive risk takers who use an array of specialized financial weaponry like derivatives and short-selling. (No license to kill, of course, though their lightly regulated funds do allow managers tremendous, nonlethal latitude.)

headline: Vanishing Growth
abstract: Fourth-qharter growth was weaker than reported.

headline: NYSE Euronext Is Born
abstract: As the Nasdaq Stock Market licks its wounds after its failed bid for the London Stock Exchange, all seems to be going as planned for the New York Stock Exchange‘s overseas deal.

headline: Zell’s Tribune Bid Gains Traction, Report Says
abstract: Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate magnate who made a fortune by turning around distressed properties, has emerged as a strong contender to buy Tribune, according to a report in The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Zell’s bid for Tribune, which also owns The Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Cubs baseball team, is getting serious consideration because it could buy out the disgruntled Chandler family of California and take the company private, the newspaper said. That scenario is attractive to Tribune management because it would remove the company from the pressure of Wall Street investors.

headline: Nu Image Said to Be in Deal for First Look
abstract: The production company Nu Image/ Millennium Films is reportedly in talks to buy the hedge-fund backed First Look Pictures, whose chief executive and largest shareholder, Henry Winterstern, recently resigned. The move is an about face since Mr. Wintersten was himself planning to make a run at Nu Image before he fell afoul of a backer Prentice Capital Management, reportedly for his lavish spending habits and inability to pick a winner.

headline: BofA Cooperating in Bond Inquiry
abstract: Bank of America said Friday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.

headline: Teaming With Carlyle, Irish Media Mogul Revives APN Bid
abstract: The Irish billionaire Tony O’Reilly revived his 3.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.97 billion) takeover offer for APN News & Media, Australia’s fourth-largest media company, after luring the Carlyle Group to his buyout group. The bidders, led by Mr. O’Reilly’s Independent News & Media, offered 6.05 Australian dollars a share for the 60 percent of APN it does not already own. But shares of the publisher of the New Zealand Herald closed unchanged at 6.15 Australian dollars Thursday, signaling the group, which includes Providence Equity Partners, may have to increase its offer.

headline: Grasso Spars With New York Over Taxes
abstract: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose pay package has been the subject of a legal battle, is getting hit on another front as well. The New York Post reports that the New York State Department of Taxation wants to impose a $1.8 million penalty on Mr. Grasso related to New York City tax returns it believes he should have filed in 2002 and 2003. The dispute, according to the Post, hinges on the location of Mr. Grasso’s main residence during that time.

headline: For Dodd, Wall Street Looms Large
abstract: Democrats take control of Congress this week, and many in the financial services industry are wondering what legal or regulatory changes are in store. An important figure to watch is Christopher Dodd, the Connecticut senator who will become chair of the powerful Senate Banking Committee. On Tuesday, the Associated Press suggested that Mr. Dodd’s potential presidential ambitions may temper any zeal to slap additional regulations on Wall Street.

headline: Redrawing the Lines in I.P.O. Suits
abstract: Underwriters facing lawsuits over tech-boom stock offerings recently won an important legal victory, while the plaintiffs’ lawyers face a much tougher playing field for securities litigation, according to TheDeal.com.

headline: Vornado Chief Loses a Deal but Keeps His Reputation
abstract: The real estate magnate Steven Roth has let deals slip away before. He came within an inch of buying the World Trade Center in 2001. He lost out in the bidding for the prestigious General Motors building on Fifth Avenue in 2003. But never before has Mr. Roth, the chairman and chief executive of Vornado Realty Trust, been an also-ran in such a heavily publicized contest as the bidding war for Equity Office Properties, the nation’s largest office landlord.

headline: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $38.3 Billion
abstract: The Blackstone Group increased its offer for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, or $54 a share, in cash, escalating the stakes in the pitched battle for the country’s largest office landlord. The new offer trumps a rival $37.6 billion, $52-a-share bid by a real estate consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust made earlier this month. Analysts and industry watchers had expected the private equity giant to top the Vornado group’s bid, as the agreement it reached with Equity Office last November — for $48.50 a share — allowed Blackstone to match rival offers. If completed, the offer would set a record for a leveraged buyout.

headline: Hush Tactics for the iPhone
abstract: How Cingular managed to keep the iPhone a secret.

headline: Highbridge Buys Stake in Energy Business
abstract: The Highbridge Capital Management hedge fund said Monday that it had invested in the energy business of the Louis Dreyfus Group, the old-line commodities trading firm, forming a venture with an enterprise value of more than $1 billion. Highbridge Capital, a $17 billion hedge fund based in New York that is majority owned by J.P. Morgan Chase, said it had invested in Louis Dreyfus to gain more access to energy delivery and trading markets on its own.

headline: Private Equity Firm Picks Up Linde Unit
abstract: Linde, the world’s biggest producer of industrial gases, said Monday it sold part of its BOC Edwards subsidiary to private equity firm CCMP Capital for 685 million euros ($901.12 million). The deal to sell the unit of BOC Edwards, which was part of Britain’s BOC Group that Linde paid 12.4 billion euros for last year, is subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Shell Scores Victory in Takeover of Canadian Unit
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell is on the verge of taking over Shell Canada, announcing early Saturday that it had scored a significant victory in its bid of 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) for the firm. Royal Dutch, one of the largest public oil companies in the world, already owns about 78 percent of Shell Canada and is trying to buy the rest.

headline: Merrill to Pour $4 Billion into Real Estate Venture
abstract: Merrill Lynch plans to invest up to $4.15 billion in a property development partnership with the Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings, Reuters reported. Merrill Lynch’s Japan arm and SBI have agreed to create a special-purpose company to buy land and build condominiums and commercial properties, intending to sell the developments on to real estate funds and other investors, the report said.

headline: Univision Gets a New Chief
abstract: The private investor group that is acquiring Univision Communications said Tuesday that it had named Joe Uva, president and chief executive of the ad-buying firm OMD Worldwide, to become chief executive when the acquisition closes. Mr. Uva, 51, will succeed A. Jerrold Perenchio, 76, Univision’s longtime chairman and chief executive, on April 1, the investor group, Broadcasting Media Partners, said. The terms of Mr. Uva’s contract were not disclosed. He will remain based in New York when he takes control of Univision, which is based in Los Angeles.

headline: Chrysler’s Finance Arm Could Be Sold, C.E.O. Says
abstract: The financing arm of the Chrysler Group, the American division of DaimlerChrysler, could be sold as its parent company considers options, DaimlerChrysler’s chief executive said Monday. On Feb. 14, DaimlerChrysler said it was keeping all options open regarding the future of the Chrysler Group, leading to speculation about the prospects of a sale or a spinoff. Speaking during the Merrill Lynch Global Automotive Conference in Geneva, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said the same held true for the financing arm.

headline: Valuing a Public Blackstone
abstract: As reports emerge that buyout behemoth  Blackstone Group is considering an initial public offering, here is the multibillion-dollar question: What would a publicly traded Blackstone be worth? It is difficult to guess, because most of the private equity firm’s financial figures are, well, private. But a comparison with Fortress Investment Group, which recently opened its kimono as part of its highly successful I.P.O., gives some extremely rough guideposts.

headline: Top Credit Suisse Executive Joins Ripplewood Firm
abstract: Credit Suisse‘s head of Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Leonhard Fischer, has resigned to become co-chief executive at a holding company controlled by the private equity firm Ripplewood Holdings. His departure comes six weeks after one of Mr. Fischer’s colleagues was chosen as the Swiss bank’s next chief executive.

headline: Kerkorian Caught Up in Pellicano Wiretapping Case
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who controls MGM Mirage and led a failed bid to push General Motors into an alliance with Nissan and Renault, is more deeply involved in the federal case against the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano than previously known, according to The New York Times. The Times has tapes of telephone conversations between Mr. Pellicano, who is currently in jail awaiting trial, and Mr. Kerkorian’s long-time lawyer that suggest that Mr. Kerkorian was aware that the private detective was listening in on his ex-wife’s conversations.

headline: Merrill Lynch Tunes In to Australian TV Auction, Report Says
abstract: Merrill Lynch was looking at a possible bid for CanWest Global‘s stake in the Australian broadcaster Ten Network, Reuters reported. Canada’s CanWest has a 56.4 percent stake in Ten and had initially hoped to get up to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion) for the holding, but the sale has apparently made slow progress. Ten has a market value of about 3 billion Australian dollars, including the CanWest stake, based on the latest share price.

headline: New Charges in Russia Against Oil Executives
abstract: Russian prosecutors brought new charges Monday against the imprisoned founder of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent. The former executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, and his partner, Platon A. Lebedev, were charged with embezzlement and money laundering, which his lawyers said together could carry prison sentences of 15 years.

headline: Tribune Management Mulls Bid of Its Own, Report Says
abstract: Tribune‘s top management team is talking with private-equity companies about crafting a new deal to restructure the company and will likely begin discussing its ideas with the company’s special board committee Saturday in Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported. The newspaper said that the media company’s board has decided that the two offers tabled for the company by the Chandler family, Tribune’s largest shareholder, and the Los Angeles billionaires Eli Broad and Ron Burkle are too low.

headline: The Man Behind Pirate Capital
abstract: Magnum Global Investments is a former client of Pirate Capital, a Connecticut-based hedge fund. According to a lawsuit filed by Magnum, Pirate reneged on its promise to pay for steering it $28 million in investments. David Friedland, Magnum’s president, tells Bloomberg News that his firm’s relationship with Thomas Hudson, the chief Pirate, “got pretty ugly.” If, he said, “we’d known this was the kind of character he had, we wouldn’t have invested.”

headline: Deloitte Nominates New Chief Executive
abstract: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu‘s board nominated James. H. Quigley, head of its United States businesses, on Thursday to succeed its chief executive, William G. Parrett, who will step down in May. Mr. Quigley’s nomination is subject to a vote by member firm partners worldwide, the company, which is based in New York, said. The company also announced that John P. Connolly, chief of the British unit, would be the new chairman, succeeding Piet Hoogendoorn.

headline: Jefferies Executive Forced Out Following Scandal, Report Says
abstract: Jefferies & Co. reportedly forced out a longtime executive last week as it continues to clean house in the wake of its involvement in a travel and entertainment scandal with Fidelity Investments. While it was couched as a retirement, The New York Post reported that the departure of Jefferies’s veteran equity chief, Scott Jones, was anything but voluntary.

headline: Treasury Official to Resign
abstract: Emil W. Henry Jr., a former senior partner of Gleacher Partners, said Thursday he would resign as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Financial Institutions. He has held the position since October 2005. In a letter announcing his resignation, he said he was seeking to spend more time with his family in New York. While at Gleacher Partners, Mr. Henry oversaw the firm’s investment activities which included private equity and hedge-fund pools.

headline: Nonprofit Wikipedia Founder Now Looks for Profits
abstract: Wikipedia‘s founder, Jimmy Wales, has become a star with the non-profit online encyclopedia, now he is looking for gold with his latest venture, Wikia, writes Business 2.0. But the road to profits is apparently a somewhat rocky one for Mr. Wales, who now finds himself playing in a different league.

headline: Goldman and Morgan Eye Dominion Bid, Report Says
abstract: The investing arms of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are working on a $15 billion private-equity play for the oil-and-gas assets of the utility company Dominion Resources, The Wall Street Journal reported. Goldman and Morgan are said to be part of a consortium that includes the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, Warburg Pincus, First Reserve and the Carlyle Group and its affiliate Riverstone Holdings. The Journal said that it may end up bidding against a rival consortium, made up of Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which is also exploring an offer.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Siemens Still Sees Spinoff, Not Sale, of Auto Unit
abstract: Siemens said Tuesday it was sticking to its plan for an initial public offering of up to half of its automotive engineering unit despite interest from potential buyers. The comments came as The Financial Times reported that TRW Automotive is considering a bid for the Siemens division, which makes products including driver assistance devices and safety systems.

headline: Will Bondholders Play Spoiler in Blackstone Deal?
abstract: In a deal valued at $36 billion, quibbling over $100 million or so may seem absurd. But that is just what is happening in the background as Blackstone Group tries to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust in what would be the largest leverage buyout in history. A group of Equity Office’s bondholders, including insurance giant American International Group, say they are being shortchanged under a proposed debt buyback that would facilitate the sale. And at least one analyst points to the dispute as one of the reasons that Equity Office may be put back in play.

headline: Tales From the Caremark Files
abstract: There is nothing like a legal fight to draw out the inner workings of the normally secretive dealmaking process. TheStreet.com’s Melissa Davis examined the court filings in the battle over Caremark Rx‘s proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS and came up with two “major revelations” that seemed especially disturbing to the judge in the case. Express Scripts, which has made a hostile offer for Caremark, wants the court to block the CVS merger. The judge expects to rule on the matter next week.

headline: Cadbury’s Chocolate Craving Returns
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes has candy on the brain. Prodded by activist investor Nelson Peltz, the British company said earlier this month it would split off its beverage unit to focus on becoming a giant in the confections business. The announcement had many analysts speculating that both pieces of the company could be attractive takeover targets. But Cadbury Schweppes chief executive Todd Stitzer hinted at a different outcome this week, suggesting it would make sense for Cadbury to buy United States-based Hershey, something it unsuccessfully tried to do in 2002.

headline: Volkswagen Executive Confesses in Corruption Case
abstract: Volkswagen‘s former personnel chief may get a suspended sentence and a fine in exchange for a confession on breach of trust charges, the judge at his trial over a corruption scandal at the automaker said Wednesday. The former executive, Peter Hartz, is charged with 44 counts of breach of trust in the case, which has shone an unsavory light on the cozy relationship between the company’s management and labor representatives.

headline: Dolans Look to Malone after Second Cablevision Bid Rejection
abstract: Shortly after the rejection of their $8.9 billion second offer for Cablevision, the cable company’s ruling Dolan family might be looking to John Malone for some solace, The New York Post reports. Unnamed sources said that the failed bid poses an opportunity for the two sides to talk about selling part or all of the network’s Rainbow Media, home to the AMC and IFC channels, to Mr. Malone’s Liberty Media. As it previously reported, the Post said that the Dolans could use cash from the transaction to make a third run at Cablevision.

headline: The Overstock Story
abstract: The latest Overstock lawsuit costs the company a director.

headline: Goldman Names Investment Banking C.O.O.
abstract: Goldman Sachs named Gregg Lemkau chief operating officer of investment banking. He had been co-head of healthcare investment banking at the firm.

headline: Is One of Boston’s Stars on the Wane?
abstract: Convexity Capital Management, the record-setting hedge fund launched by former Harvard Management stars famous for beating the markets, apparently couldn’t keep up in 2006. Convexity’s $6 billion hedge fund offers clients a variety of investment strategies. Each earned about 4.5 percent less than their benchmark indexes in 2006, the fund’s first year of operation, according to the Boston Globe.

headline: McAfee’s Ex-Lawyer Indicted
abstract: The former top lawyer of McAfee was charged on Tuesday with stock options tampering that muddied the finances of the computer security software maker. A federal grand jury indicted the lawyer, Kent Roberts, nine months after McAfee fired him as its general counsel for “improper” handling of stock options issued in 2000. The indictment includes seven criminal counts of fraud, accusing Mr. Roberts of deceiving investors by filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and falsifying McAfee’s books.

headline: Forstmann Is Leader of the Pack at IMG
abstract: Forstmann Little‘s Teddy Forstmann has said that IMG, the sports, fashion, entertainment and media marketer, would be one of his last big acquisitions. To sell it at the steep profit he envisions, Mr. Forstmann has overhauled the ingrained agent culture nurtured in Cleveland by its founder, Mark H. McCormack, and is running it like a profit-driven, even obsessed, property.

headline: Live from New Orleans’ M&A Lawyer Confab
abstract: DealBook comes to you this morning from New Orleans, where Tulane University Law School’s 19th Annual Corporate Law Institute is just getting under way. Many of the nation’s most prominent deal lawyers, including Casey Cogut of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and Richard Katcher of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, are here to talk tactics and drink mint juleps. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Delaware’s Court of Chancery is here as well, and he is already talking about two of his favorite subjects: go shops and staple financing. We won’t dwell on the legal jargon, but we will bring you updates throughout the day and in tomorrow’s e-mail report.

headline: Spitzer Joins Call to Streamline Wall Street Rules
abstract: As New York’s attorney general, he was one of the most ardent defenders of heightened securities regulation. As the state’s new governor, however, Eliot Spitzer may be backtracking, or at least that is the suggestion of Tuesday’s article in The New York Post. Joining Sen. Chuck Schumer and New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday as they presented a new plan to streamline regulations, Mr. Spitzer said that he will do what it takes to keep Wall Street at the top of global finance.

headline: Taiwan Firm Sues Apple in Shuffle Skirmish
abstract: Luxpro, fresh from a legal victory against Apple Computer over whether its portable music players are ripoffs of Apple’s iPod Shuffle, is seeking $100 million in damages in the case.

headline: Genesis Agrees to $1.25 Billion Buyout
abstract: Genesis HealthCare, a nursing home operator, said Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium of private equity firms for about $1.25 billion. The joint venture, which includes affiliates from Formation Capital and JER Partners, will pay $63 a share (a premium of about 31 percent over Genesis shares’ average closing price over the past 30 trading days) and assume $450 million in debt.

headline: Citigroup Raises $3.3 Billion for Buyout Fund
abstract: Citigroup has raised $3.3 billion for private equity investments, highlighting the growing eagerness of Wall Street banks to take part in the high-risk, high-return boom in leveraged buyouts. The fresh pool of money, to be announced on Monday, exceeds the bank’s $2.5 billion target and includes commitments from clients and employees, as well as $1 billion of the bank’s own balance sheet. The fund, Citigroup Capital Partners II, will be used to strike deals in a variety of industries and regions alongside other private equity firms.

headline: Three Envelopes at Home Depot
abstract: Blaming the Old Boss at Home Depot

headline: TicketsNow Takes $34 Million in Funding
abstract: TicketsNow, an online ticket reseller, said Monday it closed its first round of venture funding, drawing $34 million from a group led by Adams Street Partners. The announcement came just a few weeks after eBay, the giant Web auctioneer, agreed to buy ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million.

headline: The Highs and Lows of a Biotech Deal
abstract: News about a merger in the world of immunoassays — that is, blood tests — has sent shares in one biotech company soaring and stock in another plummeting. Beckman Coulter said Sunday that it will buy Biosite, a maker of several blood tests, for $1.55 billion in cash, or $85 a share.

headline: Regulators Seek $210 Million Penalty From TXU
abstract: Texas state regulators are demanding $210 million in fines from the energy company TXU for allegedly manipulating the wholesale power market in 2005. It would mark the largest penalty ever proposed by the Texas Public Utility Commission’s staff. TXU, which is currently the subject of a $45 billion buyout proposal, called the accusations “flatly wrong” and said it planned to contest the findings.

headline: J.P. Morgan Wants to Be Hollywood’s Rainmaker
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase is going Hollywood — all the way. Already one of the major players in structuring and financing entertainment deals, the investment bank is planning a unit aimed at advising moviemakers on everything from financing arrangements to merchandising deals, according to The Wall Street Journal. The Journal noted that the plan is part of J.P. Morgan’s effort to grow its business without relying on acquisitions.

headline: Equity Office Bidding Battle Goes to a Vote
abstract: Going up?

headline: Chinese Bank Buys Indonesian Rival
abstract: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, which had a record initial public offering in October, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Bank Halim of Indonesia in its first such overseas purchase. Industrial & Commercial, which did not disclose the deal price, said it would buy 90 percent of Bank Halim and take an option to buy the rest from shareholders in three years.

headline: Building Materials Re-Raises ElkCorp Bid
abstract: In a quick turnaround, the Building Materials Corporation of America raised its offer for ElkCorp, a roofing products maker, to $43.50 a share, ElkCorp said in a regulatory filing. The increased offer extends a months-long battle with the Carlyle Group, which raised its offer to $42 on Monday, matching Building Materials’ previous bid. ElkCorp had previously recommended that shareholders accept the Carlyle offer.

headline: Veritas-S.E.C. Settlement for $30 Million
abstract: Securities regulators have fined Veritas Software, a business software maker, $30 million to settle accusations that the company engaged in an assortment of accounting schemes in the years leading to its sale to Symantec in 2005. The civil penalty, disclosed Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was announced four and a half years after regulators opened an inquiry into a deal that Veritas negotiated with AOL in 2000.

headline: V.C.’s Hedge Cleantech Bets with Fossil Fuels
abstract: Silicon Valley’s technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries’ dominance with its green-tech innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. The cry has been raised by some of the Valley’ most stored venture capital firms such as Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Its principals, John Doerr in particular, have passionately (and tearfully) advocated development of alternative energies as a way to create energy independence and clean up the carbon-saturated atmosphere.

headline: Nymex Abandoning Plans for British Futures Market
abstract: Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a lonely champion of open-outcry trading, is cutting its last ties to an ill-fated plan to set up a trading floor in Britain. The commodities market has quietly applied for “derecognition of exchange” with British regulators, traders in London said.

headline: Alliance Boots Rejects Buyout Bid
abstract: British pharmacy chain Alliance Boots rejected a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) buyout offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its own executive deputy chairman, saying the bid tabled only a few hours before was too low. Shares in Alliance Boots, formed last year from the merger of retailer Boots and drugs wholesaler Alliance Unichem, were up 7 percent at 997 pence.

headline: Taking on the Myths of Private Equity
abstract: Private equity is getting plenty of attention these days. Headlines routinely mention firms such as the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Texas Pacific Group, the Carlyle Group and Providence Equity Partners as they recount the latest record-breaking buyout or takeover of a well-known company.

headline: S.E.C. Files Insider Trading Suit in TXU Buyout
abstract: In the second major insider-trading case in as many days, federal regulators have charged several unnamed individuals with profiting illegally from advance knowledge of the $45 billion buyout of TXU, the largest L.B.O. ever. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit in Chicago, saying that several individuals used foreign brokerage firms in the transactions to cover their tracks. The agency said that the unnamed defendants “are in a position” to earn more than $5.3 million in profits.

headline: Prada Thinks an I.P.O. May Be in Fashion
abstract: The Italian fashion house Prada confirmed on Monday it could consider an initial public offering of its shares next year and said sales in 2006 probably rose 10 percent. “At this point, based on where we are it would make sense to go for an I.P.O. at some point, maybe next year,” a spokesman, Tomaso Galli, told Reuters after the company’s menswear fashion show. “We are reaching all our targets. So obviously we can now look at a potential I.P.O.,” he said. The chief executive, Patrizio Bertelli, said in November that the company could look again at a listing in 2008 but not in 2007.

headline: Under XM-Sirius Merger Plan, Potty Mouth Is Optional
abstract: The “shock jock” Howard Stern has been very important to the success of Sirius Satellite Radio. Subscriptions surged after he agreed to bring his raucous show to the service.

headline: Building a Better TiVo
abstract: Who is working to build a better DVR, the magical invention that lets us digitally record, pause and rewind TV?

headline: Televisa Gets Green Light for Mexican Cable Buy
abstract: Grupo Televisa, Mexico’s largest broadcaster, obtained conditional approval from antitrust regulators to buy a stake in a cable company in northern Mexico it plans to use to offer telephone services. Televisa will be allowed to buy 50 percent of Television Internacional de Monterrey on the condition that it offers its free channels to all pay-TV providers nationwide, Mexico’s Federal Competition Commission said in an e-mail Sunday.

headline: Viacom Sues Google for $1 Billion
abstract: Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of “massive copyright infringement.” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.

headline: BofA Seeks a Lift on Deposit Caps
abstract: Bank of America has begun a push to raise a regulatory cap that bars any bank in the United States from an acquisition that would give it more than 10 percent of the nation’s total bank deposits, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The company has argued that United States banks are artificially small and vulnerable to foreign acquirers, the Journal said. It said the bank last year won support for changing the policy in votes before the North Carolina Bankers Association and the New Hampshire Bankers Association. Bank of America has also approached bankers in Massachusetts and other states to support potential legislation this spring in Congress, the Journal reported.

headline: NYSE Chief Says Tide Will Turn on Private Equity
abstract: John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, offered up some sobering words Friday about the explosive rise of private equity, which has swept many publicly traded companies off of the world’s major exchanges. He said, in effect: They’ll come back to us.

headline: Canadian Banks Chided for Timid Approach to China
abstract: China wants Canadian banks to abandon their timid approach to the Asian market of 1.3 billion consumers and instead step up investment there, the Canadian finance minister, Jim Flaherty, said Sunday, passing on advice that he underlined should be heeded. “One of the things I heard from officials in China is that our financial services sector – particularly our banks – have probably been too conservative, not aggressive enough, in the China market,” Mr. Flaherty said during a conference call with reporters at the end of a week-long trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

headline: NovaVision Scores $20 Million Third Round
abstract: NovaVision, a developer of neurological therapy technology, raised $20 million in a third round of funding, which it will use to expand its network of stroke and brain trauma treatment centers. Late-stage venture investor Chicago Growth Partners led the round.

headline: Judge Drops KPMG Charge in Tax Case
abstract: A federal judge has dismissed a criminal charge accusing KPMG, the accounting firm, of conspiring to sell illegal tax shelters, after prosecutors said that the firm had met its obligations under a 2005 deferred-prosecution agreement.

headline: I.B.M. Selling Printer Unit to Japanese Firm
abstract: The Japanese office equipment maker Ricoh will buy I.B.M.‘s digital commercial printer operations for about $700 million in April, the Nikkei reported. The acquisition, Ricoh’s largest ever, will make the firm the No. 1 player in the growing market for devices used by companies to print contracts and other documents quickly and in large volumes, the report said.

headline: Revolving Door: Greenhill, Gibson Dunn
abstract: The turnaround veteran Martin F. Lewis joined Greenhill & Company as a managing director to help the New York-based investment bank expand its restructuring practice. Mr. Lewis recently worked at middle-market investment bank Rhone Group and before that was a name partner at Miller Buckfire, a firm that frequently advises bankrupt and financially distressed companies.

headline: Tribune May Reject Outside Bids
abstract: The Tribune Company indicated over the weekend that it might reshape its future without outside help. On the auction block since last fall, the company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and other media properties, received three bids last week for all or part of the company.

headline: Two Charged in Payments From Wagers on Internet
abstract: Two founders of a company that processes Internet gambling transactions were arrested and charged with laundering billions of dollars in gambling proceeds, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday. The charges were filed against John David Lefebvre, 55, and Stephen Eric Lawrence, 46, who founded the company, Neteller, in 1999, in two criminal complaints unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday, Michael J. Garcia, a United States attorney, said in a statement.

headline: Hedge Fund Has InFocus Board in Its Sights
abstract: A hedge fund, Caxton Associates, has raised its stake in InFocus, a provider of digital protection technology, in a move that might signal a proxy battle. Caxton said in a filing that it had raised its stake to 11.2 percent from 9.9 percent after discussions with InFocus management in the fourth quarter of last year had yielded unsatisfactory results.

headline: Trial Begins for Ex-Chief of Hollinger
abstract: Two wildly different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented to the jury in opening arguments Tuesday at the criminal trial of the former newspaper baron and three colleagues. In the version put forward by a prosecutor, Lord Black is a thief who is different from a bank robber only in that his methods involve artfully worded memoranda and he wears suits and ties.

headline: U.S. Freezes Assets in Latvia in Stock Inquiry
abstract: United States securities regulators obtained an emergency court order freezing $3 million of proceeds in a Latvian account suspected of being used to hack into online brokerage accounts and manipulate stock trading.

headline: Did Hedge Funds Fall, or Just Stumble?
abstract: Is it possible that hedge funds, the media stars du jour, may have lost a little of their shine lately? Data from two reports suggests that may be the case — at least, temporarily. Bloomberg News writes of a new study by Hedge Fund Research showing that hedge fund inflows dropped 64 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006. And a separate report by Spectrem found that among the wealthiest investors, investment in that $1.3 trillion asset class dropped by more than 10 percent.

headline: Macquarie to Buy Spirit Finance
abstract: Spirit Finance, a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said on Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium led by Australia’s Macquarie Bank for about $1.6 billion. The group offered $14.50 per share in cash, a premium of about 11 percent over Spirit Finance’s closing price of $13.05 on Monday. The deal is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, Spirit Finance said, though a provision lets it solicit other bids through April 9.

headline: Auction Is Set for Air America
abstract: Air America Radio, the liberal news and talk radio network, has won bankruptcy court approval to sell its assets at an auction Friday, starting with a $4.25 million bid from a consortium of purchasers formed by Stephen L. Green, the chairman of SL Green Realty of New York.

headline: Talk of a Dow Partnership Stirs up Buyout Talk
abstract: As rumors of a buyout dance around Dow Chemicals, the chemical giant is in talks with India’s Reliance Industries to create a joint venture that would reduce its exposure to the volatile commodity chemicals market. The Financial Times said that reports have suggested that a deal might lead to a takeover of Dow by Reliance, India’s largest public company, sending shares up 5 percent. But unnamed sources told the F.T. that such speculation was untrue.

headline: EMI Tries Luring Private Equity to the Table, Report Says
abstract: Is EMI trying to cook up a bidding war after receiving the latest takeover offer from Warner Music Group? According to The New York Post, buyout shops Apollo Management and Permira Advisors have resurfaced as potential suitors for EMI, but the paper said that a new bid from the private equity groups seemed unlikely.

headline: At Blockbuster, 28% Profit Dip and Dispute Over the Chief’s Pay
abstract: Blockbuster, which on Tuesday reported a 28 percent decline in its fourth-quarter earnings, said it was trying to resolve a dispute with its chairman and chief executive, John F. Antioco, over his 2006 bonus. On Jan. 25, the board of the movie rental company awarded Mr. Antioco a bonus of $2.28 million, on top of his 2006 salary and deferred compensation of about $2.5 million. But according to a statement in the company’s earnings report, Mr. Antioco claims he is entitled to a total of $10.15 million.

headline: Chandler Bid Packs Big Payments for Tribune Executives
abstract: If Tribune is sold to the Chandler family, some executives could walk away with compensation totaling an estimated $269 million, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the family, which formerly owned the Times, notes a change of control payments. While it does not say how many executives would be eligible, the paper says that Tribune’s chief executive, Dennis J. FitzSimons; publishing president, Scott C. Smith; and broadcasting president, John E. Reardon, are among those eligible if they are dismissed within three years of a Chandler takeover.

headline: Boston Scientific Considers $1 Billion Spinoff
abstract: There is more to Boston Scientific than the troubled heart stent and defibrillator businesses for which it is best known – enough that the company predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion to the public. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said yesterday that it was considering a public stock offering for 18 percent to 25 percent of those other businesses, which are grouped under its Endosurgery division.

headline: Aerovance Secures $32 Million V.C. Round
abstract: Aerovance, a drug maker, said Tuesday that Clarus Ventures had agreed to provide $32 million of financing that will allow it to independently pursue a clinical trial of its asthma drug Aerovant later this year. Aerovance is continuing to seek partnerships with pharmaceutical companies in support of trials that would give the partner licensing rights to Aerovant. The new funding will give Aerovance more freedom to select a partner for the drug’s marketing and sales.

headline: Acquisition Ban Lifted at Career Education
abstract: The Career Education Corporation, which operates more than 80 campuses in the United States and overseas, said Monday that the Education Department lifted a ban imposed in June 2005 that limited acquisitions and expansion. The Education Department said eight months ago that it was satisfied with the results of a financial audit review at Career Education that prompted the restriction. The company’s founder, John Larson, retired in December.

headline: Bidding for ElkCorp Heats Up
abstract: The bidding for the roofing products maker ElkCorp heated up Thursday, with the Building Materials Corporation of America raising its bid to $865.2 million, topping a $834 million offer by a private equity firm, the Carlyle Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Building Materials said it had raised its offer for ElkCorp to $42 a share in cash, from an earlier $40. Earlier in the day, Carlyle said it had started a tender offer on its previously disclosed bid of $40.50 a share.

headline: EGL Board to Seek Other Bids
abstract: EGL, a manager of freight services for companies, said a board committee authorized its financial adviser to seek bids in addition to a management-led $1.2 billion buyout offer. The adviser, Deutsche Bank Securities, began reviewing options even before the chief executive, James Crane, lost his equity sponsor, General Atlantic, last week, Houston-based EGL said Monday.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Google, Trade Talks, Dark Rooms
abstract: The World Economic Forum in Davos has yet to start and already reports are surfacing about the first deal to be announced there. The Guardian wrote Monday that the British Broadcasting Company was in talks with Google to make programming available through a branded channel on YouTube, the video site the Internet giant bought last year for $1.65 billion.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Why Blackstone Might Go Public
abstract: Blackstone Group‘s reasons for considering a initial public offering probably include a desire for a way for insiders to cash out more easily, as well as a bit of hubris, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner. “Having the biggest market capitalization and making the first splash could be worth more than the purely financial reward to someone who already has all the money he could ever want,” Mr. Weidner writes.

headline: Ravelston to Pay $7 Million in Fraud Plea
abstract: Ravelston, the Toronto-based holding company once controlled by the fallen newspaper baron Conrad Black, pleaded guilty Monday to one count of fraud and agreed to pay a $7 million fine. Mr. Black, a Canadian-born media mogul and a British lord, had sought to block the company from agreeing to a plea, arguing it would ruin his chances of a fair trial. A Canadian judge disagreed.

headline: Tata Would Have Gone Higher on Corus Bid
abstract: In what can’t possibly be music to Corus shareholders’ ears, Indian steel magnate Ratan Tata has said he would have been prepared to pay even more to clinch control of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker. In an interview with The Times Of India today, the chairman of Tata group said: “Let me put it this way. At 608 pence ($11.97), we hadn’t reached the limit we had set ourselves.”

headline: Motorola: How Far Will Icahn Go?
abstract: Carl C. Icahn’s announcement Tuesday that he would be seeking a seat on Motorola‘s board had industry observers wondering what the well-known activist investor was up to this time. Motorola shares jumped 6.9 percent, to $19.58, in a sign that investors hoped Mr. Icahn might force a showdown with Motorola to make significant changes.

headline: The Mystery of the Private-Equity Populists
abstract: Why are so many billionaires speaking out lately about income inequality and the plight of the middle class? Trend-mongering is part of it, to be sure. But Slate’s Daniel Gross also sees something else at work: fear that the hoi-polloi are mad as hell, and soon won’t take it anymore. Should the middle class face continued hardship — while “economic royalists” like Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group keep growing richer — the free trade of goods, services and capital will lose political support. And who else does that hurt?

headline: Superpowers and Blogger Power
abstract: This year’s overarching theme at Davos — the “shifting power equation” — apparently means many things to the throngs gathered here. For some, it crystallized a growing concern that established institutions are losing power. Rogue states and nonstate actors threaten disorder on the global stage, which could take the form of weapons proliferation, terrorism or the spread of AIDS and other deadly diseases. These threats “create an environment in which the things we treasure cannot prosper,” Richard N. Haas, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, said in a panel Wednesday called “The Shifting Power Equation: Geopolitics.”

headline: Scripps May Spin Off Newspapers
abstract: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company. E. W. Scripps, the parent company of The Rocky Mountain News, The Commercial Appeal in Memphis and 18 other dailies, told an investor conference Wednesday that it was exploring separating its newspaper business from its more profitable cable television and syndication ventures.

headline: Bank Analyst Leaves Prudential for Deutsche
abstract: Michael Mayo, the outspoken analyst who runs the financial-services research team for the Prudential Equity Group, is leaving to join Deutsche Bank. Mr. Mayo, who has been at Prudential since 2001, will bring his five-person team to Deutsche, where they will continue to cover financial stocks.

headline: Shell Mulls Boosting Offer for Canadian Unit, Report Says
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell is dangling the prospect of a 15 percent-plus bump in its offer to buy oil patch subsidiary Shell Canada for C$7.7 billion ($6.6 billion), if minority shareholders agree to support its takeover bid, The Globe and Mail reported. Apparently frustrated in its attempts to drum up interest in a 40-Canadian-dollars -a-share offer made in October, and fearing a nasty takeover battle, Royal Dutch has been quietly meeting with the biggest shareholders in its Calgary-based offspring in recent weeks, the report said. Money managers in Toronto and Calgary told the newspaper that the parent company is holding out the promise of $46 to $48 a share if institutions agree to commit their shares.

headline: An Investment Banking Love Story
abstract: How does a harried investment banker send love notes? By BlackBerry, of course.

headline: Many Are Eager to See Data on Chrysler
abstract: As JPMorgan Chase prepares an investment book to circulate to potential bidders of Chrysler, American and foreign auto companies, private equity groups and investment banks are chomping at the bit to inspect the struggling company’s financial data. “Everybody will take a look,” a senior executive at a global car company, which will be eyeballing the book, told The New York Times.

headline: The notMac Challenge
abstract: An open-sourcey effort is afoot to develop a free alternative to Apple’s “dot Mac” service.

headline: The View From 1,650 Meters
abstract: World leaders and corporate chiefs will spend the next few days in Davos debating issues that affect billions of people — the global economy, climate change and energy, just to name a few — in what the World Economic Forum describes as an attempt to set the global agenda.

headline: SAC’s (Teddy) Bearish Investment
abstract: Who says hedge funds can’t be warm and fuzzy? SAC Capital, the large and secretive investment pool run by Steven A. Cohen, made a regulatory filing Monday disclosing that the fund and its affiliates owned a 5 percent stake in Build-a-Bear Workshop, a publicly traded company that sells custom-made plush toys such as the “Taking Care of Business” bear, which comes complete with two-piece suit and black briefcase.

headline: Industry Ventures Bags $105 Million for New Fund
abstract: A secondary fund operator, Industry Ventures, raised $105 million in committed capital for its fourth fund aimed at buying up venture capital investments from corporate portfolios, liquidating funds and special situation investors looking for early liquidity.

headline: Going Private to Get a Raise?
abstract: Private equity firms have been offering compensation on an unprecedented scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that they have bought out. Could that be why so many companies are choosing to go private these days? If, so, “we would have a more serious problem than I thought,” Representative Barney Frank recently said, “because that would be elevating the private interests of the C.E.O. above every other consideration.”

headline: Watchwords at Chrysler Are Hurry Up and Wait
abstract: One week after DaimlerChrysler signaled its plans to put the Chrysler Group on the auction block, the company indicated on Thursday that it might be weeks or months before the future of the ailing American automaker can be determined. That word came in an e-mail message sent to employees by the Chrysler chief executive, Thomas W. LaSorda, which the company posted on a media Web site.

headline: Want to Buy a Hedge Fund? Try eBay
abstract: Last year brought us “Hedge Funds For Dummies.” Now comes another potential sign of the frothiness in the business of hedge funds, which are investment pools for wealthy and institutional investors. Available on eBay for a minimum of $70,000 is what claims to be a “full authorized and operative” hedge fund, offered by someone in Italy with the eBay handle “hdgfund.”

headline: S.E.C. Is Silent on H.P. Proxy Fight
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission declined to take a stand on Monday on a request from Hewlett-Packard to exclude from its proxy ballot a proposal from some shareholders that would give them more power to nominate directors.

headline: Credit Suisse Names Head of European M&A
abstract: A few months after announcing his resignation as HSBC‘s European head of investment banking, David Livingstone has resurfaced as Credit Suisse‘s head of mergers and acquisitions in Europe. Mr. Livingstone started his new position in Credit Suisse’s London office on Monday, the firm said. Susan Kilsby, who had been Credit Suisse’s head of European M&A since 2002, was named chairman of European M&A at the investment bank, Credit Suisse said Monday.

headline: Greenberg’s P.R. Firm Sues for $2 Million
abstract: A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenberg’s company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Second Life, W.T.O. Talks, C.E.O. Pay
abstract: Virtual world Second Life is a hot topic at the World Economic Forum this year, according to The Independent. Indeed, even the forum’s founder and chairman, Klaus Schwab, has his own avatar, or virtual identity, and Reuters is conducting interviews with major players at Davos at its virtual bureau in the Second Life realm.

headline: Activist Fund Steps Down from New Century’s Board
abstract: Amid an implosion in the subprime mortgage market, David Einhorn is resigning from the board of New Century Financial. The hedge fund manager, who runs Greenlight Capital, is leaving the company as it faces an inquiry into its accounting and mounting credit problems. The company made Mr. Einhorn a director last March after Greenlight Capital, a $4.7 billion fund and New Century’s second-largest shareholder, threatened to wage a proxy fight.

headline: At a Billionaire’s Bash, Some Jokes Fell Short
abstract: Friday brought yet more canape-by-canape accounts of the 60th birthday celebration for Blackstone Group chairman Stephen Schwarzman, plus all kinds of analysis about where the bash sits in the pantheon of hot New York parties. David Patrick Columbia’s New York Social Diary has an especially detailed rundown of the event, reporting that there were some uncomfortably “raunchy” jokes from comedian Martin Short as well as some unfortunate seating decisions.

headline: India’s Power Finance Plans I.P.O.
abstract: Indian state-owned Power Finance has confirmed its intention to raise up to $225 million from the first sizable initial public offering in the Indian market this year. The announcement came as the Mumbai benchmark index closed at a record high after it finished above 14,000 points for the first time on Friday. Power Finance, which provides financing for Indian power and infrastructure projects within both the public and private sectors, will sell 117.3 million new shares at a price between 73 rupees and 85 rupees apiece.

headline: A Case of Gay Bias or Thin Skin?
abstract: There is little question that the comments allegedly made by Aaron Charney’s boss at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell — if he made them — were rude and juvenile. It is far less clear whether they were discriminatory, Robert Kolker suggests in his article on Mr. Charney and the lawsuit he filed against the firm, which appears in this week’s New York magazine. The story is just the latest account of a legal battle that has generated intense debate about office culture at a top New York law firm.

headline: Equity Office Bids May Go Higher, Analysts Say
abstract: As the biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger Thursday when the Blackstone Group increased its bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to a whopping $54 a share, market watchers fell over themselves trying to guess if a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust would be forced to up its bid. But even more than that, analysts and other industry watchers, who can sometimes take a been-there-done-that attitude toward bidding battles, seemed on the edge of their ringside seats, caught up in the high-stakes (and high-price) war for the nation’s largest office landlord, with nearly 600 buildings across the country.

headline: Hedge Fund Shoppers or Status Seekers?
abstract: It is not so surprising that some of the most-expensive hedge funds — as measured by the fees they charge — can deliver below-average returns. After all, anyone can have a bad year (or two). The more remarkable part about Financial News’ recent analysis of hedge funds with high fees is the suggestion that investors, who are mainly institutions and wealthy individuals, sometimes intentionally avoid funds that charge lower fees, preferring the cachet of a top-dollar fund even if its recent performance is lackluster.

headline: Subprime Mortgage Woes May Haunt Cerberus
abstract: As the market reels from the implosion of the subprime mortgage market, taking down profits at banking giants like HSBC, another notable company could face trouble. The New York Post reports that Cerberus Capital Management‘s 51 percent stake in GMAC could pose problems for the investment firm, along with its partners Citigroup and Aozora Bank.

headline: Madison Dearborn Sells Pizza Chain
abstract: Madison Dearborn Partners has sold Peter Piper Pizza, a restaurant chain, to Acon Investments for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported. Peter Piper said its annual revenue is expected to exceed $200 million in 2007.

headline: Proxy Season Preview: Pay in the Crosshairs
abstract: Last year was a contentious one for corporate governance and shareholder proposals. What will 2007 bring? Institutional Shareholder Services, one of the main proxy advisory firms, has issued its 2007 Proxy Season Watch List, which offers some clues. One notable statistic: There are 39 shareholder proposals so far that would link executive pay more closely to a company’s performance, compared with just 17 such proposals in last year’s proxy season.

headline: Short-Sellers and the Companies That Hate Them
abstract: An inquiry by the Justice Department into pretexting allegations at Allied Capital raises questions about how far companies may be going to fight hedge funds that have sold their stocks short. Allied, a business development company that provides financing to smaller firms, said Tuesday that federal prosecutors had subpoenaed documents in an effort to discover how private investigators it hired may have obtained the phone records of David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager and one of its leading critics.

headline: Frank Talk on Hedge Funds
abstract: As the new chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, Barney Frank has much of Wall Street bending his ear these days. But his office has fielded few calls from hedge fund managers — and he says he is not surprised.

headline: The SAC and Icahn: Different Styles Linked by Investments
abstract: SAC Capital, the giant hedge fund run by Steven Cohen, has recently invested in some of the same companies as the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, a coincidence that The New York Post said links investors with very different styles.

headline: Xerox Sells Coporate Headquarters
abstract: Xerox has sold its corporate headquarters to a developer in Norwalk, Conn., for $54.8 million. The sale to a division of Building and Land Technology closed Friday. It came less than two months after the company announced plans to leave its office complex at 800 Long Ridge Road.

headline: In da Car at Dakar
abstract: No, I’m nowhere near the cars of the Dakar rally. But I will be following this as a fan. The race started today, and for the moment, it looks as if Volkswagen is ready to crush all competition after taking the top five spots of the first stage.

headline: Another Prosecutor Moves to the Greener Pastures of Private Law
abstract: Former Enron prosecutor Kathy Ruemmler has joined the law firm of Latham & Watkins in Washington, D.C., confirming speculation that she would follow some of her former colleagues into private practice — and a higher income bracket. Ms. Ruemmler was one of three Assistant U.S. Attorneys who took leading roles in the 2004 Enron Nigerian barge case and the criminal trial of former Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay last year. The move again puts her in the same office as her ex-boss, former Enron Task Force chief Sean Berkowitz, who joined Latham in November.

headline: Bank of America Bids Adieu to Venture Arm
abstract: Scale Venture Partners is saying adios to Bank of America as it closes its second fund. The former venture arm of Bank of America (BA Venture Partners) said Wednesday that because of high demand from outside investors to participate in the $400 million fund, the bank made a graceful exit from the fund.

headline: Ex-Secretary at Coke Guilty of Trade-Secrets Theft
abstract: A federal jury rejected a former Coca-Cola secretary’s claim that she was duped by two accomplices and convicted her on Friday of conspiring to steal trade secrets from the world’s largest beverage maker in an effort to sell them to its rival, Pepsi. The former secretary, Joya Williams, showed no visible reaction when the verdict was announced. She remains free on bond, pending sentencing.

headline: Helicos BioSciences Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Helicos BioSciences, a venture-backed biotechnology company, filed late Wednesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering. Helicos’s current shareholders include Flagship Ventures and Highland Capital Partners.

headline: Volvo Drives Off With Nissan Diesel
abstract: The Swedish truck maker Volvo said on Tuesday it would take over Nissan Diesel Motor for $1.1 billion. Volvo, which currently owns 19 percent of Nissan Diesel, said it would acquire the rest of the stock for 540 yen a share ($4.51), a premium of 22 percent over Monday’s closing price.

headline: As Fund Grows, Providence Cuts Fees
abstract: Providence Equity Partners is gearing up to play with the big boys. The media buyout specialist is looking to triple its fund size, and, in doing so, has agreed to cut its carried interest, or percentage of the fund’s profits, to 20 percent from 25 percent, according to press reports. The firm promised at the outset to do so if the new fund exceeded its initial $8 billion soft target, The Deal.com reported. And now it is now raising up to $12 billion, after recently holding a first close at $8 billion. The move puts Providence among $10 billion-plus mega-funds raised by the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Citi Says It Won’t Raise Nikko Offer Again
abstract: After raising its offer for the Japanese brokerage Nikko Cordial by 26 percent on Tuesday, Citigroup said Wednesday that its offer is final. The boards of the two companies agreed to raise the tender offer price to 1,700 yen ($14.40) a share, from last week’s initial bid of 1,350 yen ($11.44) a share after it was rejected by some of Nikko’s largest shareholders.

headline: TV in Your Car…at 80 Miles Per Hour
abstract: Samsung says it has the solution to making sure that you will never have to be without “Desperate Housewives.”

headline: Ameriquest Looks for Hedge-Fund Buyer, Reports Say
abstract: Ameriquest, the largest subprime mortgage lender in the United States, may be sold to a bond hedge fund as it and its competitors face an increasingly difficult business environment, reports said. J.P. Morgan Securities, which owns the lender, has approached several buyers recently, including Ellington Capital Management, a $4.5 billion fund with a specialty in hedging mortgage credit risk. Sources told The New York Post that Ellington executives have not yet decided if they want to receive an offering circular. A price has not been given.

headline: My Plane’s Bigger Than Your Plane
abstract: Do you want a giant jet of your very own?

headline: Home Depot’s New C.E.O. to Receive $8.9 Million
abstract: Home Depot may pay its chief executive, Frank Blake $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert Nardelli, who was ousted this month amid criticism of his compensation. Mr. Blake, who took over Jan. 2, received a base salary of $975,000. He will get the rest if he meets the board’s profit and stock performance goals, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Bank Settles Shelter Suits by Investors
abstract: Deutsche Bank has reached a settlement with hundreds of wealthy investors who bought aggressive tax shelters, a major shift in how it is dealing with the legal woes surrounding its tax shelter work.

headline: Altria Expected to Announce Kraft Spin-Off This Week
abstract: The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. Altria, which acquired Kraft in 1988 for $13.1 billion cash, will release details of what will be one of the largest tax-free corporate spin-offs on the day it reports fourth-quarter earnings, The newspaper said. It added that Altria is likely to spin its 88.6 percent stake in Kraft by giving its shareholders 1.46 billion Kraft shares.

headline: Review Clears Bristol-Myers
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, has been cleared of securities law violations in connection with its botched Plavix patent settlement last year, the company said on Monday in a regulatory filing. The company said that it has been informed by the United States attorney in Newark, Christopher J. Christie, that a review found no violation of securities laws or breach of an earlier consent order the company had signed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Turning a Statistic On Its Head
abstract: A critic of Sarbanes Oxley gets the numbers wrong.

headline: New Angle on the New Ferrari
abstract: The “launch” of the new Ferrari came complete with highly controlled photos. The only photos we have come from something Ferrari took in the workshop. Anyone notice that the innovative front suspension and especially the innovative rear of the car are not really visible?

headline: Morgan Stanley Poaches Rivals for Latin America Office
abstract: Morgan Stanley hired eight people from Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch for its Latin American private wealth division, bringing total additions at the unit to 27 so far this year.

headline: Private Equity Sets Record Pace in 2007
abstract: If you thought that private equity funds would slow down after last year’s rapid-fire dealmaking, think again.

headline: No French Grand Prix in 2008?
abstract: Following races in Belgium, Germany and Italy, the French Grand Prix may take a sabbatical next year, according to a statement today from the Federation Française de Sport Automobile, and as I pointed out last week after reading an interview with Bernie Ecclestone in AutoHebdo.

headline: Two Online Gambling Sites Hold Merger Talks
abstract: Sportingbet, the British online gambling company, is in takeover talks with the Austrian online bookmaker Bwin. Sportingbet was forced by the Britain’s Takeover Panel to issue a statement Wednesday confirming the talks after deal rumors swept the market and set off a sharp rise in the company’s share price.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Regulators Fine Specialists
abstract: The regulatory arm of the New York Stock Exchange said Tuesday that it had fined seven specialist firms a combined $2.8 million for trading violations. NYSE Regulation said that the specialists violated the so-called “firm quote” rule. The rule requires specialist firms execute buy or sell orders that are presented to them at prices that are at least as favorable as the N.Y.S.E.’s published bid or offer at the time the orders enter the N.Y.S.E.’s electronic-display book. The specialists also were censured.

headline: The Death of Trade: Greatly Exaggerated?
abstract: Behold the good tidings of Davos: That wave of protectionism you heard about is a mirage.

headline: Prospective Jurors Questioned in Case Against Former Qwest Chief
abstract: Jury selection began on Monday in the $101 million insider trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, who watched prospective jurors and actively consulted with lawyers.

headline: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
abstract: Ah, the corporate jet. Like $6,000 shower curtains and the nickname Kenny Boy, the corporate jet lives large in the public imagination, writes The New York Times’ David Carr. And it may be the reason, he suggests, that the ethically questionable relationship between Maria Bartiromo, the popular anchor on the business news channel CNBC, and the ousted Citigroup executive, Todd S. Thomson, has garnered so much attention.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table.
