Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Hyundai Chief, Awaiting Appeal, to Stay on Job
abstract: The chairman of Hyundai Motor, sentenced on Monday to three years in prison for embezzling corporate funds, will continue to run the corporation while his case is appealed. The presiding judge, Kim Dong-oh, said that the chairman, Chung Mong-koo, committed a “clearly criminal act” by raising and using “a large-scale secretive fund” that “greatly undermines the transparency and soundness of business management and has many adverse effects on our business culture.”

headline: A Kinder Telecom Market Sparks I.P.O. Chatter
abstract: Despite the fall from grace that initial public offerings of telecommunications companies took following the tech bust in 1999, some brave souls are once again eyeing the public markets. MetroPCS Wireless, which filed for bankruptcy in the 1990s and canceled a planned I.P.O. in 2004 due to accounting problems, is now hoping to raise $1.2 billion when it goes public in the next few months.

headline: CBOT Green Lights Talks With ICE
abstract: CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Bord of Trade, and IntercontinentalExchange, the energy derivatives market, are moving quickly after a proposal on Thursday by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion. The parent of the Chicago exchange said Monday that its board had authorized talks with ICE, adding it had not changed a recommendation that shareholders vote next month in favor of a merger struck with CME Holdings, parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Egyptian Billionaire Takes Control of Greece’s TIM Hellas
abstract: An Egyptian billionaire, Naguib Sawiris, agreed Wednesday to buy TIM Hellas Telecommunications from two buyout firms in a deal that valued the Greek cellphone company at about 3.4 billion euros and extended his reach in Europe. The deal provides an exit for sellers Apax Partners Worldwide and the Texas Pacific Group, which bought TIM Hellas two years ago for 1.4 billion euros. Mr. Sawiris, through his holding company, Weather Investments, will pay 500 million euros, or $650 million, and take on 2.9 billion euros in debt.

headline: Cablevision Buyout Offer Is a Drag, Analyst Says
abstract: A takeover bid is usually seen as something that props up a company’s share price. But a Pali Research analyst, Richard Greenfield, argues that just the reverse is true for Cablevision, the giant cable operator. In a research report on Friday, he suggests that Cablevision’s stock is worth far more than what its controlling family, the Dolans, has said it is willing to pay.

headline: LVMH Said to Buy Aston Martin
abstract: LVMH, the French conglomerate that owns luxury brands such as Louis Vuitton and Fendi, may be adding Aston Martin to its collection as well. MarketWatch said that the German trade publication Autobild was expected to report Friday that LVMH is set to buy Aston Martin, the British sports-car maker that is part of Ford Motor‘s Premium Automotive Group. A spokesman for the Premium Automotive Group told Dow Jones Newswires that the sale process for Aston Martin was “ongoing.”

headline: Skype Founders Start a YouTube Rival
abstract: The founders of Skype and Kazaa, Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom, have chosen a name for their new online-video start-up: Joost. The start-up had been dubbed “The Venice Project” by company executives before the the duo came up with the name, which they apparently chose because they liked the ring of it. Joost plans to offer studios, cable stations and anyone else who wants to distribute high-quality video over the Internet, a fast, efficient and cheap distribution method. The site will rely on the peer-to-peer technology that helped Mr. Friis and Mr. Zennstrom build Skype and Kazaa, in an effort to compete in the increasingly crowded online video market.

headline: Flames Flare Over Naked Shorts
abstract: Unsuspecting readers of certain stock message boards may be forgiven for believing they have stumbled into a flame war among 14-year-old boys. But the increasingly vicious online dispute actually involves, among others, the chief executive of a publicly traded corporation and a longtime business journalist.

headline: Citigroup Makes Cutbacks in Japan
abstract: Citigroup will shut about 270 consumer finance branches and 100 loan machines in Japan after a new local law capped the interest rate nonbank lenders can charge. Citigroup increased its loan-loss reserves by $375 million and said costs related to the closings would total another $40 million. The actions will cut Citigroup’s fourth-quarter profit by 8 cents a share, a spokeswoman, Shannon Bell, said.

headline: New Blow to Milberg Weiss Under Inquiry
abstract: A few years before he faked the theft of two works of art from his home in Brentwood, Calif., Steven G. Cooperman, a former ophthalmologist, received a personal check from a partner of the law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad for $175,000 as an “option payment” on one of those works, Picasso’s “Nude Before a Mirror.”

headline: Bear and UBS Subpoenaed Over Subprime Research
abstract: Massachusetts Secretary of State William F. Galvin said Tuesday he had ordered UBS Securities and Bear Stearns to turn over documents concerning their analysts’ recommendations on subprime lenders such as New Century Financial. Among the questions that Mr. Galvin is examining is whether these banks’ analysts published positive research on New Century, whose stock has plunged as problems in the home mortgage market have emerged, to bolster other financial relationships at the banks, The Boston Globe reported.

headline: Floating Away From New York
abstract: It was a hardly a bad year for the NYSE Group, whose shares have roughly doubled since June. But 2006 did bring one unhappy milestone for the NYSE, which operates the New York Stock Exchange. Thomson Financial notes that for the first time ever, the NYSE’s New York Stock Exchange was bested in the global market for initial public offerings. Both the London Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange were bigger venues for public floats in 2006, as measured by the volume of proceeds raised, the research firm said.

headline: After Brief Hospital Stay, Kozlowski Returns to Prison
abstract: The former chairman of Tyco International, Dennis Kozlowski, returned to prison Thursday after being hospitalized, according to a prison spokeswoman. Mr. Kozlowski is currently being housed in the Mid-State Correctional Facility’s infirmary in New York, after being treated for an undisclosed ailment. Mr. Kozlowksi is serving a sentence of 8-1/3 to 25 years after being found guilty in June 2005 of looting the company.

headline: MySQL Mulls I.P.O.
abstract: MySQL, one of the leading open source database vendors, is preparing itself for an initial public offering and could be ready to go public before the end of the year, the Swedish company’s chief executive, Marten Mickos, told Computer Business Review. “We are planning to go public,” Mr. Mickos told the publication. However, he added that the company was in no hurry to go public after raising $18.5 million in venture capital at the beginning of last year.

headline: Yet More Musings on a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
abstract: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.

headline: Merrill Hires Former Citigroup Exec for China
abstract: Merrill Lynch hired Margaret Ren, a former Citigroup executive, as chairman of China investment banking after regulators in the United States cleared her of wrongdoing in a 2003 initial public offering. Ms. Ren, the daughter-in-law of former Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang, will report to the China region chairman, Liu Erh-fei and the Asia banking head, Sheldon Trainor.

headline: Lawyers Make Hay Out of Hedge Fund Activism
abstract: Activist and dissident shareholders, particularly hedge funds, are increasing corporate legal work as boards of directors cope with demands from sophisticated investors and proxy contests when those investors seek a board seat, according to The National Law Journal. The report notes that as directors are increasingly confronted by sophisticated activist shareholders with their own legal advisers, they are relying on advice from the company’s outside lawyers.

headline: Silicon Valley Makes Clean-Tech Pitch to Washington
abstract: Seeing green in more ways than one, some big names from Silicon Valley on Wednesday urged Washington to double its funding of energy research, The San Jose Mercury New reported. The chief executives and venture investors used a day of meetings organized by TechNet, an organization set up by technology executives, to try and convince members of the Bush administration and Congress, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, that they need a sustained federal commitment to research, and changes in tax policy to spur the development of clean technology.

headline: Texas Pacific One of 11 Bidders for Alitalia
abstract: Shares of Alitalia, Italy’s largest airline, jumped as much as 4.9 percent as a plan to sell the state’s stake in the unprofitable carrier attracted 11 possible bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and UniCredit. The stock gained as much as 5.4 cents to 1.15 euros ($1.49) a share and was up 3.4 percent in Milan, valuing Rome-based Alitalia at 1.57 billion euros ($2 billion). Texas Pacific, which is part of a consortium buying Qantas Airways Ltd., Australia’s biggest carrier, said it would invite Italian and foreign investors to join an eventual offer to buy the company.

headline: Raines Seeks Curb on Fannie Mae Regulator
abstract: Fannie Mae’s former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court Wednesday to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him. James B. Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, “has prejudged the charges” against him “and cannot serve as the impartial decision maker that due process requires,” Mr. Raines said in a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. On Dec. 18, the agency sued Mr. Raines; a former chief financial officer, J. Timothy Howard; and Fannie Mae’s former controller, Leanne G. Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.

headline: Allianz to Sell BMW Stake
abstract: Allianz, Europe’s biggest insurer, is selling a stake worth as much 750 million euros ($973 million) in BMW, the world’s largest maker of luxury cars. Merrill Lynch is managing the offer of 16.1 million shares of BMW. The stake is being offered for between 45.55 euros and 46.55 euros a share to investors today, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Permira and Centaurus Are Said to Be in Talks with Atos
abstract: Two British firms — Permira, the buyout group, and Centaurus, an activist hedge fund — have proposed a 4 billion euro ($5.3 billion) deal for Atos Origin, a French information technology services group, the Financial Times reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Atos confirmed Thursday that it had received an informal bid, but did not disclose the bidders. Shares in the company surged 25.2 percent to 49.50 euros a share on Thursday.

headline: Northwest Reaches Deal to Buy Feeder Airline
abstract: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that it had reached an agreement to buy the regional feeder airline Mesaba, although it was not clear that Mesaba’s parent company would accept it. Both airlines are in bankruptcy protection.

headline: DoubleClick Said to Consider Sale
abstract: DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.

headline: The iPhone Rumors Are Right…Finally
abstract: OK, so after three years of being wrong, the rumor sites were finally right. Now there IS an Apple cellphone. Or, rather, will be one in June.

headline: AirTran Raises Midwest Offer to $345 Million
abstract: Just after US Airways bumped up its unsolicited bid for Delta Air Lines, AirTran Airways has applied the gas to its own efforts to acquire Midwest Air Group. AirTran, a discount airline based in Orlando, Fla., raised its bid 19 percent, to $345 million Thursday, making the offer directly to shareholders and putting pressure on Midwest Air’s management. Last month, Midwest rejected AirTran’s initial offer of $290 million as too low, and on Wednesday, the airline unveiled a plan to add routes and update its fleet to help convince shareholders it should remain independent.

headline: Study Links Bear Stearns to Subprime Mess
abstract: Bear Stearns was among the Wall Street firms that helped fuel the meltdown in the subprime mortgage sector by failing to adequately monitor the quality of the loans they were buying, a credit-research firm, CreditSights, concluded in a study. An unidentified Bear Stearns executive told The New York Post that the research firm “got it wrong, period.”

headline: Goldman Media Banker to Defect to Credit Suisse, Report Says
abstract: Sebastian Grigg, one of Europe’s best-connected media bankers, is in talks to leave Goldman Sachs for Credit Suisse, where he would become head of British investment banking, according to The Financial Times. Mr. Grigg, who The F.T. said was close to finalizing the terms of the move Sunday night, has worked at Goldman Sachs since the start of his banking career and has advised prominent United States and European media owners in recent years, including the publisher Houghton Mifflin and VNU.

headline: Icahn May Take Sands Stake from Troubled GB Holdings
abstract: GB Holdings, which is liquidating its assets, will seek approval of a plan anchored by Carl Icahn’s $53 million offer to buy the debtor’s stake in Atlantic City’s Sands Hotel & Casino. Chief Judge Judith Wizmur in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden set Jan. 30 for a confirmation hearing on GB’s eighth modified disclosure statement, records show. The plan requires Mr. Icahn to pay $53 million for GB’s remaining 28.2 percent interest in Atlantic Coast Entertainment Holdings, one of his affiliates.

headline: Burkle and Broad May Raise Tribune Bid, Report Says
abstract: The auction for Tribune may indeed be set for another round. With less than a week to go before Tribune is scheduled to conclude its six-month strategic review, the Los Angeles billionaires Ronald Burkle and Eli Broad are considering raising their bid for the media company, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Shares of Kraft Foods Expected to Fall After Spinoff From Altria
abstract: The Altria Group is expected to announce the terms of the long-awaited spinoff of its stake in Kraft Foods on Wednesday, and several analysts said they expected Kraft’s shares to decline in the near term. Altria owns more than 88 percent of Kraft, the largest maker of food products in the United States, and is expected to disburse shares among Altria shareholders.

headline: Chicago Merc Says Deal Is Still On
abstract: Responding to the IntercontinentalExchange‘s surprise bid for its would-be merger partner, CME Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, sounded unruffled Thursday. In a news release, the company said that its $8 billion deal to combine with CBOT Holdings, which runs the Chicago Board of Trade, would proceed as planned, despite Intercontinental’s bombshell $9.9 billion offer for CBOT. In a brief statement, the CME said simply this:

headline: Hedge Fund Money to Play Role in Political Races
abstract: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged in the last several years as a potentially powerful force in politics, as underscored by the significant role it is playing in the presidential aspirations of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. says. During the 2006 election cycle, executives who work at the 30 biggest hedge funds made $2.8 million in contributions to political candidates or party committees, almost double the amount in 2000.

headline: Pennsylvania Merger Creates Giant Health Insurer
abstract: Pennsylvania’s two largest health insurers agreed on Wednesday to merge in a deal that had been in the works for years and gives the two nonprofits control over most of the state’s health insurance market. The boards of Independence Blue Cross of Philadelphia and Highmark of Pittsburgh separately approved a merger that would create the nation’s third-largest health insurer behind the UnitedHealth Group and Wellpoint.

headline: Express Scripts Says It Can’t Raise Caremark Bid
abstract: Acknowledging its weakened position, Express Scripts said Monday that it woud not raise its offer for rival Caremark Rx without the chance to conduct due diligence, which Caremark has refused to allow. The announcement appears to put CVS in a position to win the bitter takeover feud for Caremark, a bitter fight that has played out in public and in the courts since December. In a press release, Express Scripts criticized Caremark’s merger process as “flawed” and continued to urge Caremark’s shareholders to vote against the merger with CVS, the nation’s largest drugstore chain.

headline: Home Depot to Review Nardelli’s Pay
abstract: Home Depot, the home improvement store chain, said Monday that its board would require that two-thirds of its independent directors approve any compensation granted to Robert L. Nardelli, the former chairman and chief executive. The decision, made last Thursday but not disclosed until Monday in a regulatory filing, follows an uproar over Mr. Nardelli’s pay.

headline: Goldman Sachs: An Embarassment of Riches?
abstract: Lloyd Blankfein appears to have little in common with Marie Antoinette, but readers of Michael M. Thomas’s fiery opinion column in this week’s New York Observer can be forgiven for thinking otherwise. Mr. Thomas, a former investment banker and observer of Wall Street manners, has produced an incendiary diatribe that focuses on the year-end bonuses recently doled out at Goldman Sachs, where Mr. Blankfein is chief executive. Using revolutionary imagery, Mr. Thomas suggests that Goldman’s bonuses could become a touchstone for a national (and possibly irrational) debate on the wealth gap.

headline: 3i Targets U.S. With New Investment Team
abstract: The 3i Group, a private equity and venture capital firm based in London, said Thursday that it had formed a new division and opened a New York office as part of a plan to increase its investments in United States companies. The firm said its U.S. Growth Capital team will typically make investments of $20 million to $200 million in privately owned companies.

headline: Upstart Video Game Publisher to Focus on Small Developers
abstract: Some video-game veterans plan to announce on Monday the formation of a new publisher that they hope will act as the equivalent of an independent film company for small game developers.

headline: Zell Bid for Tribune Gains Traction, Again
abstract: The Tribune Company, it seems, is again warming up to the offer tabled by real estate mogul Samuel Zell. After reports surfaced last week that the Tribune Co. had cooled to the Mr. Zell’s proposal, The New York Times says that the mercury is rising.

headline: European Commission Takes Spain to Court over Endesa
abstract: The European Commission took Spain to the highest European Union court on Wednesday for interfering in the $56.5 billion bid by the German utility E.On for Endesa. The move marks the latest legal hurdle in the takeover battle for Endesa, Spain’s biggest utility, amid accusations of economic nationalism and fears that the deal could spend years in litigation.

headline: When a Stake Is Not a Stake
abstract: Consider what happens when a hedge fund buys stock in a company — giving it voting rights in various matters of importance to all shareholders — but then uses other investments to reduce or cancel out the economic risk associated with the holding. Paul Atkins, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, said this common situation could raise concerns as some corporate-governance groups seek to give shareholders greater influence in a proxy vote. He told The Financial Times that hedge funds “have used financial derivatives to influence the voting for acquisitions but where they don’t have the economic interest.”

headline: Balfour Betty Hammers Out Deal for Centex Unit
abstract: British construction group Balfour Beatty said yesterday it was buying U.S. rival Centex Construction for $362 million in cash. The company, part of America’s fourth-biggest housebuilder, Centex, specializes in military housing with an order book worth $5.6 billion.

headline: Icahn Goes Wireless With $50 Million
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier, has invested $50 million in a wireless content startup, Motricity. Motricity, which announced in August it plans to raise $75 million from investors, said it has completed the equity funding agreement with Mr. Icahn through “an affiliated company.” Mr. Icahn’s son, Brett Icahn, an investment analyst with New York-based Icahn Associates and a number of affiliated companies, will join Motricity’s board of directors as a result of the investment.

headline: Bumptop Desktop
abstract: A desktop filing system uses icons that behave like actual sheets and bundles of paper.

headline: Storm Clouds Gather as Congress Takes Up Net’s Future
abstract: The starting gun was fired in what could turn into a battle royale between major Internet players. Senior lawmakers, emboldened by the recent restrictions on AT&T and the change in control of Congress, have begun drafting legislation that would prevent high-speed Internet companies from charging content providers for priority access.

headline: Nymex Stockholders Sell $956 Million of Shares
abstract: NYMEX Holdings, the parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange, sold shares valued at $956 million in a secondary offering of shares held by NYMEX stockholders. The offering is expected to close on March 27.

headline: Blackstone Continues to Unload Equity Office Properties
abstract: Even with the sale of more than $18 billion in assets of Equity Office Properties Trust, Blackstone Group does not appear to be done dealing. In the latest sell off of properties it acquired in the biggest leveraged buyout in history, Blackstone sold 24 properties in downtown Los Angeles and Orange County, Calif., to Maguire Properties for $2.88 billion.

headline: The (Potential) Rise of Silicon Alley 2.0
abstract: Unlike the last Internet boom, entrepreneurs in “Silicon Alley,” New York’s venture-capital community, is filled with older, more experienced entrepreneurs who focus more on long-term profits. Internet heavyweights like Google have opened up ambitious new offices in the Big Apple. But some things never change, according to The New York Sun’s Jay Akasie: Just like in the olden days, Silicon Alley still takes a distant second to the West Coast.

headline: A Genial C.E.O. Provides an Updraft for the Airline Industry
abstract: Despite robust resistance by Delta Air Lines management and employees to US Airways’ unsolicited $10.5 billion bid for the rival carrier, there may be one positive outcome everyone can agree on. A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again, writes The New York Times’ Jeff Bailey.

headline: Rejected, British Tobacco Giant Still Wants to Buy French-Spanish Rival
abstract: Imperial Tobacco of Britain said on Sunday that it would continue “friendly” efforts to buy a Franco-Spanish rival, Altadis, which rejected its initial attempt at 45 euros a share. Imperial, which makes Lambert & Butler and Embassy cigarettes, offered 11.5 billion euros ($15.3 billion) for Altadis on Thursday, beginning a possible bidding war in the consolidating tobacco industry.

headline: Google Guys Aren’t Writing Off Old Media
abstract: The sight of Larry Page and Sergey Brin is enough to strike fear into a newspaper editor’s heart. After all, the giant Internet company they founded, Google, has become a powerful force for democratizing the distribution of news, blogs and other forms of information, a trend that has left many in the industry bracing for the day when the print newspaper is dead.

headline: Lender Faces Credit Crisis With Banks
abstract: The Wall Street banks and brokerage firms that just a few months ago welcomed New Century Financial with open arms and gave it credit lines worth billions of dollars have quickly shut off the spigot, forcing it ever closer to bankruptcy. New Century, one of the biggest mortgage lenders to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit, said in a securities filing Monday that all its lenders had frozen their credit lines and were demanding that it buy back $8.4 billion in loans that it issued using the money it borrowed from the banks – money New Century says it does not have.

headline: Man Group to Spin Off U.S. Brokerage Unit
abstract: Man Group, the British alternative asset manager, said on Friday it would demerge its U.S. brokerage unit and list it in New York. It also said group pretax profits were likely to be in line with consensus market expectations. The listing of a majority interest in the unit, Man Financial, will take place in the third quarter of 2007, subject to favorable market conditions, the firm said.

headline: Israeli Property Consortium Buys Marriott Hotels from Royal Bank of Scotland
abstract: Delek Real Estate, an Israeli property company, and its partners have agreed to buy 47 British hotels operated by Marriott International from Royal Bank of Scotland for about $2.1 billion. Delek will purchase a 17 percent stake in the hotels through its Delek-Belron International unit, while Electra Real Estate will buy a 9.9 percent stake.

headline: FIA Acts on New Role for Car Manufacturers
abstract: In keeping with the announcement in November by the International Automobile Federation and the Grand Prix Manufacturers Association that peace had broken out between the two groups, the FIA today announced the creation of a Formula One Manufacturers’ Advisory Commission.

headline: NimbleGen, a Biotech Firm, Considers Initial Offering
abstract: A biotech firm, NimbleGen Systems, filed an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $75 million in common stock. The company, based in Madison, Wis., makes microarrays, or biological assays, and related products for the life sciences research market.

headline: Equity Office Bondholders Pressure Blackstone for More Money
abstract: A group of Equity Office Properties Trust bondholders said Friday that they had received commitments from enough investors to block the Blackstone Group‘s tender offer for $725 million of their bonds. Investors owning a majority of bonds have agreed not to tender their securities, according to a statement from the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York. While Equity Office can still move ahead with the sale without approval from the bondholders, the group could force Blackstone to increase its offer, raising the $36 billion cost of what would be the biggest leveraged buyout ever.

headline: Travelport Plans I.P.O. for Orbitz Unit
abstract: Travelport, a travel-services company owned by private equity firms, said Wednesday it plans to sell part of its Orbitz Worldwide unit in an initial public offering, which it expects to complete in the third quarter. The size of the stake to be sold and the price are still undetermined, Travelport said.

headline: Icahn Backs Three for Cyberonics Board
abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he planned to back three nominees by Metropolitan Capital Advisors to the board of Cyberonics, a medical device maker under investigation for its stock options dating practices. Mr. Icahn holds a 9.77 percent stake in Cyberonics, which is scheduled to have its annual stockholders meeting on Feb. 1, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Company management is trying to have shareholders re-elect three directors; Metropolitan Capital wants to replace all three.

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: Tribune Considering Late Offer From Real Estate Magnate
abstract: Sam Zell, the billionaire Chicago real estate maverick, made a last-minute proposal to buy the company.

headline: Trying to Regain Initiative, Bush Looks Ahead
abstract: President Bush today pledged to work with the incoming Democratic Congress but held fast to his own goals.

headline: Researchers Track Down a Plague of Fake Web Pages
abstract: Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind thousands of spam Web pages.

headline: Chip Makers Settle Patent Dispute
abstract: Toshiba and Hynix Semiconductor agreed to end patent disputes over flash memory chips used to store data in electronic devices like digital cameras and MP3 players. Financial terms were not disclosed. Each company will get a license to the other’s semiconductor technology and signed product supply agreements. The accord settles all patent-related litigation in Japan and the United States, including three disputes before the International Trade Commission in Washington. The legal battles between the companies began in November 2004 when Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, sued Hynix, based in Ichon, South Korea, after the companies failed to extend a licensing agreement.

headline: Ecuador: President’s Supporters Try to Storm Congress
abstract: Hundreds of protesters tried to storm Congress, forcing violent clashes with the police. The protesters, largely supporters of President Rafael Correa, a leftist economist, had gathered to criticize an effort by lawmakers to raise their own salaries and to show support for a plan by Mr. Correa to convene an assembly to rewrite parts of the Constitution. Tensions have been building between Mr. Correa and Congress.

headline: S.E.C. Approves New Method for Companies to Value Stock Options
abstract: The S.E.C. gave tentative approval to one auction method, while warning that auditors should study the results of the auction before actually using the results in their financial statements.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:.

headline: Japan Stands by Declaration on ‘Comfort Women’
abstract: The government repeated today that there was no evidence that the Japanese military had forcibly recruited women into sex slavery during World War II.

headline: China: Petroleum Seller Acquired
abstract: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, Asia’s largest oil refiner, will buy the Hong Kong petroleum products distribution unit of China Resources Enterprise for 4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($511 million). The two companies signed a framework agreement, and the final purchase price remains subject to review, according to China Resources. A formal agreement will be signed in mid-April, the company said. The Beijing-based China Petroleum and Chemical, which is known as Sinopec, is expanding its refining and fuel distribution system to keep pace with the rapidly growing Chinese economy.

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about Martek Biosciences misidentified the headquarters city of D. A. Davidson & Company, which employs Timothy S. Ramey, a food and beverage analyst who now has an “underperform” recommendation on Martek’s stock. Although Mr. Ramey’s office is in Portland, Ore., D. A. Davidson is based in Great Falls, Mont.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Questioning Radio Deal
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission has questioned Congressional testimony by the architect of a proposed satellite radio merger.

headline: Can Video Help Save the Satellite Radio Business?
abstract: Besides the scrutiny of the proposed combination between XM and Sirius, the satellite radio business is facing huge changes.

headline: Draft Law Keeps Central Control Over Oil in Iraq
abstract: The law would distribute all oil revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers.

headline: Child Pornography on Vienna Computer Prompts Worldwide Hunt
abstract: Austrian authorities said they have gathered information on more than 2,360 individuals from 77 countries who tried to view child pornography.

headline: Iran Turns Up Volume in Face-Off Over Captured Britons
abstract: In a new video broadcast on Friday, a British Royal Marine purportedly apologized “deeply” for entering Iranian waters without permission.

headline: Strong Computer Sales Help H-P to 26% Gain
abstract: Sales of notebook computers rose 40 percent in the first quarter.

headline: Somali Islamists’ No. 2 Leader Surrenders in Kenyan Capital
abstract: The second in command of Somalia’s defeated Islamist forces, described as a moderate Muslim and potential peacemaker, has surrendered to Kenyan authorities.

headline: Official in Furor on AIDS Policy in South Africa Is Hospitalized
abstract: Dr. Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, who promoted garlic and beetroot as protection against AIDS, is in a hospital with severe anemia and a lung infection.

headline: Trade Deficit Improves for Third Straight Month
abstract: The United States’s balance of trade with the rest of the world improved in November for the third straight month.

headline: Boston Scientific Considers Spinning Off Division
abstract: The stent maker predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion of the company to the public.

headline: Group Weighs Rival Bid for Equity Office REIT
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management is said to be considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust.

headline: Protesters Oppose Plan to Expand American Base in Northern Italy
abstract: Residents of the area say they are concerned over the possibility of terrorist attacks, military traffic congestion and environmental damage.

headline: Rivals Offer $38 Billion for a REIT
abstract: The $38 billion offer has set off the biggest buyout battle since the landmark fight for RJR Nabisco nearly two decades ago.

headline: Bomb Kills Doctor in Pakistani Border Area
abstract: The attack was another indication of a creeping militancy in Pakistan’s border regions.

headline: Iraqi Forces in Fierce Battle With Gunmen
abstract: Iraqi forces backed by U.S. helicopters and tanks traded fire for 15 hours with hundreds of gunmen near the southern city of Najaf.

headline: Afghan Suicide Bomber Wounds 6 Soldiers
abstract: A suicide bomber disguised as a doctor blew himself up Tuesday morning at the opening of a hospital ward built by American forces in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: Pope Reaffirms View Opposing Gay Marriage and Abortion
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI said that Roman Catholic politicians were “especially” obligated to defend the church’s stance in their public duties.

headline: As Airlines Surge, Pilots Want Share
abstract: With most of the industry returning to profitability, pilots are demanding that they should recoup some of the pay and other benefits they gave up in recent years.

headline: Britain Won’t Follow U.S. in Adding Troops in Iraq
abstract: Britain, America’s closest ally in Iraq, said today that it would not follow the United States in raising troop levels there and signaled that it would pursue its own planned handover of security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

headline: South Africa: Soweto Gets Luxury Train Service
abstract: The commuter service Metrorail will add luxury express train service next month between Johannesburg and Soweto, the township that once symbolized the poverty and oppression of blacks under apartheid rule. Aimed at business clients who shun Metrorail’s usually hot and crowded commuter cars, the 530-seat train underscores Soweto’s rise from impoverished township to an increasingly attractive location for the black middle and upper classes. The service will feature uniformed attendants, bar service and ticketing and boarding facilities separate from ordinary trains.

headline: Gambling Subpoenas on Wall St.
abstract: Four investment banks have been issued subpoenas in an investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry.

headline: Ford Loses Record $12.7 Billion in ’06
abstract: The Ford Motor Company had perhaps the worst year in its 103-year history in 2006, losing $5.8 billion in the fourth quarter alone.

headline: Medical Data on Empire Blue Cross Members May Be Lost
abstract: A compact disc holding vital medical and other personal information of about 75,000 members of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has disappeared.

headline: Times Company Nominates Board Member
abstract: The New York Times Company has nominated Daniel H. Cohen to its board after Cathy J. Sulzberger chose not to stand for re-election.

headline: A Video Camera That Won’t Be a Burden to Carry to the Reunion
abstract: Like many new camcorders, Sony’s new Handycam models record straight to a hard drive, providing up to 60 gigabytes of room.

headline: Non-Celebrities on the Web, Seeming to Make Non-Pitches
abstract: Marketers are turning to unusual personalities who offer the kind of novelty and freshness that young people might blog about, link to and comment on in chats.

headline: Japanese Officials Issue Warning on Flu Drug
abstract: The warning against giving the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu to teenagers follows reports that some children who took the drug exhibited bizarre behavior, news reports say.

headline: The U.S. Is Losing Market Share. So What?
abstract: The United States is losing market share in the global economy, and that is not necessarily a bad thing.

headline: For Newsweek Subscribers, a Question: Smoking or Nonsmoking?
abstract: Newsweek says it will provide tobacco ad-free copies of its magazine to any individual subscribers who request them.

headline: Calm at Jerusalem Holy Site in Spite of Calls for Protest
abstract: Despite calls by Muslim religious figures for mass protests today against Israeli excavation work near a holy site, the Old City section of Jerusalem was largely calm today.

headline: Pentagon to Fill Iraq Reconstruction Jobs Temporarily
abstract: A small number of military personnel and Defense Department civilians will fill about one-third of the 350 new State Department jobs in Iraq.

headline: China: Intel Considers Building Chip Plant
abstract: Intel is considering building its first semiconductor factory in Asia in the northeastern Chinese city of Dalian. China’s central government has approved the project, said Gao Fujun, assistant counsel at the Dalian Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Bureau. An Intel spokesman, Mark Miller, said the company was in talks with several governments about its next chip factory. The company won approval to build a factory in the Dalian Economic and Technological Development Zone, Mr. Gao said. Intel has assembly and testing plants in Shanghai and Chengdu.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Remain Apart on Trade Negotiations
abstract: Gaps on issues like beef and automobiles are delaying a deal the Bush administration calls the most sweeping since Nafta.

headline: Damaged Ship Spilling Cargo Off British Coast
abstract: A damaged and listing cargo ship was spilling fuel and cargo containers into stormy seas off the southwest coast of England, near Devon, British officials said tonight. Some of the containers held hazardous materials.

headline: ABN AMRO Urges Shareholders to Reject Breakup
abstract: AMSTERDAM, March 28 (Reuters) - The Dutch bank ABN AMRO (NYSE:ABN) on Wednesday urged shareholders to reject plans by a hedge fund to break-up or sell the company, as it pursues a merger with Britain's Barclays to create a bank worth over $175 billion.

headline: Do They Still Want Their MTV?
abstract: MTV has managed to reinvent itself continuously, but finding the edge was simpler before competition for its core demographic started coming from all fronts.

headline: Farmers to Plant Largest Amount of Corn Since ’44
abstract: Growers intend to plant more than 90 million acres in an effort to meet demands for ethanol, food and feed.

headline: Airbus Workers in France Protest Planned Job Cuts
abstract: Thousands of Airbus employees took to the streets to protest planned job cuts that have drawn fire amid a heated presidential campaign.

headline: Options Developments at 2 Companies
abstract: The UnitedHealth Group said its former chief executive entered into an options repricing agreement with the company to avoid a potential tax liability.

headline: Report Accuses Belfast Police of Collusion in Gang Killings
abstract: A 160-page report indicated that police handlers turned a blind eye to tips from informants about at least 10 killings and 10 attempted killings.

headline: U.S. Fugitive Starts Over in Namibia
abstract: The former chief executive of Comverse Technology has formed a company in Namibia that will invest in construction, tourism and agriculture.

headline: Qwest Records Quarterly Profit and Rise in Internet Subscribers
abstract: The phone company reported a fourth-quarter profit, helped by a gain tied to the sale of real estate and an increase in high-speed Internet subscribers.

headline: Jimmy Choo Sold for $364 Million
abstract: TowerBrook Capital Partners has agreed to buy Jimmy Choo Ltd., for $364 million.

headline: French Join U.S. Résistance Over London Traffic Charge
abstract: Diplomats from several countries are refusing to pay the congestion charge, calling it a tax from which they should be exempt.

headline: People
abstract: People.

headline: Smith & Wollensky to Sell Restaurants Outside of New York
abstract: Smith & Wollensky to Sell Restaurants Outside of New York.

headline: 2 Financial Institutions Find Common Cause in New York
abstract: The country’s largest black financial institution is teaming up with Merrill Lynch to help the firm entree into minority neighborhoods.

headline: To Counter Iran’s Role in Iraq, Bush Moves Beyond Diplomacy
abstract: In promising to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, President Bush returned to a strategy of confrontation in dealing with Tehran.

headline: European Officials Agree to Widen Economic Sanctions Against Iran Over Nuclear Program
abstract: European officials said a resolution negotiated over the last week should go far toward satisfying the Bush administration.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Alumni to Lead a CNBC Monthly Magazine
abstract: The financial news network CNBC is introducing an hourlong monthly newsmagazine, “Business Nation.”

headline: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says He’ll Leave
abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

headline: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

headline: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortress’s I.P.O.
abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

headline: The LCD Juggernaut
abstract: More than half of American households will have an HDTV this year.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
abstract: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Google‘s “Radical Benefit for Humanity” fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest “innovation” for local philanthropists: “Glamour.”

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
abstract: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies – Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK – agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

headline: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank‘s asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

headline: S.E.C. Is Looking at Stock Trading
abstract: An investigation has begun into whether Wall Street bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients.

headline: Can Common Sense Be Legislated?
abstract: A senator’s proposal to tackle the problem of “iPod oblivion” is seen by some as a bit nanny-minded and intrusive.

headline: People
abstract: People.

headline: In Kenya’s Capital, a Sense That Danger Is Ever Stronger
abstract: Nairobi, once a favorite playground for Westerners in Africa, is spinning out of control.

headline: Court Backs  White House on Detainees
abstract: A federal appeals court today upheld of a new law that strips federal courts of the authority to review the cases of foreign prisoners held at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Verizon Sells Venezuela Stake
abstract: Venezuela’s government agreed to buy the stake held by Verizon Communications in Compañía Anónima Nacional Teléfonos de Venezuela for $572 million.

headline: Iraqi Militants Launch Attack on U.S. Base
abstract: In a rare coordinated assault on a U.S. combat outpost north of Baghdad, insurgents killed two American soldiers and wounded at least 17 more.

headline: Israel: Police Say Tip Thwarts Suicide Attack
abstract: Acting on a tip, the police arrested a Palestinian suspected of planning a suicide bombing in the Tel Aviv area, the authorities said. The police set up roadblocks around Tel Aviv and conducted an intensive search, arresting the Palestinian, identified as Omar Abu Rob, at an apartment in the suburb of Bat Yam. He led the police to the nearby city of Rishon Letzion, where they said he had hidden explosives for the attack. Several men suspected of helping of him were also arrested.

headline: New Setback in North Korean Nuclear Talks
abstract: Negotiations stalled over disagreements about the size and timing of the aid package to be provided in exchange for shutting down nuclear weapons facilities.

headline: Indonesia: Boy Has Bird Flu; 6 Others Tested
abstract: A new human cluster of avian flu cases could be emerging in a suburb of the capital, Jakarta, according to Indonesian news reports. One case of H5N1 flu, the country’s 75th, was confirmed by the Health Ministry over the weekend; it was in a 14-year-old boy who had reportedly buried a flock of backyard ducks that died suddenly. He was alive but using a respirator to breathe. A local radio station and news outlets said six other people from the same town  at least three of them related to him  were hospitalized with flu symptoms in Jakarta, being treated with Tamiflu and awaiting test results. Indonesia has failed to get its poultry epidemic under control since it emerged in 2005.

headline: South Africa: Man Fights Off Crocodile
abstract: A 37-year-old man, Michael Sithole, fought off a crocodile with a switchblade after it seized his leg as he relaxed on a river bank. He said he had taken a dip in the Letaba River, in Limpopo Province, after a day of fishing and was sitting on a rock “when I suddenly felt a bite on my thigh.” He said that he grabbed a knife he had used to slice bread for his lunch but that by the time he opened the blade, the crocodile had dragged him to the middle of the river. He stabbed it in the stomach, forcing it to flee. “Thank goodness the knife was still new, so it was sharp enough,” said Mr. Sithole, who was treated for injuries to his right leg and hands, according to the South African Press Association.

headline: 4 Editors, an Art Director and a Shot at the Magazine Title
abstract: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists is among the finalists announced for the National Magazine Awards, the industry’s most prestigious prize.

headline: Awaiting a Compromise on YouTube
abstract: The problem for both Google and Viacom is that copyright law is filled with compromises and ambiguity.

headline: Runs, Hits and Calories
abstract: Think you have a hard time eating right while traveling? Imagine if all your business was done in the ballpark.

headline: A Cheeky Broadsheet’s Tabloid Makeover
abstract: The New York Observer’s new tabloid format is still pinkish, and still plays host to some terrific writing. But reading the new Observer also provides a palpable feeling of loss.

headline: After 40 Years in French Politics, Chirac to Retire
abstract: In a deeply personal address to the nation, Jacques Chirac said he would not seek a third term as president of France.

headline: Can Executives Find Happiness With a BlackBerry Minus Its Scroll Wheel?
abstract: Executives who are longtime BlackBerry users will have to teach their right thumb some new tricks if they switch to a model introduced on Monday.

headline: ‘Little Mosque’ Defuses Hate With Humor
abstract: When it came to funny television shows in Canada, producers had a reliable stable of topics; Islam was not one of them, until now.

headline: Iran’s President Defiant on Nuclear Program
abstract: President Ahmadinejad said Iran will halt its uranium enrichment program only if Western powers do the same.

headline: Halliburton Moving C.E.O. From Houston to Dubai
abstract: The move is part of a strategy by the energy services giant to concentrate its efforts in the Middle East.

headline: Working in France, in the Style of Silicon Valley
abstract: Europe’s new entrepreneurs are turning West to learn the start-up culture bred in Silicon Valley before coming back to apply their learning.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: FREE PASSPORT PHOTOS In a marketing tie-in to new federal requirements that air travelers present passports when returning from Canada, Mexico, Central and South America and the Caribbean, JetBlue is offering free passport photos this month to customers traveling through Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport. The photos will be taken Thursdays through Saturdays near Gate 12A. The promotion is offered in partnership with the Bermuda Department of Tourism and the Nassau Paradise Island Promotion Board.

headline: Signs of a Deal Seen in North Korea Nuclear Talks
abstract: America’s envoy said he was “cautiously optimistic” about talks to shut down North Korea’s nuclear program.

headline: Home Depot Profit Falls as Wal-Mart Reports a Rebound
abstract: A report delivered by Home Depot’s new chief executive revealed how much work it will take to turn around the home improvement chain.

headline: Correction: History, Digitized (and Abridged)
abstract: An article last Sunday about the digitization of historical documents referred incorrectly to a 1968 letter from Jacqueline Kennedy to Leonard Bernstein, part of a Bernstein collection that was donated to the Library of Congress. The letter, which thanked Bernstein for conducting a Gustav Mahler work at the funeral of Robert F. Kennedy, was referring to the Adagietto movement from Mahler’s Fifth Symphony; Mrs. Kennedy did not thank him in the letter for conducting “Mahler’s Requiem.” (Mahler never composed a requiem.).

headline: Commerce Department Says U.S. Economy Is Weaker Than Expected
abstract: The economy inched ahead by 2.2 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, down sharply from the government’s prior estimate of 3.5 percent.

headline: How to Show That You’re No Gordon Gekko
abstract: Buried in the Blackstone Group’s 221-page-thick prospectus is an unusual paragraph: The firm says it plans to start a charitable foundation.

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Canada: Hotel Operator Posts a Profit
abstract: Four Seasons Hotels, the world’s largest operator of luxury hotels, reported a fourth-quarter profit on higher room revenue. Four Seasons, based in Toronto, said profit was $16.9 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.8 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. The company said it had higher costs in the year-earlier period related to retirement benefits and lower revenue after ending its lease for the Pierre in New York. Revenue rose 19 percent, to $69.8 million, from $58.5 million, because of an increase in hotel management and ownership fees. Revenue for each available room worldwide rose 14 percent, to $258.13; at properties in the United States, it was up 8.4 percent, to $297.83. Four Seasons agreed last month to be sold to a group of private investors.

headline: Portugal: Utility Buys Texas Wind Farm
abstract: EDP-Energias de Portugal, an electric utility, said that it had agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from the Goldman Sachs Group for $2.15 billion to more than double its wind-power production. EDP, which is based in Lisbon, said it would borrow the money to pay for Horizon, which is based in Houston and has assets in 15 states. EDP has branched into Spain and the United States because it faces growing competition in Portugal. The market in the United States has gained appeal because the federal government has extended incentives for wind energy.
